A typical admission staff at a college includes a dean or vice president for admission or enrollment management, middle-level managers or assistant directors, admission officers, and administrative support staff.<ref name=tws3JanN113/> The chief enrollment management officer is sometimes the highest-paid position in the department, earning $121,000 on average in 2010, while admissions officers average only $35,000, according to one estimate.<ref name=tws3JanN113/><ref name=tws3JanN214/> Admissions officers tend to be in the 30-to-40 age demographic.<ref name=tws3JanN212>{{cite news |author= Kelly Truong |title= Admission Officials' Tweets Fall on Deaf Ears |newspaper= The Chronicle of Higher Education |quote= ... but college admissions officers typically fall into the 30-to-40 age demographic ... |date= July 1, 2010 |url= http://chronicle.com/blogs/wiredcampus/admission-officials-tweets-fall-on-deaf-ears/25254 |accessdate= January 14, 2013}}</ref> They are chosen for their experience in admissions, aptitude for statistics and data analysis, experience in administration and marketing and public relations.<ref name=tws3JanN113>{{cite news |author1=Melissa E. Clinedinst |author2=Sarah F. Hurley |author3=David A. Hawkins |title= 2011 State of College Admissions |newspaper= National Association for College Admission Counseling (NACAC) |quote= Previous admission experience ... statistics/data analysis ... higher education administration ... marketing/public relations ... |year= 2011 |url= http://www.nacacnet.org/research/PublicationsResources/Marketplace/research/Pages/StateofCollegeAdmission.aspx |accessdate= January 14, 2013 }}</ref> They serve dual roles as counselors and recruiters, and do not see themselves as [[Marketing|marketers]] or salespeople, according to one view.<ref name=tws3JanN214>{{cite news |author= Eric Hoover |title= On 'Finite' Recruitment |newspaper= The Chronicle of Higher Education |quote= ... They are counselors, but also recruiters. They use marketing techniques, but many don't like to use the "m word." ... |date= August 4, 2010 |url= http://chronicle.com/blogs/headcount/on-finite-recruitment/26001 |accessdate= January 14, 2013 }}</ref> They are evaluated on how well they "represent their college, manage their office, recruit staff members, and work with other administrators".<ref name=tws3JanN214/> Michele Hernandez suggested there were basically two types of officers: a first group of personable, sharp, people-oriented go-getter types who were often recent college grads; a second group was somewhat out-of-touch "lifers" who often did not graduate from a highly selective college.{{sfn|Hernandez|2009|pp=1–3}} Officers are generally paid an annual salary, although there have been reports of some recruiters paid on the basis of how many students they bring to a college, such as recruiters working abroad to recruit foreign students to U.S. universities.<ref name=tws3JanN214/>
Many colleges and universities work hard to market themselves, trying to attract the best students and maintain a reputation for academic quality. Colleges spent an average of $585 to recruit each applicant during the 2010 year.<ref name=twsMayO211/><ref name=tws3JanN113/> There are efforts to make increased use of [[social media]] sites such as [[Facebook]] to promote their colleges.<ref name=tws3JanN213>{{cite news |author= Eric Hoover |title= A 'Sea Change' in Admissions |newspaper= The Chronicle of Higher Education |quote= ... rising costs ... impact of the web ... social media such as Facebook or YouTube that admissions offices need to master. |date= June 29, 2011 |url= http://chronicle.com/blogs/headcount/a-sea-change-in-admissions/28421 |accessdate= January 14, 2013 }}</ref> Marketing brochures and other promotional mailings often arrive daily in the hope of persuading high school students to apply to a college. According to Joanne Levy-Prewitt, colleges send "view books" not because they intend to admit them, but "because they want multitudes of students to apply" to improve the college's selectivity ranking and to make sure that they have as many well-qualified applicants as possible from whom to choose the strongest class.<ref name=tws2T22>{{cite news |author= Joanne Levy-Prewitt |title= Juniors should be wary of slick college admission come-ons |work= The Record (Bergen County, NJ) via Highbeam Research |quote= ... If you are a junior in high school, this winter or spring you are very likely to be inundated with glossy view books and slick brochures ... |date= December 30, 2006 |url= http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P1-132960540.html |accessdate= August 20, 2012}}</ref> Colleges get access to names and addresses after students give permission to them after taking the [[PSAT/NMSQT|PSAT]] or [[SAT]] exams.<ref name=tws2T22/>
===Information sources=== ''US News'' compiles a directory of colleges and universities and has made a ranking of them, although the rankings are controversial, some colleges refuse to cooperate, and high school guidance counselors sometimes have major problems with the rankings.<ref name=twsL18>{{cite news |author= Jacques Steinberg |title= 'Best Colleges'? Counselors Beg to Differ With U.S. News |publisher= ''The New York Times'' |date= May 19, 2011 |url= http://thechoice.blogs.nytimes.com/2011/05/19/nacac-on-usnews/ |accessdate= December 12, 2011}}</ref> Other sources rank colleges according to various measures, sell guidebooks, and use their rankings as an entry into college admissions consulting services. [[College Board]] launched a website called BigFuture in 2012 with tools to help the admissions process.<ref name=twsMay2Q934>{{cite news |author= Tanya Caldwell |title= The Start of BigFuture, a New College Planning Web Site |newspaper= The New York Times |date= March 26, 2012 |url= http://thechoice.blogs.nytimes.com/2012/03/26/college-board-bigfuture-web-site/ |accessdate= May 17, 2012 }}</ref> There are services to help expedite the college admissions process, including a web-based service that sells copies of applications that gained the applicant admission to Ivy League colleges.<ref name=tws3JanN215>{{cite news |author= Eric Hoover |title= For Sale: Successful Ivy League Applications—Only $19.99 |newspaper= The Chronicle of Higher Education |quote= ... the Application Project Inc., which sells copies of successful applications to Ivy League colleges. Want to browse applications submitted by 21 members of Brown University's 2009–10 freshman class? You can buy access to them for $19.99 .... |date= October 14, 2010 |url= http://chronicle.com/blogs/headcount/for-sale-successful-ivy-league-applications%E2%80%94only-19-99/27560 |accessdate= January 14, 2013 }}</ref>
===Test preparation firms=== Companies such as the [[College Board]] have offered services to help students prepare for their tests and provide other services, usually web-based, to help students compare schools. Some firms work with schools to provide test preparation advisors who teach students how to take the SAT and [[ACT (test)|ACT]] entrance exams.
==Planning==
===Timing=== {| style="float:left; width:18em; font-weight:bold; border:solid 1px #999999; font-size:.9em; line-height:1.3em; margin:0 0 1em 1em;" cellpadding="4" cellspacing="0" |-style="color:#000080; font-size:2.1em;" valign="top" |Timeline |-style="color:#800000; font-size:1.3em;" valign="top" |Ninth/tenth grade |-style="color:#10365B;" valign="top" | Grades count towards GPA |-style="color:#10365B;" valign="top" | Good study habits |-style="color:#10365B;" valign="top" | Course selection |-style="color:#10365B;" valign="top" | Read, read, read |-style="color:#10365B;" valign="top" | Extracurricular activities |-style="color:#800000; font-size:1.3em;" valign="top" |Eleventh grade |-style="color:#2A6B35;" valign="top" | Fall: PSAT test |-style="color:#2A6B35;" valign="top" | Meet guidance counselor |-style="color:#2A6B35;" valign="top" | Build lists of colleges |-style="color:#2A6B35;" valign="top" | Begin meeting college reps |-style="color:#2A6B35;" valign="top" | College fairs |-style="color:#2A6B35;" valign="top" | Research, visit schools |-style="color:#2A6B35;" valign="top" | Tests: SAT/ACT, SAT Subject Tests, AP/IB exams |-style="color:#2A6B35;" valign="top" | Summer: write essays |-style="color:#800000; font-size:1.3em;" valign="top" |Twelfth grade |-style="color:#0581F1;" valign="top" | Know admissions deadlines |-style="color:#0581F1;" valign="top" | Teacher recommendations |-style="color:#0581F1;" valign="top" | Apply to schools |-style="color:#0581F1;" valign="top" | Ask high school to send transcripts |-style="color:#0581F1;" valign="top" | Winter: FAFSA/CSS forms |-style="color:#0581F1;" valign="top" | Check if colleges received materials |-style="color:#0581F1;" valign="top" | April: acceptances and rejections |-style="color:#0581F1;" valign="top" | Revisit accepting schools |-style="color:#0581F1;" valign="top" | May: deposit is due |} For those intending to enter college immediately after high school, the admissions process usually begins during a student's eleventh grade when a student meets with a guidance counselor, selects some colleges, and perhaps visits a few campuses. The summer before twelfth grade is a time when many applicants finalize application plans and perhaps begin writing essays. Further, they decide whether to apply by early or regular decision. International students may need to take tests showing English-language proficiency such as the [[TOEFL]], [[IELTS]], or [[Pearson Test of English Academic|PTE Academic]].<ref name=twsMayO214/> The twelfth grade is when applications are submitted. The [[CSS Profile|CSS]] can be submitted by October first of the student's twelfth grade, while the FAFSA becomes available on the web after January first.<ref name=tws2V2449>{{cite web |title= Frequently Asked Questions about Finding a College |work= diycollegerankings.com |year= 2012 |url= http://diycollegerankings.com/frequently-asked-questions-about-finding-a-college/ |accessdate= June 22, 2012 }}</ref>
==Selection of colleges==
===Rankings=== {{Main|Rankings of universities in the United States}}
[[File:US News Top 40 Colleges 2007 ranking with names by location.png|thumb|alt=Map of US with names of 40 top colleges.|The ''[[US News]]'' ranking has generated much controversy; this map shows locations of its assessment of the top 40 universities in the US in 2007, with many located in the [[Northeastern United States|Northeast]].]]
There are several [[Rankings of universities in the United States|college and university rankings]] guides published, and they include the ''[[U.S. News and World Report]]'',<ref>{{cite web|url=http://colleges.usnews.rankingsandreviews.com/college|title=US News & World Report rankings|work=US News & World Report|accessdate=September 29, 2014}}</ref>{{sfn|Mamlet|2011|p=127}} [[Business Insider]],<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.businessinsider.com/best-colleges-in-the-us-2014-9?op=1 |title=The 50 Best Colleges in America}}</ref> [[Money Magazine]],<ref>{{cite web|url=https://best-colleges.time.com/money/full-ranking#/list |title=MONEY's Best Colleges |publisher=Time |accessdate=July 31, 2015}}</ref> ''[[The Washington Monthly]]'s '' "College Rankings" issue,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.washingtonmonthly.com/features/2006/0609.libarts.html|title=Washington Monthly's College Rankings|publisher=|accessdate=September 29, 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141107154840/http://www.washingtonmonthly.com/features/2006/0609.libarts.html|archivedate=November 7, 2014|df=mdy-all}}</ref> and ''[[Forbes]] '' "America's Top Colleges" ranking,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/top-colleges/list/|title=Forbes America's Top Colleges Ranking|publisher=|accessdate=July 20, 2015}}</ref> as well as a variety of other groups and organizations that publish rankings based on different factors and using different methodology. For a more comprehensive and detailed look at U.S. university rankings, with top-ranked schools identified, see [[Rankings of universities in the United States]].
Rankings have been the subject of much [[Criticism of college and university rankings (North America)|criticism]]. Since much of the data is provided by colleges themselves, there are opportunities for schools to manipulate the rankings to enhance prestige. There have been instances in which school officials deliberately misreported statistics, such as an admissions dean at [[Claremont McKenna College|Claremont McKenna]] who falsified average SAT statistics,<ref name=twsMayO213>{{cite news |author= Tanya Caldwell |title= Rankings Did Not Motivate College Official Who Falsified SAT Scores, Report Finds |newspaper= The New York Times |date= April 18, 2012 |url= http://thechoice.blogs.nytimes.com/2012/04/18/claremont-mckenna-official-who-falisified-sat-scores-was-not-motivated-by-rankings-report-finds/ |accessdate= May 15, 2012 }}</ref> and a report that [[Emory University]] falsely reported student data for "more than a decade,"<ref name=tws2T44>{{cite news |author= Justin Pope |title= Emory University Sent False Data To Rankings Groups For More Than A Decade: Report |work= Huffington Post |quote= ... Prestigious Emory University intentionally misreported student data to rankings magazines for more than a decade .... |date= August 17, 2012 |url= http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2012/08/20/emory-university-sent-fal_n_1810287.html |accessdate= August 20, 2012 }}</ref> as well as reports of false data from the [[United States Naval Academy]] and [[Baylor University]].<ref name=twsSepN2111>{{cite news |author= Lynn O'Shaughnessy |title= How U.S. News' College Rankings Can Hurt You |newspaper= The College Solution |quote= One of the perverse aspects about the rankings is that turning out thoughtful, articulate young men and women, who can write cogently and think critically won't budge a school's ranking up even one spot. |date= September 12, 2012 |url= http://www.thecollegesolution.com/how-u-s-news-college-rankings-hurt-you |accessdate= September 14, 2012 }}</ref> Writer Andrew Ferguson noted considerable hypocrisy surrounding rankings: some colleges pretend to loathe the guidebooks that rank them, yet if they get a good write-up, they "wave it around like a bride's garter belt."<ref name=twsMayO411/> Lynn O'Shaughnessy criticized the "mindless pursuit of better numbers" by colleges to boost their college rankings as destructive and wrote that families place too much emphasis on the rankings as a way to select colleges.<ref name=tws2Z211/> Further, she criticized the ''US News'' rankings for failing to take a college's affordability into account<ref name=tws2T35>{{cite news |author= Lynn O'Shaughnessy |title= The Real Cost of Attending an Expensive East Coast University |work= The College Solution |quote= Rankings Perversion – ... US News & World Report's college rankings doesn't ... bestow demerits for being unaffordable. ... |date= March 10, 2011 |url= http://www.thecollegesolution.com/the-real-cost-of-attending-an-expensive-east-coast-university |accessdate= August 20, 2012 }}</ref> or factor in the average student indebtedness after college<ref name=twsSepN2111/> as well as failing to measure how well colleges actually educated their students.<ref name=twsSepN2111/> She noted how the ''US News'' algorithm "favors schools that spurn more students."<ref name=twsSepN2111/> College admissions counselors criticized rankings as misleading, and criticized the rankings inputs of peer assessments, student selectivity and alumni giving as being poor predictors of a college's overall quality.<ref name=tws2T27>{{cite news |title= "Best For Whom?": College Admission Counselors Challenge Key Assumptions About College Rankings |work= States News Service (via Highbeam Research) |quote= ... The annual rankings of undergraduate colleges and universities by U.S. News and World Report generate negative opinions among professionals who work most closely with students and families ... |date= May 19, 2011 |url= http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-256790465.html |accessdate= August 20, 2012 }}</ref> The rankings title "America's Best Colleges", prompted counselors to ask "best for whom"?<ref name=tws2T27/>
In 2007, members of the [[Annapolis Group]] discussed [[Criticism of college and university rankings (2007 United States)#Presidents Letter|a letter to college presidents]] asking them not to participate in the ''[[U.S. News and World Report|US News]]'' "reputation survey".<ref>Note: this "reputation survey" makes up 25% of the ranking.</ref> A majority of the approximately 80 presidents at the meeting agreed not to participate,<ref>{{cite web | first =Scott | last =Jaschik | title =More Momentum Against 'U.S. News'| publisher = [[Inside Higher Ed]] | date = June 20, 2007 | url= http://www.insidehighered.com/news/2007/06/20/usnews}}</ref> although the statements were not binding.<ref name="collegenews.org">{{cite web|title=ANNAPOLIS GROUP STATEMENT ON RANKINGS AND RATINGS |publisher=[[Annapolis Group]] |date=June 19, 2007 |url=http://www.collegenews.org/x7131.xml |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070626055807/http://www.collegenews.org/x7131.xml |archivedate=June 26, 2007 |df= }}</ref> Members pledged to develop alternative web-based information formats<ref name="collegenews.org"/> in conjunction with several collegiate associations.<ref>Note: associations include the '' [[National Association of Independent Colleges and Universities]]'' and the ''[[Council of Independent Colleges]].''</ref> ''[[U.S. News and World Report|US News]]'' responded that their peer assessment survey helps them measure a college's "intangibles" such as the ability of a college's reputation to help a graduate win a first job or entrance into graduate school.<ref name="usnews.com">{{cite web| first =Robert| last =Morse| title =About the Annapolis Group's Statement| publisher =[[U.S. News and World Report]]| date =June 22, 2007| url =https://www.usnews.com/blogs/college-rankings-blog/2007/6/22/about-the-annapolis-groups-statement.html#read_more| deadurl =yes| archiveurl =https://web.archive.org/web/20070702061309/http://www.usnews.com/blogs/college-rankings-blog/2007/6/22/about-the-annapolis-groups-statement.html#read_more| archivedate =July 2, 2007| df =mdy-all}}</ref> An article by Nicholas Thompson in ''[[Washington Monthly]]'' criticized the U.S. News rankings as "confirming the prejudices of the meritocracy" by tuning their statistical algorithms to entrench the reputations of a handful of schools, while failing to measure how much students learn.<ref name=tws3JanK11/> Thompson described the algorithms as being "opaque enough that no one outside the magazine can figure out exactly how they work, yet clear enough to imply legitimacy."<ref name=tws3JanK11>{{cite news |author = Nicholas Thompson |title = Playing With Numbers: How U.S. News mismeasures higher education and what we can do about it |newspaper = Washington Monthly |quote = ... U.S. News rankings don't measure how much students learn; ... |date = September 2000 |url = http://www.washingtonmonthly.com/features/2000/0009.thompson.html |accessdate = January 11, 2013 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20130114232520/http://www.washingtonmonthly.com/features/2000/0009.thompson.html |archivedate = January 14, 2013 |df = mdy-all }}</ref>
:{{Further|Criticism of college and university rankings (2007 United States)}}
===Choosing schools by selectivity=== [[File:Scattergram by Naviance which estimates likelihood of admission.png|thumb|A Naviance scattergram for a hypothetical student, John Doe, applying to a particular hypothetical university. Grades and test scores can be compared with those of past applicants to that university from that high school. The method helps students see whether a school is a ''reach, possible, probable'' or ''solid'' school.]]
Advisors typically ask students to begin to see potential colleges in terms of four types: * '''Reach''' schools provide a slim chance of acceptance, such as a 5% or slimmer chance.{{sfn|Mamlet|2011|pp=133–134}} * '''Possibles''' (or high matches) have greater chance of rejection than acceptance.{{sfn|Mamlet|2011|pp=133–134}} * '''Probables''' (or low matches) have greater chance of acceptance than rejection.{{sfn|Mamlet|2011|pp=133–134}} * '''Solid''' or '''safety''' schools seldom reject candidates with similar academic credentials.{{sfn|Mamlet|2011|pp=133–134}} High school counselors recommend that a safety school be one that a student would like to attend if rejected everywhere else. Mark Kantrowitz advised having at least one financial aid safety school that is affordable even without financial aid.<ref name=tws2ZG311/> Another classification is "unlikelies" (5% chance of acceptance), "reach schools" (25% chance), "possibles" (50% chance), and "likelies" (80% chance).
Typically counselors will suggest an applicant apply to a mix of the different types of schools, usually having at least one ''safety'' school, but the numbers of the others are up to students and families. [[Phillips Academy|Andover]]'s counseling director recommends that a student apply to a minimum of two "solid" schools and two "probable" schools.<ref name=tws3afa/> Many high schools subscribe to an online service called [[Naviance]], which, among other things, can help a student gauge the likelihood of admission to a particular college.{{sfn|Mamlet|2011|p=160}} It is based on a student's grades and test scores in comparison to the admissions results from students from previous years applying to that particular college (see diagram).{{sfn|Mamlet|2011|p=160}} Naviance uses a [[scattergram]] to graphically illustrate the chances for a student from a particular high school being admitted into a particular college or university.{{sfn|Mamlet|2011|p=20}} In addition, counselors can help a student consider different types of colleges, such as [[Liberal arts colleges in the United States|liberal arts colleges]], research universities, and specialty schools.{{sfn|Mamlet|2011|pp=116–117}} A report in ''[[Time magazine]]'' in 2013 suggested that it was almost impossible for poor students to gain admission to elite universities,<ref>Time magazine, Noliwe M. Rooks, February 27, 2013, [http://ideas.time.com/2013/02/27/the-biggest-barrier-to-elite-education-isnt-affordability-its-accessibility/ The Biggest Barrier to Elite Education Isn't Affordability. It's Accessibility], Retrieved August 27, 2014, "... accessibility of these schools to students who are poor, minority ... the weight that Ivy League and other highly selective schools ... unfortunate set of circumstances ... gifted minority, poor and working class students can benefit most from the educational opportunities ..."</ref> and that the percentage of students at 28 elite colleges coming from less affluent households was relatively constant at around 10% from 2001 to 2009, based on a study that included all eight [[Ivy League]] schools.<ref>August 26, 2014, Boston Globe (via The New York Times), [http://www.boston.com/business/news/2014/08/26/generation-later-poor-are-still-rare-elite-colleges/pL5EU7PrPXvpEflvgXAuEJ/story.html A Generation Later, Poor are Still Rare at Elite Colleges], Retrieved August 30, 2014, "more elite group of 28 private colleges and universities, including all eight Ivy League members, ... from 2001 to 2009, ... enrollment of students from the bottom 40 percent of family incomes increased from just 10 percent to 11 percent ...."</ref> The difficulty of admissions to elite universities has sometimes prompted accusations:
{{Quote|The admissions system of the so-called ''best'' schools is rigged against you. If you are a middle-class youth or minority from poor circumstances, you have little chance of getting in to one of those schools. Indeed, the system exists not to provide social mobility but to prevent it and to perpetuate the prevailing social order.|Essayist Neal Gabler in the ''[[Boston Globe]]'', 2010<ref name=twsMay2R113>{{cite news |author= Neal Gabler |title= The college admissions scam |newspaper= Boston Globe |date= January 10, 2010 |url= http://www.boston.com/bostonglobe/editorial_opinion/oped/articles/2010/01/10/the_college_admissions_scam/ |accessdate= May 18, 2012 }}</ref>}}
===Return on investment=== {| class="wikitable sortable" style="float:right;" |- |+ '''Return on investment<br>Top colleges 2013<ref name=CollegeWorthIt/> |- !College !ROI rank |- |align="left"|[[Harvey Mudd College|Harvey Mudd]] |align="right"|1 |- |align="left"|[[California Institute of Technology|Caltech]] |align="right"|2 |- |align="left"|[[Massachusetts Institute of Technology|MIT]] |align="right"|3 |- |align="left"|[[Stanford University|Stanford]] |align="right"|4 |- |align="left"|[[Princeton University|Princeton]] |align="right"|5 |- |align="left"|[[Harvard University|Harvard]] |align="right"|6 |- |align="left"|[[Dartmouth College|Dartmouth]] |align="right"|7 |- |align="left"|[[Duke University|Duke]] |align="right"|8 |- |align="left"|[[University of Pennsylvania|U. Penn]] |align="right"|9 |- |align="left"|[[University of Notre Dame|Notre Dame]] |align="right"|10 |- |} Former US Education Secretary [[William Bennett]] suggested college should be seen as a long-term purchase with the [[return on investment]] (ROI) being the future earnings potential of a graduate.<ref name=CollegeWorthIt/> Schools have been compared financially by examining average costs, student debt, and lifelong earnings, to yield an effective average ROI.<ref name=CollegeWorthIt/> Bennett suggested that only 150 out of the nation's 3500 colleges provided positive returns.<ref name=CollegeWorthIt>Lauren Lyster, Yahoo Finance. [https://finance.yahoo.com/blogs/daily-ticker/only-150-3500-u-colleges-worth-investment-former-132020890.html Only 150 of 3500 U.S. Colleges Are Worth the Investment: Former Secretary of Education], Accessed May 7, 2013</ref><ref>Note: for the complete list see external links under "ROI"</ref>
===Better fit or prestige=== Prestige of colleges correlates with age, such that the oldest east-coast schools tend to have accumulated the most prestige by virtue of their longevity. There is widespread consensus that the fit between a student and a school is an important factor. Several reports suggest that "fit should trump prestige every single time," and that it is better for a school to match a student in terms of social, cultural, and academic qualities and not be chosen simply because of a school's prestige.<ref name=twsL14/><ref name=twsMay2Pfjk/> Others see college admissions as essentially a choice between "price and prestige".<ref name=twsMayO115>{{cite news |author= Tanya Caldwell |title= 6 Tips About College Admissions Results |newspaper= The New York Times |date= March 30, 2012 |url= http://thechoice.blogs.nytimes.com/2012/03/30/6-tips-about-college-admissions-results/ |accessdate= May 15, 2012 }}</ref> Elite colleges have been compared to designer labels, a valuable credential in the job market,<ref name=twsMay2R113/> and an entryway into top graduate schools.<ref name=twsMay2S213>{{cite news |author= Howard and Matthew Greene |title= PBS: 'Ten Steps to College' (transcript) |newspaper= Washington Post |date= October 22, 2003 |url= https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/articles/A21178-2003Oct13.html |accessdate= May 19, 2012 }}</ref> Some advisors specialize in helping students find a good fit—a suitable list of colleges—which helps students in the long run. They help students to explore their values and needs, and provide counseling to help both students and parents find a college or university program that helps students meet long-term goals. Questions include thinking about life goals, which activities a person likes best, and what style of learning works best for the student.<ref name=twsL13/> Evaluating personal preferences is important and can take time.<ref name=twsL12/> One advisor suggests it is important for a student to think through what is best, and choose on this basis, and "do not listen to your friends" since they have different needs and wants. "One of the worst ways to make a decision about where to go to college is to follow a friend because he or she is having a good time at that school," wrote one advisor.<ref name=twsL13/> Since "barely half" of students entering college as first-year students ever graduate from college later in their lives,<ref name=twsL28/> getting the right fit is important for parents and students to avoid wasting money.<ref name=twsL28/> What is a good fit:
{{Quote|The college that fits you best is one that will: (1) Offer a program of study to match your interests and needs (2) Provide a style of instruction to match the way you like to learn (3) Provide a level of academic rigor to match your aptitude and preparation (4) Offer a community that feels like home to you and (5) Value you for what you do well.|report in ''US News''<ref name=twsL28/>}} {| class="wikitable sortable" style="float:right;" |- |+ '''Colleges with 4 or more<br>professors chosen<br>for<br>teaching excellence<ref name=twsImag114>{{cite news |title= Lectures – Professors |work= The Teaching Company |quote= Note: in some instances, professors may have changed university affiliations since the year of publication of their respective Teaching Company courses |date= July 18, 2012 |url= http://www.thegreatcourses.com/tgc/professors/professorsbytopic.aspx |accessdate= July 18, 2012 }}</ref> |- !University<br>affiliation !# of<br>Great<br>Courses<br>teachers |- |align="left"|[[University of Texas at Austin|U. Texas-Austin]] |align="right"|7 |- |align="left"|[[University of Virginia|U. Virginia]] |align="right"|6 |- |align="left"|[[University of Pennsylvania|U. Pennsylvania]] |align="right"|6 |- |align="left"|[[University of California, Los Angeles|UCLA]] |align="right"|5 |- |align="left"|[[Emory University|Emory]] |align="right"|5 |- |align="left"|[[Georgetown University|Georgetown]] |align="right"|5 |- |align="left"|[[University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill|UNC-Chapel Hill]] |align="right"|4 |- |align="left"|[[Vanderbilt University|Vanderbilt]] |align="right"|4 |- |align="left"|[[University of Toronto|U. Toronto]] |align="right"|4 |- |align="left"|[[College of William & Mary|William & Mary]] |align="right"|4 |- |align="left"|[[Southern Methodist University|SMU]] |align="right"|4 |- |} A private admissions counselor elaborates:
{{Quote|A school has to ''fit'' – academically, socially, and economically ... Ask whether a college feels ''right'' ... rather than is it ''best'' ...|Michael Szarek, 2011<ref name=twsL21aa/>}}
One admissions dean likens "fit" to a [[friendship]]:
{{Quote|I draw the analogy of friends to explain why fit is so important in considering a college. You like your good friends for some reason. It may not be an objective reason. It's often subjective. There's some sense of compatibility, a kind of intuition, a match, a common sense of values, what you like to do, how you think – those are the things that really bind people together. It's similar with college. You don't want to spend four years with a college who isn't really your friend.|Jennifer Rickard, admissions dean at [[Bryn Mawr College|Bryn Mawr]]{{sfn|Mamlet|2011|p=166}}}}
In addition, counselors can help less academically astute students find good colleges to help them pursue careers, and can point out colleges that are "gems" but relatively unknown.<ref name=twsL19>{{cite news |author= Theo Emery |title= College Options (And Strategies) for the 'B' and Even 'C' Student |publisher= ''The New York Times'' |date= September 25, 2009 |url= http://thechoice.blogs.nytimes.com/2009/09/25/nacac-b-c/ |accessdate= December 12, 2011 }}</ref> In some cases, choosing a college in a different part of the country can improve chances for admission, particularly if the college is seeking "geographical diversity."<ref name=twsL19/> One study suggests that the overall prestige of a person's college is less important, overall, in predicting how they would fare in later life, and that personal characteristics, such as aptitude, are more important.<ref name=twsL25/>
===Costs===
====Sticker versus net price==== {| class="wikitable sortable" style="float:left;" |- |+ Priciest colleges<br>2012–2013<br><small>tuition, room, board, books</small><br><small>Source: ''Business Insider''</small><ref name=twsJuly2013>Kelley Holland, CNBC, Business Insider, July 11, 2013, [http://www.today.com/money/most-expensive-colleges-america-really-6C10604264 The most expensive colleges in America – really], Accessed July 11, 2013</ref> |- !School !Cost |- |Princeton U. |$62,919 |- | align="left" |New York U. | align="right" |$61,977 |- |align="left"|Harvey Mudd |align="right"|$61,760 |- |align="left"|Bard |align="right"|$61,446 |- |align="left"|Rensselaer |align="right"|$60,779 |- |align="left"|Sarah Lawrence |align="right"|$60,656 |- |align="left"|Wesleyan |align="right"|$60,214 |- |align="left"|Dartmouth |align="right"|$60,201 |- |align="left"|U. Chicago |align="right"|$60,039 |- |align="left"|Bard-Simon's Rk |align="right"|$60,003 |- |align="left"|Trinity |align="right"|$59,860 |- |} The general pattern is that most colleges and universities, particularly private ones, have an artificially high<ref name=tws2MayY311/> and unreliable<ref name=tws2MayY311/> [[Sticker price#United States|sticker price]] while charging most students, by awarding grant and scholarship money, a "discounted price" that varies considerably.<ref name=tws2MayY312>{{cite news |author= Mary Beth Marklein |title= 'Best value' colleges: Some have high price tags |newspaper= USA Today |date= February 7, 2012 |url= https://www.usatoday.com/news/education/story/2012-02-07/princeton-review-best-value-colleges-2012/52991578/1 |accessdate= May 25, 2012 }}</ref> Writer Lynn O'Shaughnessy in ''[[US News]]'' compared college prices with "airline tickets" since "everybody pays a different fare".<ref name=tws2MayY211>{{cite news |author= Lynn O'Shaughnessy |title= Don't Believe a College Sticker Price |newspaper= US News |date= May 31, 2011 |url= https://www.usnews.com/education/blogs/the-college-solution/2011/05/31/dont-believe-a-college-sticker-price |accessdate= May 25, 2012 }}</ref> Another report agreed:
{{Quote|Sticker price is the full price colleges list in their brochures and on their websites. Net price is the price students actually pay. Net price accounts for the fact that many students receive grants or scholarships. So it can be considerably lower than sticker price.|Jacob Goldstein, NPR, 2012<ref name=tws2MayY111>{{cite news |author= Jacob Goldstein |title= The Price Of College Tuition, In 1 Graphic |newspaper= NPR |date= May 25, 2012 |url= https://www.npr.org/blogs/money/2012/05/22/153316565/the-price-of-college-tuition-in-1-graphic |accessdate= May 25, 2012 }}</ref>}}
Discounting began in the 1970s and was dramatically expanded in the 1990s, according to one report.<ref name=tws3JanN311>{{cite news |author= Paul Fain |title= Why Deep Tuition Discounts May Not Spell Financial Doom: They can be a useful tool as long as tuition revenue is solid |newspaper= The Chronicle of Higher Education |quote= ... Discounting in higher education began in the 1970s, as college admissions officers copied the pricing systems used by airlines and other businesses. The approach of charging as much as people would pay was novel in the academy. .... |date= May 2, 2010 |url= http://chronicle.com/article/Why-Deep-Tuition-Discounts-May/65331/?viewMobile=0 |accessdate= January 14, 2013 }}</ref> Discrepancy between sticker and average net prices can vary substantially. Estimates vary, but show a consistent pattern of sticker prices being much greater than real costs, sometimes more than double, sometimes only one and a half times as high.<ref name=tws2MayY211/><ref name=tws2MayY112>{{cite news |title= The Real Price Of College |newspaper= NPR |date= May 11, 2012 |url= https://www.npr.org/blogs/money/2012/05/11/152511771/the-real-price-of-college |accessdate= May 25, 2012 }}</ref><ref name=tws2MayY213/><ref name=tws2MayY115>{{cite news |author= Jacob Goldstein |title= Average Sticker Price For Private College: $36,993 A Year |newspaper= NPR |date= October 28, 2010 |url= https://www.npr.org/blogs/money/2010/10/27/130867761/average-cost-for-a-year-of-private-college-40-476 |accessdate= May 25, 2012 }}</ref> Estimates are that 88%<ref name=tws2MayY211/><ref name=tws2MayY314/> or 67%<ref name=tws2MayY214>{{cite news |author= Rebecca R. Ruiz |title= Only One in Three Full-Time Students Pays Full Tuition |newspaper= The New York Times |date= November 15, 2011 |url= http://thechoice.blogs.nytimes.com/2011/11/15/economix/ |accessdate= May 25, 2012 }}</ref> get some form of discount. One estimate in 2015 was that at private nonprofit four-year colleges, the average first-year student pays 48% less than the sticker price.<ref name=twsNBCNews5/> Generally, the sticker-to-net price discrepancy is greater at private colleges than public universities.<ref name=tws2MayY213/> For example, in 2011–2012, the average sticker price for tuition, fees and living expenses at private colleges, was $38,590 while the average actual cost was $23,060; at public colleges, the average sticker price was $17,130 and the average actual cost was $11,380.<ref name=tws2MayY311/> Another estimate was that the average full-time undergraduate gets $6,500 in grant aid along with $1,000 in tax-based aid to offset tuition and fees.<ref name=tws2MayY214/> There is widespread consensus that the most cost-effective college option is [[Community colleges in the United States|community colleges]], which charge on average only $3,000 for full-time tuition.<ref name=tws2MayY314>{{cite news |author= Kim Clark |title= College costs climb, yet again |newspaper= CNN Money Magazine |quote= While community college tuition posted a sharp 8.7% gain, it's still a bargain: only about $3,000 a year for full-time tuition. |date= October 29, 2011 |url= http://money.cnn.com/2011/10/26/pf/college/college_tuition_cost/index.htm |accessdate= May 25, 2012 }}</ref>
{| class="wikitable sortable" style="float:right;" |- |+ '''College Access Index''' |+ <small>Commitment to economic</small> |+ <small>diversity of student body</small> |+ <small>--top 25 schools (2017)--</small> |+ <small>source: ''[[The New York Times]]''</small><ref name=twsNYT9959>New York Times, [https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2017/05/25/sunday-review/opinion-pell-table.html?emc=edit_ty_20170526&nl=opinion-today&nlid=76434108&te=1&_r=0 Top Colleges Doing the Most for the American Dream], Retrieved May 26, 2017</ref> |- !College !Index |- |align="left"|UC-Irvine |align="right"|1.90 |- |align="left"|UC-SantaBar |align="right"|1.61 |- |align="left"|UC-Davis |align="right"|1.60 |- |align="left"|UC-SanDiego |align="right"|1.58 |- |align="left"|UCLA |align="right"|1.52 |- |align="left"|U.Florida |align="right"|1.46 |- |align="left"|Amherst |align="right"|1.44 |- |align="left"|Pomona |align="right"|1.43 |- |align="left"|UC-Berkeley |align="right"|1.38 |- |align="left"|Harvard |align="right"|1.36 |- |align="left"|Vassar |align="right"|1.36 |- |align="left"|Williams |align="right"|1.35 |- |align="left"|Princeton |align="right"|1.34 |- |align="left"|Wellesley |align="right"|1.32 |- |align="left"|Stanford |align="right"|1.31 |- |align="left"|Knox |align="right"|1.30 |- |align="left"|UNC-Chapel |align="right"|1.30 |- |align="left"|Columbia |align="right"|1.26 |- |align="left"|Barnard |align="right"|1.25 |- |align="left"|Yale |align="right"|1.22 |- |align="left"|Westminster |align="right"|1.21 |- |align="left"|Wesleyan |align="right"|1.21 |- |align="left"|Davidson |align="right"|1.20 |- |align="left"|MIT |align="right"|1.20 |- |align="left"|Texas A&M |align="right"|1.19 |- |}
Colleges use high sticker prices because it allows them wide latitude in how to use funds to attract the best students, as well as entice students with special skills or increase its overall racial or ethnic diversity.<ref name=tws3JanN311/> The most sought-after students can be enticed by high discounts while marginal students can be charged full freight.<ref name=tws2MayY113>{{cite news |author1=Chana Joffe-Walt |author2=Jacob Goldstein |title= How Colleges Fight For Top Students |newspaper= NPR |date= May 2, 2012 |url= https://www.npr.org/blogs/money/2012/05/02/151759177/how-colleges-fight-for-top-students |accessdate= May 25, 2012 }}</ref><ref name=tws2MayY114>{{cite news |author= Jay Conley |title= New Online Tools Expected to Lift Veil on College Sticker Prices: With federal mandate, all schools must offer net price calculators online by October 29. |newspaper= US News |date= September 14, 2011 |url= https://www.usnews.com/education/best-colleges/paying-for-college/articles/2011/09/14/new-online-tools-expected-to-lift-veil-on-college-sticker-prices |accessdate= May 25, 2012 }}</ref> Further, the high sticker price is a marketing tool to suggest the overall worth of a college education, along the lines of encouraging people to think that "schools that cost more must provide a better education."<ref name=tws2MayY211/> A report by the Pew Research Center found that while there was growing concern about escalating college prices, most Americans believed that their personal investment in [[Higher education in the United States|higher education]] was sound.<ref name=tws2MayY212>{{cite news |author= Brian Burnsed |title= Americans Split on Value of a College Degree: A Pew study indicates many are skeptical, but college graduates remain confident in their choices. |newspaper= US News |date= May 16, 2011 |url= https://www.usnews.com/education/best-colleges/articles/2011/05/16/americans-split-on-value-of-a-college-degree |accessdate= May 25, 2012 }}</ref> But discounting adds complexity to decision-making, deterring some students from applying in some instances based on a false sense of unaffordability.<ref name=tws2MayY213>{{cite news |author= Judith Scott-Clayton |title= College Is Cheaper Than You Think |newspaper= The New York Times |date= November 4, 2011 |url= https://economix.blogs.nytimes.com/2011/11/04/college-is-cheaper-than-you-think/ |accessdate= May 25, 2012 }}</ref> In recent years, there has been attention to the problem of bright students from low-income backgrounds not applying to top colleges, and attending less challenging colleges instead or skipping college entirely; this phenomenon has been called [[undermatching]] in the sense that these students are not properly paired or "matched" with academically challenging colleges; there have been efforts at some colleges such as [[Williams College|Williams]] to actively seek out bright low-income students.<ref name=twsNBCNews1>Nona Willis Aronowitz, October 3, 2014, NBC News, [http://www.nbcnews.com/news/education/middle-class-squeeze-elite-education-worth-170-000-debt-n212811 Middle-Class Squeeze: Is an Elite Education Worth $170,000 in Debt?], Retrieved October 3, 2014, "... recruiting high-achieving, low-income kids to apply ... 18 percent of Williams students now pay no tuition ... To offset the cost, these schools often aggressively recruit students whose families can pay the full cost ..."</ref> According to ''[[NBC News|NBC]]'' reporter [[Nona Willis-Aronowitz]], the financial makeup of the student body at elite colleges tends to be mostly affluent students, with some low-income students if the college actively seeks out bright low-income applicants, but few students from middle-class backgrounds.<ref name=twsNBCNews1/> As a result, middle-class applicants are increasingly faced with a tough choice: to either attend an elite school, paying close to the sticker price, and graduate with substantial debt, or to attend a publicly supported state school with less debt; Aronowitz described this as the "middle class squeeze".<ref name=twsNBCNews1/> In 2015, however, there were several instances of private colleges reducing their tuition by more than 40%.<ref name=twsNBCNews5>NBC News, [http://www.nbcnews.com/feature/freshman-year/these-two-colleges-plan-tuition-reset-40-percent-cut-n442876 These Two Colleges Plan 'Tuition Reset' With 40 Percent Cut], Retrieved October 12, 2015, "... two small private liberal arts colleges are actually cutting tuition next year — by more than 40 percent. Utica College in New York and Rosemont College in Pennsylvania ..."</ref>
{{Further|College tuition in the United States}}
====Net price calculators==== In the fall of 2011, colleges were required by federal law to post a [[College cost calculator|net price calculator]] on their websites to give prospective students and families a rough estimate of likely college costs for their particular institution,<ref name=tws2MayY311>{{cite news |author= Daniel de Vise |title= College Web sites to post cost calculators for prospective students |newspaper= Washington Post |date= October 28, 2011 |url= https://www.washingtonpost.com/local/education/college-web-sites-to-post-cost-calculators-for-prospective-students/2011/10/27/gIQABj0SQM_story.html |accessdate= May 25, 2012 }}</ref><ref name=twsMay2Q848>{{cite news |author= Jacques Steinberg |title= The Choice on 'Today': Tips on Fafsa, and Net-Price Calculators |newspaper= ''The New York Times'' and ''The Today Show'' |date= January 20, 2012 |url= http://thechoice.blogs.nytimes.com/2012/01/20/choice-on-today-fin-aid/ |accessdate= May 17, 2012 }}</ref> and to "demystify pricing."<ref name=twsL24/><ref name=tws2MayY311/> A student or family could go online, find the calculator at a college's website, and enter the required financial and academic information, and the calculator should tell them an estimate of the likely cost of attending that college. The first online calculators were started by [[Williams College]].<ref name=tws2MayY114/> The online calculators look at financial need and academic merit to try to estimate the likely discounted price offered to a particular student from a particular college,<ref name=tws2MayY311/> using information including details from tax returns, household income, grade point averages and test scores.<ref name=tws2MayY114/> Schools vary in terms of their pricing formulas; some consider [[home equity]] as a factor while others disregard it.<ref name=tws2Q213/> Lynn O'Shaughnessy recommends that families shopping for colleges go to a college's website and use the net price calculator to get a personalized estimate of cost.<ref name=tws2Q213>{{cite news |author= Lynn O'Shaughnessy |title= Will Your Home Equity Hurt Financial Aid Chances? A Case Study |work= The College Solution |date= June 25, 2012 |url= http://www.thecollegesolution.com/will-your-home-equity-hurt-financial-aid-chances-a-case-study |accessdate= June 26, 2012 }}</ref> {| class="wikitable sortable" style="float:left;" |- |+ Sticker versus net price<br><small>Family income $48K-$75K</small><br><small>Total annual cost</small><br><small>Selected colleges 2012</small><br><small>Source: CNN/Money</small><ref name=tws2MayY314/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://cgi.money.cnn.com/tools/collegecost/collegecost.html|title=CNN Money college cost calculator|publisher=|accessdate=September 29, 2014}}</ref><br><small>Click triangles to sort</small> |- !School !Sticker<br>price !Net<br>price<br>(avg) |- |align="left"|Lafayette |align="right"|53020 |align="right"|19800 |- |align="left"|Cornell |align="right"|55501 |align="right"|27400 |- |align="left"|New York University |align="right"|57858 |align="right"|40300 |- |align="left"|SUNY-Binghamton |align="right"|20026 |align="right"|19400 |- |align="left"|U. Chicago |align="right"|56716 |align="right"|28500 |- |align="left"|Reed |align="right"|54800 |align="right"|29400 |- |align="left"|Berkeley |align="right"|29027 |align="right"|24300 |- |align="left"|Swarthmore |align="right"|54400 |align="right"|20000 |- |align="left"|Georgetown |align="right"|55110 |align="right"|26400 |- |align="left"|Harvard |align="right"|52652 |align="right"|10600 |- |} There are numerous potential problems with the calculators. Some are difficult to find on a college's website;<ref name=tws2MayY311/><ref name=tws2MayY114/> others require specific financial numbers, possibly leading to errors by parents or students; some are difficult to understand and use;<ref name=tws2MayY114/> some may be manipulated by schools to increase applications or to make it seem as if a college is "more affordable" than it is.<ref name=tws2MayY114/> Accuracy of calculator estimates may vary considerably from college to college.<ref name=tws2MayY311/><ref name=tws2MayY114/> Ultimately aid decisions will not be made by calculators, but by humans in the admissions offices.<ref name=tws2MayY311/>
====Types of financial aid==== * '''Need-based aid''' is offered according to the financial need of a student. Generally colleges at the "top of the pecking order" dispense aid solely in terms of need using "fairly predictable formulas", according to one source.<ref name=tws2MayY311/> ''The Chronicle of Higher Education'' reported that elite colleges had made little progress in helping poor students get need-based aid, and that less than 15% of undergraduates at the nation's 50 wealthiest colleges received [[Pell Grant]]s in 2008–2009, which are offered on the basis of need to promising yet less affluent students.<ref name=twsSepN2112>{{cite news |author1=Beckie Supiano |author2=Andrea Fuller |title= Elite Colleges Fail to Gain More Students on Pell Grants |newspaper= The Chronicle of Higher Education |quote= ... Just under 15 percent of the undergraduates at the country's 50 wealthiest colleges received Pell Grants in 2008-9, ... |date= March 27, 2011 |url= http://chronicle.com/article/Pell-Grant-Recipients-Are/126892/ |accessdate= September 14, 2012 }}</ref> According to one source, about 30 elite universities have "coffers deep enough to meet all student need" and consequently only offer need-based aid.<ref name=tws3JanN311/>
* '''Merit-based aid''' is scholarships and grants awarded to top academic performers or others with special talents. One report suggested that academic scholarships tended to be few, and were usually awarded by the admissions office and are "highly competitive".<ref name=tws2ZG311/> Another report suggested that most colleges use merit scholarships, based on high scores or grades or other accomplishments, to lure students away from a competing college.<ref name=tws2ZG314/>
One view is that most colleges award aid using a mix of both.<ref name=tws2MayY311/> Further, [[student loan]]s can lessen the immediate difficulty of large tuition bills but can saddle a student with debt after graduation; in contrast, grants and scholarships do not have to be paid back.<ref name=tws2ZB42/>
According to Lynn O'Shaughnessy, schools trying to climb the prestige ladder use merit-based scholarships to attract top students to boost their rankings in the ''US News'' guidebook.<ref name=tws2Z211>{{cite news |author= Lynn O'Shaughnessy |title= The Realities of Merit Scholarships |work= The College Solution |date= May 3, 2012 |url= http://www.thecollegesolution.com/the-realities-of-merit-scholarships |accessdate= June 26, 2012 }}</ref> She elaborated that as a school's "stock" rises, high-performing students start attending in greater numbers, and consequently the college can "ratchet back on the merit aid to wealthy students" and shift funds towards "need-based financial aid".<ref name=tws2Z211/> Elite schools such as the Ivies don't give merit scholarships, according to two reports.<ref name=tws2Z211/><ref name=tws2ZG314/> Another tool is to use the College Board's expected family contribution calculator that can give families an idea of how much college will cost, but not for any particular college.<ref name=tws2Q214>{{cite news |author= Lynn O'Shaughnessy |title= Do You Really Expect Me to Pay That Much for College? |work= The College Solution |date= May 22, 2012 |url= http://www.thecollegesolution.com/do-you-really-expect-me-to-pay-that-much-for-college |accessdate= June 26, 2012 }}</ref> According to ''US News'', 62 out of 1,137 colleges, which responded to a survey, claimed to meet 100% of the demonstrated financial need of students.<ref name=twsUSNews62>Susannah Snider September 15, 2014, US News, [https://www.usnews.com/education/best-colleges/paying-for-college/articles/2014/09/15/colleges-and-universities-that-claim-to-meet-full-financial-need Colleges and Universities That Claim to Meet Full Financial Need], Retrieved October 1, 2014</ref> "Demonstrated financial need" is the gap between the "expected family contribution" (based on tax information, family size and assets) and the cost of attendance (tuition and fees, dormitory, food expenses, and so forth.)<ref name=twsUSNews62/> {| class="wikitable sortable" style="float:right;" |- |+ '''Elite colleges with highest % of lower income students''' |+<small>Source: The New York Times 2017</small><ref name=twsNYT2017>The New York Times, January 18, 2017, [https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2017/01/18/upshot/some-colleges-have-more-students-from-the-top-1-percent-than-the-bottom-60.html?em_pos=medium&emc=edit_up_20170915&nl=upshot&nl_art=7&nlid=76434108&ref=headline&te=1 Some Colleges Have More Students From the Top 1 Percent Than the Bottom 60. Find Yours.], Retrieved September 15, 2017</ref> |- !College !Students |- |align="left"|[[University of California, Los Angeles|UCLA]] |align="right"|19% |- |align="left"|[[Emory University|Emory]] |align="right"|16% |- |align="left"|[[Barnard College|Barnard]] |align="right"|15% |- |align="left"|[[New York University|NYU]] |align="right"|14% |- |align="left"|[[Vassar College|Vassar]] |align="right"|14% |- |align="left"|[[Bryn Mawr College|Bryn Mawr]] |align="right"|14% |- |align="left"|[[Massachusetts Institute of Technology|MIT]] |align="right"|14% |- |align="left"|[[University of Miami|U. Miami]] |align="right"|14% |- |align="left"|[[Brandeis University|Brandeis]] |align="right"|13% |- |align="left"|[[Wellesley College|Wellesley]] |align="right"|13% |- |}
{{Further|Student financial aid in the United States}}
====Applying for financial aid==== [[File:FAFSA screenshot using camera.jpg|thumb|left|The [[FAFSA]] website is <nowiki>www.fafsa.ed.gov</nowiki> and is free. Other websites ''look like'' the official FAFSA website, but are deliberately misleading.]]
There are many reports that many applicants fail to apply for financial aid when they are qualified for it; one estimate was that 1.8 million students in 2006 who would have qualified for aid did not apply for it.<ref name=twsMay2R214>{{cite news |author= Valerie Strauss |title= A new college admissions bible |newspaper= Washington Post |date= October 3, 2011 |url= https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/answer-sheet/post/a-new-college-admissions-bible/2011/10/02/gIQAZVhqHL_blog.html |accessdate= May 18, 2012 }}</ref> Applying for financial aid is recommended by almost all college admissions advisers, even for middle- and upper-class families applying to private colleges.<ref name=twsL24/> Each college has its own criteria for determining financial need and loans.<ref name=twsMay2Pfjk/> One advisor counseled against letting the sticker price of a college dissuade a student from applying, since many of the top colleges have strong endowments allowing them to subsidize expenses, such that the colleges are less expensive than so-called "second tier" or state colleges.<ref name=twsL24/>
College advisers suggest that parents keep financial records, including tax forms, business records, to use when applying for financial aid,{{sfn|Mamlet|2011|p=22}} and complete the [[FAFSA]] online, using income and tax estimates (usually based on previous years), early in January of their college-bound student's twelfth grade.<ref name=twsMay2Q848/> Admissions officers can see the names of up to nine other colleges a student has applied to. According to several reports, some colleges may deny admission or reduce aid based on their interpretation of the order of colleges on the FAFSA;<ref name=Rivard>Ry Rivard, October 28, 2013, ''Inside Higher Ed'', [http://www.insidehighered.com/news/2013/10/28/colleges-use-fafsa-information-reject-students-and-potentially-lower-financial-aid Using FAFSA Against Students], Accessed December 12, 2013, "... Now, some colleges use this FAFSA position when considering students' applications for admission, which may affect decisions about admission or placement on the wait list, said David Hawkins ..."</ref><ref name=CBSNews1>CBS News, Lynn O'Shaughnessy, October 30, 2013, [http://www.cbsnews.com/news/be-careful-what-you-share-on-the-fafsa/ Be careful what you share on the FAFSA], Accessed December 12, 2013, "... The order, however, could also be hurting students who list their favorite school as No. 1. If a teenager shows too much interest in a school, the admission office may decide to offer the applicant a lower award because it is assumed that the child will enroll anyway ..."</ref><ref name=DailyFinance>Liz Weston, Reuters, November 11, 2013, Daily Finance, [http://www.dailyfinance.com/2013/11/11/colleges-may-penalize-students-over-preference-on-financial-aid/#!slide=976781 Colleges May Penalize Students Over Preference on Financial Aid Applications], Accessed December 12, 2013, "... Students can list up to 10 schools to receive their financial aid information, and the ones they list first strongly predict which enrollment offers they're likely to accept, college consultants say ..."</ref> accordingly, several sources recommend that colleges be listed alphabetically on the FAFSA to obscure any preferences.<ref>Lynn O'Shaughnessy, October 30, 2013, The College Solution, [http://www.thecollegesolution.com/a-dirty-little-fafsa-secret/ A Dirty Little FAFSA Secret], Accessed December 10, 2013</ref><ref>Rachel Fishman, October 28, 2013, Access to Higher Education, Higher Ed Watch, [http://higheredwatch.newamerica.net/blogposts/2013/the_dark_side_of_enrollment_management-95569 The Dark Side of Enrollment Management] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131217224151/http://higheredwatch.newamerica.net/blogposts/2013/the_dark_side_of_enrollment_management-95569 |date=December 17, 2013 }}, Accessed December 13, 2013, "... The FAFSA should either not allow institutions to see where students have applied or it should list the institutions in alphabetical order ..."</ref> The earliest that the FAFSA form can be filled out is January first of twelfth grade; in contrast, the [[CSS Profile]] can be filled out earlier during the preceding fall.<ref name=tws2ZG115>{{cite news |author= Lynn O'Shaughnessy |title= Take First Step to Apply for College Financial Aid |work= US News |date= November 29, 2011 |url= https://www.usnews.com/education/blogs/the-college-solution/2011/11/29/take-first-step-to-apply-for-college-financial-aid |accessdate= July 7, 2012 }}</ref> There are reports that many parents make mistakes when filling out the FAFSA information, and mistakes include failing to hit the "submit" button, visiting an incorrect FAFSA website, such as the deceptively-named fafsa.com,<ref>Note: there are impostor websites similar to the official government website, sometimes asking for fees; the official FAFSA website is free; see [[FAFSA]] for further information</ref> leaving some fields blank instead of properly entering a zero, spelling names or entering social security numbers or estimating tax data incorrectly.<ref name=twsMay2Q848/> Since FAFSA formulas assume 20% of a student's assets can be used for college expenses as opposed to 6% of a parent's assets, advisors recommend moving funds from student to parent accounts before filing the FAFSA, including moving funds to a parent-controlled [[529 plan]] tax-advantaged account.<ref name=tws3L111/> Filing taxes early is recommended, but using estimates for FAFSA from previous years is possible provided the numbers are updated later after taxes are filed.<ref name=tws3L111/> There are no fees for applying on the FAFSA site. According to one source, the best time to begin searching for scholarships is before the twelfth grade, to guarantee meeting deadlines.<ref name=twsMay2Q848/> Several reports confirm that it is important to file aid forms such as the [[CSS Profile]] early in the school year.<ref name=tws2ZG115/><ref name=tws3L111>{{cite news |author= Victor Luckerson |title= 10 Tips for Getting the Most Out of College Financial Aid |work= Time Magazine |date= January 25, 2013 |url= http://business.time.com/2013/01/25/10-tips-for-getting-the-most-out-of-college-financial-aid/ |accessdate= February 12, 2013 }}</ref>
In addition to cost factors, increasingly colleges are being compared on the basis of the average [[student debt]] of their graduates, and ''[[US News#America's Best Colleges|US News]]'' has developed rankings based on average student indebtedness.<ref name=twsMay2Pfjk>{{cite news |author= Carolyn Butler, Arlene Weintraub, Justin Snider, Margaret Loftus, Rett Fisher, Kimberly S. Wetzel (others) |title= Best Colleges: Choose the Right School For You |newspaper= US News & World Report |quote= 2012 edition; various authors and rankings; pages 19, 20, 30, 62, 63, 68–70, 78, 84, 86, 88, others |year= 2012 }}</ref> A report in the ''[[Utne Reader]]'' chronicled substantial student indebtedness, and suggested that 37 million Americans in 2009 held student debt, and that nine in ten students used an average of 4.6 credit cards to pay for some educational expenses.<ref name="Utne">Student Debt, by the numbers, Utne Reader, July–August 2012, page 39</ref> The report chronicled an increase in average indebtedness from an average of $2,000 in 1980–81 to over $25,000 in 2009, as well as substantial decreases in Federal aid and Pell grants during that time period.<ref name="Utne"/>
''[[US News]]'' and others suggest another factor overlooked in terms of financing college, which is the length of time it takes to earn a degree. Finishing a year early (in three years) lops off a substantial portion of the overall bill,<ref name=twsMay2Pfjk/> while taking five years compounds the expense and delays entry into the workforce. Jacques Steinberg suggested that many college-bound students calculate how much [[student debt|debt]] they were likely to incur each year, and he suggested that debt for all four years of college should total less than the graduate's expected first year's salary after college, and preferably under $40,000.<ref name=twsMay2Q845>{{cite news |author= Jacques Steinberg |title= Transferring to a State University, and Saving Tens of Thousands of Dollars in the Bargain |newspaper= ''The New York Times: Education'' |date= April 11, 2012 |url= http://thechoice.blogs.nytimes.com/2012/04/11/transferring-to-save/ |accessdate= May 17, 2012 }}</ref> A handful of schools have "free tuition" policies for low income students, so that they graduate loan-free.<ref name=twsMay2Q847>{{cite news |title= No Loans for Low Income Students |newspaper= Smart Student Guide |date= May 17, 2012 |url= http://www.finaid.org/questions/noloansforlowincome.phtml |accessdate= May 17, 2012 }}</ref>
===Selecting colleges by type=== [[File:Rochester Institute of Technology 50.jpg|thumb|alt=Picture of buildings, exterior shot|Different types of schools offer different educations: including engineering-oriented colleges such as the [[Rochester Institute of Technology]], which emphasizes teaching, internships, and technical education.]] [[File:Union County College Student Center.jpg|thumb|alt=Picture of an interior glass-enclosed space.|Two-year county or community colleges, such as [[Union County College]] in New Jersey, are geared for students who live at home and commute to school, and can be a highly affordable alternative to many private colleges as well as public universities.]] [[File:Juilliard School - Alice Tully Hall.jpg|thumb|alt=Picture of a building in a city.|Some colleges focus on one particular area, such as the [[Juilliard School]] in New York City, which is highly selective, and specializes in preparing students for careers in dance, music, theater, and the arts.]]
Most educational institutions in the U.S. are [[non-profit]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://nces.ed.gov/das/library/tables_listings/showTable2005.asp?popup=true&tableID=7062&rt=p |title= Table 1. Number and percentage distribution of Title IV institutions, by control of institution, level of institution, and region: United States and other jurisdictions, academic year 2009–10 |publisher=National Center for Educational Statistics, U.S. Department of Education |year=2011 |accessdate=January 24, 2012}}</ref> Colleges and universities in the U.S. vary in terms of goals: some may emphasize a [[vocational]], [[business]], [[engineering]] or technical curriculum while others may emphasize a [[liberal arts]] curriculum. Many combine some or all of the above. Another consideration is the male-female ratio; overall, 56% of enrolled college students are women, but the male-female ratio varies by college and year and program.<ref name=twsMayO211/> Admissions guidance counselors can offer views about whether a public or private school is best, and give a sense of the tradeoffs.
'''Two-year colleges''' are often county- or community-oriented schools funded by state or local governments, and typically offer the [[Associates degree]] (A.A.). They are generally inexpensive,<ref name=twsMay2Pfjk/> particularly for in-state residents, and are focused on teaching, and accept most applicants meeting minimum grade and SAT score levels. Students commute to school and rarely live in dorms on campus. These schools often have [[Articulation (education)|articulation]] arrangements with four-year state public schools to permit students to transfer. Consultants suggest that community colleges are reasonably priced, and after two years with solid grades and academic performance, many colleges are willing to accept [[Transfer admissions in the United States|transfers]].
'''Four-year colleges''' offer [[Bachelor of Arts]] (B.A.) or [[Bachelor of Science]] (B.S.) degrees. These are primarily [[undergraduate]] institutions, although some might have limited programs at the [[Graduate school|graduate]] level. Graduates of the tuition-free [[United States service academies]] receive both a Bachelor of Science degree and a [[Officer (armed forces)|commission]].
'''Universities''' have both [[undergraduate]] and [[Graduate school|graduate]] students. [[Graduate school|Graduate programs]] grant a variety of [[Master's degree]]s including [[M.B.A.]]s or [[Master of Fine Arts|M.F.A.s]]. The highest academic degree is the [[Doctor of Philosophy]] or Ph.D. [[Medical school in the United States|Medical schools]] award either the [[Doctor of Medicine|M.D.]] or [[Doctor of Osteopathic Medicine|D.O.]] degrees while [[Law school in the United States|law schools]] award the [[Juris Doctor|J.D.]] degree. [[Public university|Public]] and [[private university|private universities]] are generally [[research]]-oriented institutions that teach both an [[undergraduate]] and [[Graduate school|graduate]] students.
'''Liberal arts colleges''' are four-year institutions that emphasize interactive instruction, although research is still a component of these institutions. They are usually [[Residential college|residential]] colleges with most students living on campus in dorms. They tend to have smaller enrollments, class sizes, and lower [[student-teacher ratio]]s than universities, and encourage teacher-student interaction with classes taught by full-time faculty members rather than graduate students known as [[teaching assistant]]s. There are further distinctions within the category of [[Liberal arts colleges in the United States|liberal arts colleges]]: some are [[coeducational]], [[Women's colleges in the United States|women's colleges]], or [[Men's colleges in the United States|men's colleges]]. There are [[historically black colleges and universities|historically black colleges]]; in addition, while most schools are [[Secularity (non-religiosity)|secular]], some stress a particular religious orientation. Most are [[private school|private]] colleges but there are some [[Council of Public Liberal Arts Colleges|public]] ones.
'''State colleges and universities'''. Since they are usually subsidized with state funds, tuitions tend to be lower than private schools. They tend to be large, sometimes with student bodies numbering in the tens of thousands, and offer a variety of programs. They are generally less selective in terms of admissions than elite competitive private schools, and are usually less expensive, sometimes half or a third as much as a private institution for in-state residents; the affordability may be leading more students in recent years to choose public or state-subsidized or community colleges.<ref name=twsL33/> There are reports that in budget shortfalls in the past few years, many state schools are selectively trying to attract higher-paying out-of-state residents.<ref name=twsMay2R212>{{cite news |author= Andrew J. Rotherham |title= The Latest Wrinkle in College Admissions: State schools are increasingly recruiting out-of-state students who pay higher fees. But is this fair? |newspaper= Time Magazine |date= December 1, 2011 |url= http://ideas.time.com/2011/12/01/the-latest-wrinkle-in-college-admissions/ |accessdate= May 18, 2012 }}</ref> In the past few years, competition for spots in public institutions has become more intense, with some state schools such as the [[State University of New York]] reporting record numbers of students saying "yes" to their offers of admission, unlike years previously.<ref name=twsL33>{{cite news |author= Lisa W. Foderaro |title= Well-Regarded Public Colleges Get a Surge of Bargain Hunters |publisher= ''The New York Times'' |date= March 1, 2009 |url= https://www.nytimes.com/2009/03/02/nyregion/02suny.html?ref=admissions |accessdate= December 12, 2011 }}</ref> There are reports that tuitions at state universities are rising faster than private universities.<ref name=twsMay2S213/> [[Flagship university#Education|Flagship state universities]] are usually the most prominent public schools in a state, and are often the oldest, have the most funding, and are often the least expensive public college.<ref name=tws2V2449/>
[[File:Flickr - The U.S. Army - United States Military Academy at West Point.jpg|thumb|alt=Outdoors men in gray uniforms throwing hats in the air.|Specialty colleges such as the [[United States service academies]] have particular admissions requirements; applicants must be nominated by their [[United States House of Representatives|congressperson]].]] [[File:View inside Wilson Commons at the University of Rochester.jpg|thumb|Physically being on a college campus, talking with students, reading in the library, and dining at an on-campus cafeteria can help a prospective student determine if the school feels right. Photo: inside Wilson Commons at the [[University of Rochester]].]]
[[File:NY College of Health Professions Massage Therapy Class.jpg|thumb|Students learning [[massage therapy]] at the [[New York College of Health Professions]] in New York State.]] '''Engineering or technical schools''' specialize in technical and scientific subjects. Some programs can be more competitive and applicants are often evaluated on the basis of grades in subjects such as mathematics (particularly calculus), physics, chemistry, mathematics, and science courses.<ref name=twsMay2S213/>
===Visiting colleges===
The consensus view among guidance advisors is that it is a good idea to visit colleges,<ref name=tws2E1114>{{cite news |author= Brennan Barnard |title= How to Make the Most of a College Visit |work= The New York Times |quote= ... there is still no match for the gut feeling one gets when stepping on a college campus ... |date= June 11, 2012 |url= http://thechoice.blogs.nytimes.com/2012/06/11/college-visit/ |accessdate= June 5, 2012 }}</ref> preferably when college is in session and not during a summer break,<ref name=twsMay2S312>{{cite news |author1=Allen Millett |author2=Leslie Goldberg |title= E-Campus Discussion Lounge |newspaper= Washington Post |year= 1999 |url= https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-adv/liveonline/viewpoint/collink/collink120199.htm |accessdate= May 19, 2012 }}</ref> with a chance to meet an actual student in the form of a tour guide,<ref name=tws3JanN211/> and taking notes for reference later when applying.<ref name=tws2E1114/><ref name=twsMay2R114/> Sometimes a college will waive the application fee based on the college visit.<ref>Source: presentation by Michael Szarek, April 2012.</ref> A benefit is seeing a school as it really is—not just glossy pictures from a brochure or a promotional video from a website.<ref name=twsL13>{{cite news |author= Valerie Strauss (interviewer) Angel B. Perez (interviewee) |title= College admissions strategies: Don't listen to friends, and more |publisher= ''The Washington Post'' |date= March 7, 2010 |url= http://voices.washingtonpost.com/answer-sheet/college-admissions/college-admissions-strategies.html |accessdate= December 12, 2011 }}</ref> Another suggested that students should ask themselves, when visiting a particular college: "can I see myself here"?{{sfn|Mamlet|2011|p=142}} Reporter Jenna Johnson in ''[[The Washington Post]]'' suggested that students contact a professor in an area of interest at the college before visiting, and try to meet with them briefly or sit in on one of their classes.<ref name=twsMay2R114>{{cite news |author= Jenna Johnson |title= Tips for maximizing your college admissions visits |newspaper= Washington Post |date= March 26, 2012 |url= https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/campus-overload/post/tips-for-maximizing-your-college-admissions-visits/2012/03/26/gIQAqFVTcS_blog.html |accessdate= May 18, 2012 }}</ref> Reporter Brennan Barnard in ''[[The New York Times]]'' recommended that student visitors should ask ''good'' questions (by avoiding factual questions better answered by the college's website), and ask for complimentary passes for dining or free food. Barnard recommends going beyond the usual tour to ask random strangers about life on campus and reading the student newspaper.<ref name=tws2E1114/> He recommends arranging to speak with a professor in the department of interest as well as athletic coaches and music directors, possibly by emailing them in advance of the visit, to try to meet them even briefly.<ref name=tws2E1114/> A follow-up "thank you" note to the host is a good idea (avoid texting abbreviations.)<ref name=tws2E1114/>
Counselor Michael Szarek commented on the importance of campus visits in dispelling false impressions:
{{Quote|Half of all college classes are ''not'' outdoors. Half of all college classes are not gathered around an electron microscope. Sometimes the leaves are brown, or even fall to the ground. So, use the viewbook to get a sense of the institution and what the college thinks are its strengths. But always rely on the campus visit.|Michael Szarek, 2011<ref name=twsL21aa>{{cite news |author= Michael Szarek |title= 17 Things to Remember |publisher= ''College Counseling for the Rest of Us'' |year= 2011 |url= http://cc4therestofus.com/17-things-to-remember-in-surviving-the-college-decision-process/ |accessdate= December 17, 2011 }}</ref>}}
However, one account suggested colleges structured the campus visit with the same boring format, which rarely includes a faculty member:
{{Quote|First there is an "informational session," conducted by an admissions officer. This is followed by an hour-long campus tour, which is led by a student with a talent for walking backwards .... On the campus tour, we are always shown a dorm room and a dining hall. We are always taken to a library and told how many volumes it contains. We are informed how many students study abroad (a lot), how many student clubs there are (ditto), and how small the classes are (very small.)|Carl Elliott in ''The Chronicle of Higher Education'', 2012<ref name=tws3JanN211>{{cite news |author= Carl Elliott |title= Lawn Boy: the College Years |newspaper= The Chronicle of Higher Education |quote= Never have I seen such careful attention to landscaping. ... |date= June 27, 2012 |url= http://chronicle.com/blogs/brainstorm/lawn-boy-the-college-years/48619 |accessdate= January 14, 2013 }}</ref>}}
==Applications considerations==
===Extracurricular activities=== There are conflicting views about student participation in [[extracurricular activities]]. A predominant position is that colleges are after "well-rounded bodies of individual specialists", suggesting that it is better for a student to be deeply involved in one or two activities rather than nine or ten superficially, such as a "violin-playing quarterback" or a "math-medalist poet,"<ref name=twsL24/><ref name=twsL14/><ref name=twsMay2R211>{{cite news |author= Jay Mathews |title= 5 wrong ideas about college admission |newspaper= Washington Post |date= January 20, 2012 |url= https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/class-struggle/post/5-wrong-ideas-about-college-admission/2012/01/19/gIQAayDXBQ_blog.html |accessdate= May 18, 2012 }}</ref> that students should not "overdo it,"<ref name=twsL44/> and that parents should not become overconcerned about their child's extracurricular activities.<ref name=twsMay2R214/> Applicants who achieve a leadership position in an extracurricular activity are regarded more highly than applicants who merely participate in a bunch of activities.<ref name=twsL24/> Advisors recommend that a student should choose which extracurricular activities they genuinely care about, pursue them with "gusto" and "joyful commitment" that demonstrates integrity and commitment.{{sfn|Mamlet|2011|p=67-70}} And, consistent with this view, is that too many extracurricular activities may look suspect to admissions officers, particularly if it seems unreasonable that any person could be as active and succeed scholastically at the same time.<ref name=twsL44/> Jobs are generally viewed favorably by admissions committees, including even part-time service jobs such as flipping hamburgers, since it suggests that a student has learned to handle [[time management]], to accept responsibility, and develop [[people skills]].{{sfn|Mamlet|2011|p=74}} A less dominant position was that it is helpful to be involved in a "variety of activities", including jobs, internships, and community service.<ref name=twsL27>{{cite news |author1=Stacey Kostell |author2=Michele Hernandez |author3=Steve Loflin |author4=Katherine Cohen |title= How Can High School Seniors Improve Odds of College Admissions? |publisher= ''US News'' |date= October 12, 2011 |url= https://www.usnews.com/education/blogs/college-admissions-experts/2011/10/12/how-can-high-school-seniors-improve-odds-of-college-admissions |accessdate= December 12, 2011 }}</ref> Some universities, such as the [[University of California]], have formal programs for spot-checking applications for accuracy, such as sending a follow-up letter to the student asking for proof about an extracurricular activity or summer job.{{sfn|Mamlet|2011|p=76}} Advisors recommend that extracurricular activities should never interfere with a student's overall academic performance.{{sfn|Mamlet|2011|p=73}} A student with many extracurricular activities in twelfth grade, but few in preceding years, particularly when the essays focus on the extracurricular activities, is suspect; this suggests an applicant is being coached, and may reflect negatively on an application (see the section on [[#Consultants|consultants]]).{{sfn|Mamlet|2011|p=43}} Advisors warn against "overscheduling" students with too many activities or courses.{{sfn|Mamlet|2011|p=23}}
