===Number of applications=== There are differing views on how many schools a student should apply to. Several reports suggest that applying to too many schools caused unnecessary stress and expense<ref name=twsMay2Pfjk/> and hampers a student from targeting applications to a few select schools.<ref name=twsL14/> However, other advisors suggest that applying to more schools increases overall chances for acceptance. Mamlet and VanDeVelde suggest applying to eight to ten schools is best, and that applying to too many schools is counterproductive.<ref name=twsMay2R214/> There are reports that the average number of schools that students are applying to has been increasing, perhaps because of greater use of the [[Common Application]]. In 2008, applications to [[Harvard University]] had increased to a record number at 27,278, a 19% increase from the year before.<ref name=twsL34>{{cite news |author= Karen W. Arenson |title= Applications to Colleges Are Breaking Records |publisher= ''The New York Times'' |date= January 17, 2008 |url= https://www.nytimes.com/2008/01/17/education/17admissions.html?ref=admissions |accessdate= December 12, 2011 }}</ref> One effect of the increase in application numbers is lower [[Yield (college admissions)|yield]] percentages. Average yield has dropped from 46% to 38% in 2001, according to one account.<ref name=twsZe25/>
===Online identity=== Some reports revealed that some college admissions departments have scrutinized applicants' personalities online, such as [[Facebook]] or [[MySpace]] profiles. As a result, admissions officers urge students to remove "sarcastic jokes, bad pictures, or political cartoons," and also to become wary about their friends' social media posts.<ref name=twsL23/> One concurring report suggested that some offices have employees tasked with "checking out applicants' Facebook pages";<ref name=twsL24/> however, a contrasting report from another college recruiter states that their policy is not to examine Facebook profiles, and that "Facebook is reserved for students on a recreational basis."<ref name=twsL44/> The same caution applies to email addresses. One advisor cautions against using provocative email addresses such as "Spicychick@gmail.com," instead encouraging applicants to use their real name since it can ease colleges' searches for applicants' records.<ref name=twsL44/>
===Choosing how to apply=== {| class="wikitable sortable" style="float:left;" |- |+ Acceptances at selective schools:<br>early vs regular admission (2009){{sfn|Hernandez|2009|pp=35}} |- !School !Overall !Early !Regular |- |align="left"|Brown |align="right"|14% |align="right"|23% |align="right"|13% |- |align="left"|Columbia |align="right"|11% |align="right"|24% |align="right"|9% |- |align="left"|Cornell |align="right"|21% |align="right"|37% |align="right"|20% |- |align="left"|Dartmouth |align="right"|15% |align="right"|21% |align="right"|6% |- |align="left"|Harvard |align="right"|9% |align="right"|21% |align="right"|6% |- |align="left"|Pennsylvania |align="right"|9% |align="right"|26% |align="right"|7% |- |align="left"|Princeton |align="right"|6% |align="right"|17% |align="right"|5% |- |align="left"|Yale |align="right"|10% |align="right"|20% |align="right"|12% |- |align="left"|Stanford |align="right"|10% |align="right"|16% |align="right"|9% |- |align="left"|MIT |align="right"|12% |align="right"|11% |align="right"|13% |- |align="left"|Total |align="right"|14% |align="right"|26% |align="right"|12% |- |}
====Applying in the fall==== Many schools have implemented a system through which students can apply at a time other than the most common usual deadline of January first of the twelfth grade, to lighten the load on students and admissions officers. Several reports suggest an increase in early admissions.
Many open slots for students at many private universities begin to fill up early in the last year of school. In 2001 it was estimated that a third of slots for next year's first-year class were filled by December, which was an increase from one-fifth a decade earlier.<ref name=twsZe25/> Estimates made around 2011 suggested that 45% of positions were taken by December.<ref name=twsM112/><ref name=twsMayO311>{{cite news |author1=Jacques Steinberg |author2=Rebecca R. Ruiz |title= Early Line on Early Admissions |newspaper= The New York Times |date= December 20, 2011 |url= http://thechoice.blogs.nytimes.com/2011/12/20/2012-early-admission/ |accessdate= May 15, 2012 }}</ref> There are reports for specific schools filling up by December 2011 for the 2012–2013 first-year class. For example, [[American University]] filled 31% of its class; [[Columbia University|Columbia]] 45%, [[Davidson College|Davidson]] 40%, [[Emory University|Emory]] 32%, [[Hamilton College (New York)|Hamilton]] 38%, [[Kenyon College|Kenyon]] 29%, [[Middlebury College|Middlebury]] 45%, [[Sarah Lawrence College|Sarah Lawrence]] 21%, [[Smith College|Smith]] 20%, and others.<ref name=twsMayO311/>
Numerous reports suggest that more students are applying using early decision or early action approaches.<ref name=twsM112>{{cite news |author1=Richard Pérez-Peña |author2=Jenny Anderson |title= As a Broader Group Seeks Early Admission, Rejections Rise in the East |publisher= ''The New York Times'' |date= January 13, 2012 |url= https://www.nytimes.com/2012/01/14/education/early-admission-applications-rise-as-do-rejections.html?_r=1&ref=todayspaper&pagewanted=all |accessdate= January 13, 2012 }}</ref> Schools such as [[Duke University]], [[Haverford College]], and the [[University of Chicago]] reported increases in early applications in 2011.<ref name=twsM112/> While early applications had been used by many students in elite prep schools and top high schools primarily in the northeastern United States, they are being used by a more diverse group of students including foreigners and minority applicants to apply to more colleges.<ref name=twsM112/> A downside of applying early is an inability to compare competing aid packages from different schools, but to an extent this can be mitigated if parents and students ask the college for a fairly firm estimate of expected costs before applying by an early method.<ref name=twsMay2Pfjk/> Several sources suggested that early admissions programs favor students from wealthier families since there was no need to compare financial aid offers.<ref name=tws3JanK11/><ref name=twsMay2R113/> Adviser Michele Hernandez suggested that the early decision and early action candidate pools were "much more homogeneous" with most applicants being affluent white students.{{sfn|Hernandez|2009|pp=36}} High-end academic applicants tended to want to have a choice, while minority applicants needed to compare scholarship offers from different colleges; accordingly, these latter two groups tended to avoid early applications.{{sfn|Hernandez|2009|pp=36}} According to Hernandez, Ivy League financial aid packages were similar whether one applied early admission or regular admission, since the Ivies are 100% [[Need-blind admission|need blind]] meaning that they do not take into account an applicant's ability to pay.{{sfn|Hernandez|2009|pp=39}} Early applicants are urged to submit applications in September and October, and not wait until November, so staff more time to consider the application.<ref name=twsMayO112/> There has been controversy surrounding early admissions programs, since there have been reports that most of those accepted in early admissions tended to be white, from good high schools and having upscale family incomes.<ref name=twsL16/> A report in ''[[US News]]'' suggested that early admissions approaches were not advised for students who were obviously under or over qualified, dependent on financial aid, undecided, behind in their college search plans, or late bloomers.<ref name=tws2ZG313>{{cite news |author= Kim Clark |title= 6 Kinds of Students Shouldn't Apply to College Early: Late bloomers and those who need financial aid benefit from regular applications. |work= US News |date= December 27, 2010 |url= https://www.usnews.com/education/best-colleges/applying/articles/2010/12/27/6-kinds-of-students-shouldnt-apply-to-college-early |accessdate= July 7, 2012 }}</ref> In 2018, a probe by the justice department is looking to see whether colleges and universities, who have an early admissions program, violated antitrust regulations by swapping information about applicants.<ref name=twsNYT8859/>
=====Early decision===== * '''Binding commitment'''. [[Early decision]] is a binding decision, meaning that students must withdraw applications to other schools if accepted. It is not legally binding,<ref name=tws2ZB47>{{cite web |title= Ask the Experts: Early Decision and Early Application |work= Peterson's College Search |date= July 7, 2012 |url= http://www.petersons.com/college-search/ask-experts-early-decision.aspx |accessdate= July 7, 2012 }}</ref><ref name=twsNYT8859/> but there is a commitment involved with penalties for withdrawing for spurious reasons. Advisers suggest that this method is only for students who are absolutely certain about wanting to attend a specific school.<ref name=tws2ZB44/> If financial aid is a concern or if a family is "shopping for the best deal", then it is usually advised to apply early action or regular decision instead.<ref name=tws2ZB44/><ref name=tws2ZB48/><ref name=twsNYT8859/> The one stipulated situation under which a student may back out of the agreement is if the financial aid offer is insufficient.<ref name=tws2ZB42/><ref name=tws2ZB47/><ref name=tws2ZB44/><ref name=tws2ZB48>{{cite news |author= Robert J. Massa |title= The Case for Early Decision |work= The New York Times |date= December 13, 2010 |url= http://thechoice.blogs.nytimes.com/2010/12/13/the-case-for-early-decision/ |accessdate= July 7, 2012 }}</ref><ref name=tws2ZB41/><ref name=tws2ZG112/> A student who backs out for other reasons may be "blacklisted" by the early decision college, which may contact the student's high school guidance office,<ref name=tws2ZB47/> and prevent it from sending transcripts to other colleges, and high schools generally comply with such requests.<ref name=tws2ZB41/> In addition, the jilted college may contact other colleges about the withdrawal, and the other colleges would likely break off their offers of acceptance as well.<ref name=tws2ZB47/> And by the time that an early decision aid package is offered it may be March or April of [[twelfth grade]], and then if a student backs out at that point for financial reasons, valuable time may be lost.<ref name=tws2ZB44>{{cite news |title= Early Decision – Financial Aid |work= The Princeton Review |date= July 7, 2012 |url= http://www.princetonreview.com/early-decision-and-financial-aid.aspx |accessdate= July 7, 2012 }}</ref> * '''November application'''. It is made early in the academic year, typically the first week in November,{{sfn|Hernandez|2009|pp=33}} although deadlines vary somewhat, so a student who applies for early decision and is accepted, typically by mid-December, must attend that college.<ref name=twsL12/> One report maintains that some colleges defer decisions on some early applicants until the next year, past their own deadlines for notifying early applicants.<ref name=tws2ZG114/> * '''Benefits for universities'''. Admitting early decision applicants benefits schools because there is an almost certain probability that the admitted applicants will attend and, as a result, colleges can increase their [[yield (college admissions)|yield]] by admitting them, and this can help a college improve its ranking.<ref name=tws3JanK11/> In addition, it helps admissions departments spread the work of sifting through applications throughout more of the school year.<ref name=tws3JanK11/> Generally counselors suggest this option is only for students who know with certainty that one particular college is their first choice. * '''Greater chance of acceptance'''. There is strong consensus that applying early decision brings a greater statistical chance of being accepted,<ref name=twsL12/><ref name=tws2ZB48/><ref name=tws2ZG113>{{cite news |author= Peter Van Buskirk |title= The College Admissions Insider: Decide if an Early Decision College Application is the Right Choice |work= US News |date= September 19, 2011 |url= https://www.usnews.com/education/blogs/the-college-admissions-insider/2011/09/19/decide-if-an-early-decision-college-application-is-the-right-choice |accessdate= July 7, 2012 }}</ref><ref name=tws2C37>{{cite web |title= Financial Aid and Early Decision |work= College Confidential |date= July 7, 2012 |url= http://www.collegeconfidential.com/dean/archives/000198.htm |accessdate= July 7, 2012 }}</ref><ref>Christopher Avery; Andrew Fairbanks, Richard Zeckhauser (2004). ''The Early Admissions Game: Joining the Elite.'' Cambridge, Massachusetts: Harvard University Press. {{ISBN|0-674-01620-3}}.</ref><ref name=tws2ZG312>{{cite news |author= Margaret Loftus |title= Know if Applying to College Early is Right for You: Getting in could be easier, but a search for financial aid might suffer |work= US News |date= September 12, 2011 |url= https://www.usnews.com/education/best-colleges/articles/2011/09/12/know-if-applying-to-college-early-is-right-for-you?page=2 |accessdate= July 7, 2012 }}</ref><ref name=twsNYT8859/> possibly doubling or tripling the chances of an acceptance letter.<ref name=twsL24/> In 2009, the average early acceptance rate according to one estimate was 15 percentage points greater than regular decision applicants.<ref name=tws2ZG114/> There is less agreement, however, whether it will help a borderline student win acceptance to a competitive college. There are numerous reports that early decision candidates tend to have stronger educational credentials than regular decision candidates,<ref name=tws2ZG311>{{cite news |author= Mark Kantrowitz |title= Guidance Office: Answers About Financial Aid, Part 6 |work= The New York Times |date= April 11, 2009 |url= http://thechoice.blogs.nytimes.com/2009/04/11/guidance-office-answers-about-financial-aid-part-6/ |accessdate= July 7, 2012 }}</ref><ref name=tws2ZG312/><ref name=tws2ZB43>{{cite web |author= Sarah Winkler |title= How Early Decision Affects Financial Aid |work= HowStuffWorks.com |date= July 7, 2012 |url= http://money.howstuffworks.com/personal-finance/college-planning/financial-aid/early-decision-financial-aid1.htm |accessdate= July 7, 2012 }}</ref> and as a result, these candidates would have been admitted whether they applied by early or regular methods, and therefore the greater statistical likelihood of acceptance may have been explained by membership in the stronger applicant pool.<ref name=tws2ZG311/> But a more widely held view is that early decision method boosts the chances of a borderline student; as Robert J. Massa of [[Lafayette College]] explained, "colleges really want qualified students who want them" and are more likely to offer acceptances to students ready to make a full commitment.<ref name=tws2ZB48/> There was a report that the "acceptance rate gap" between early and regular decision—currently an average of 57% accepted if applied early decision versus 50% if applied regular decision—has been narrowing in recent years.<ref name=twsMayO211/> Early decision has been criticized for unfairly advantaging students from affluent families.<ref name=twsNYT49104>Frank Bruni, December 21, 2016, The New York Times, [https://www.nytimes.com/2016/12/21/opinion/the-plague-of-early-decision.html?emc=edit_ty_20161221&nl=opinion-today&nlid=76434108&te=1&_r=0 The Plague of 'Early Decision'], Retrieved December 21, 2016, "...It significantly disadvantages students from low-income and middle-income families, who are ..."</ref><ref name=twsNYT8859/> * '''Other benefits'''. Twelfth graders can know sooner where they will attend and can get the hassle and uncertainty of the applications process over sooner. There is less work and expense applying to other colleges. * '''How early decision affects financial aid'''. There are conflicting reports about how early decision affects aid offers. The more widely held view is that a student's bargaining position is weaker because the student cannot compare offers from different colleges.<ref name=tws2ZB42>{{cite news |author= Grace Wong |title= Early decision action plan: Your child has been accepted to the college of their dreams – but are you sure you can afford it? |work= CNN/Money |date= December 12, 2005 |url= http://money.cnn.com/2005/12/09/pf/college/early_decision/index.htm |accessdate= July 7, 2012 }}</ref><ref name=tws2ZG313/><ref name=tws2ZB47/><ref name=tws2ZG114>{{cite news |author= Kim Clark |title= Early Applicants More Likely to Gain College Admission: Higher admission rate of early college applicants fuels controversy |work= US News |date= December 15, 2010 |url= https://www.usnews.com/education/best-colleges/right-school/timeline/articles/2010/12/15/early-applicants-more-likely-to-gain-college-admission |accessdate= July 7, 2012 }}</ref><ref name=tws2ZB45>{{cite news |title= The Financial Aid Effect on Early Decision and Early Application |work= Peterson's College Search |date= July 7, 2012 |url= http://www.petersons.com/college-search/early-decision-financial-aid.aspx |accessdate= July 7, 2012 }}</ref><ref name=tws2ZB46>{{cite news |title= How Early Decision Can Affect Financial Aid |work= CollegeMadeSimple.com |date= July 7, 2012 |url= http://www.collegemadesimple.com/how-early-decision-can-affect-financial-aid/ |accessdate= July 7, 2012 }}</ref><ref name=twsNYT8859/> Since the applicant is declaring an intention to attend if accepted, then the school can "pinpoint the smallest amount of financial aid it will take for the student to attend."<ref name=tws2ZB41/> There have been reports of problems with early Decision aid offers falling below levels that had been expected prior to applying.<ref name=twsL16/> A report in the ''[[Chicago Tribune]]'' suggested that applying early decision could cost "thousands more than necessary."<ref name=tws2ZG111>{{cite news |author= Gail MarksJarvis |title= Applying to college? 'Early decision' could cost more |work= Chicago Tribune: Business |date= September 20, 2010 |url= http://articles.chicagotribune.com/2010-09-20/business/sc-biz-0921-strip-finance-20100920_1_financial-aid-early-decision-kalman-chany |accessdate= July 7, 2012 }}</ref> A report in ''[[US News]]'' pointed to a research study concluding that regular decision applicants get more financial aid than early ones.<ref name=tws2ZG313/> Lynn O'Shaughnessy described early decision as "essentially applying blind" because a student has agreed to attend before seeing the financial aid package; and this practice "favors rich students."<ref name=tws2ZG112>{{cite news |author= Lynn O'Shaughnessy |title= Early Decision: 10 Things You Need To Know About Applying |work= CBS News |date= September 8, 2011 |url= http://www.cbsnews.com/8301-505145_162-37246537/early-decision-10-things-you-need-to-know-about-applying/ |accessdate= July 7, 2012 }}</ref> Several reports confirm that early decision applicants tend to come from wealthier families.<ref name=tws2ZB43/><ref name=twsNYT49104/> However, a contrasting view is that students who apply early have an advantage getting aid because they are applying earlier in the year when that aid is being doled out, and the early decision kids have "first crack at the money,"<ref name=tws2ZB48/><ref name=tws2ZB41>{{cite news |author= Annamaria Andriotis |title= Do Early Decision Students Get More Aid? |work= SmartMoney |date= November 10, 2009 |url= http://www.smartmoney.com/borrow/student-loans/do-early-decision-students-get-more-financial-aid/ |accessdate= July 7, 2012 }}</ref><ref name=tws2ZB43/> particularly at competitive schools without extra-large endowments. Two reports suggested that while a student's bargaining position is somewhat weaker, it is not totally diminished, and that if a college thinks an early decision admittee may withdraw because of financial concerns, the college "may pull out all the stops" to prevent this,<ref name=tws2ZB46/> and that the possibility of backing out for financial reasons gives an applicant some form of negotiating leverage.<ref name=tws2ZB48/> [[Ivy League]] universities and other universities with large endowments may be somewhat different, in the sense that all aid offers are likely to be based solely on financial need, and that whether an applicant applied by early or regular methods would have no impact on the resulting financial aid package, according to one report.<ref name=tws2ZG311/>
=====Early action===== [[File:College admissions consultant at workshop for high school juniors.jpg|thumb|College admissions consultant Michael Szarek advises against applying early decision unless a student is totally certain of the choice and parents have sufficient resources to pay the bill; he often recommends the non-binding alternative, early action, as an alternative.]]
Generally [[early action]] is similar to early decision except the decision is not binding,{{sfn|Hernandez|2009|pp=33}} so a student could apply to multiple colleges.<ref name=twsL12>{{cite news |author1=Diana Hanson |author2=Esther Walling |author3=Craig Meister |author4=Kristen Tabun |title= Which College Admissions Deadline Should You Choose? |publisher= ''US News'' |date= November 16, 2011 |url= https://www.usnews.com/education/blogs/college-admissions-experts/2011/11/16/which-college-admissions-deadline-should-you-choose |accessdate= December 12, 2011 }}</ref> The time frame is similar: apply by early November, get a decision by mid-December,{{sfn|Hernandez|2009|pp=33}} although specific deadlines vary by school. It allows a student to compare competing offers.<ref name=tws2ZB43/> The exception is that there are four colleges – [[Harvard University|Harvard]], [[Princeton University|Princeton]], [[Stanford University|Stanford]], and [[Yale University|Yale]]—which have a single-choice early action program, meaning that an applicant can only apply early action to one school. Early action can be the best choice for students who know they prefer one particular school and have done everything possible to secure admission since a student will know the result of the application sooner,<ref name=twsL12/> and to varying extents allows a student to compare aid offers from different schools.<ref name=twsMay2Pfjk/> One report suggested that non-binding early action programs continued to be highly popular, and noticed that three schools––[[Harvard University|Harvard]], [[Princeton University|Princeton]], and the [[University of Virginia]]—which had abandoned early admissions programs in 2006, reestablished them in 2011 after other colleges failed to follow their lead.<ref name=twsL16>{{cite news |author= Scott Jaschik |title= Elite universities surrender to early admissions |publisher= ''USA Today'' |date= February 25, 2011 |url= https://www.usatoday.com/news/education/2011-02-25-early-admissions_N.htm |accessdate= December 12, 2011 }}</ref> Generally fewer schools offer the early action program but ones that do include [[Georgetown University]], [[Massachusetts Institute of Technology|MIT]], and [[Boston College]].<ref name=tws2ZB43/> One account suggested that early action did not give as much of an "admissions edge" as early decision because it was non-binding.<ref name=tws2ZG312/>
====Regular admission==== Regular admission is a good choice for students who are unsure where they would like to go.<ref name=twsL12/> One advantage is that it can help students who have improved their grades substantially in the fall of twelfth grade, since decisions are not made until March of that year.<ref name=twsL12/> In addition, it offers students more time to make their decision about a college under somewhat less pressure than an early method. The fairly dominant view is that regular admission is more likely to result in higher offers of financial aid, particularly if students are admitted to several institutions that present different aid offers. Accordingly, one offer can be used as leverage to try to get a better offer at another institution,<ref name=tws2ZG313/> particularly if there are competing multiple acceptances.<ref name=tws2ZG314/> Several reports suggested that a "growing number of colleges" including [[Harvard University|Harvard]], [[Cornell University|Cornell]], and [[Carnegie Mellon University|Carnegie-Mellon]] have stated publicly that they will consider matching offers from competing colleges.<ref name=tws2ZG314>{{cite news |author= Kim Clark |title= College Cash 101: "Financial Aid eBay" Winners Set Off Scholarship Bidding Wars |work= US News |date= September 13, 2010 |url= https://www.usnews.com/education/blogs/college-cash-101/2010/09/13/financial-aid-ebay-winners-set-off-scholarship-bidding-wars |accessdate= July 7, 2012 }}</ref><ref name=tws2ZG313/> Kim Clark explained:
{{Quote|If you want to go to Cornell ... and you don't think your family can afford the full sticker prices ... you are likely to get bigger scholarships if you also apply—and get in—to wealthy and more competitive schools. ... Cornell will now adopt Harvard's definition of "need," which, in many cases, will mean bigger scholarships.|report in ''[[US News]]'', 2010<ref name=tws2ZG314/>}}
However, a dissenting view in ''[[The New York Times]]'' suggested that only one to two percent of colleges adjust aid packages based on offers from competing colleges, and that most colleges do not get into bidding wars over specific students.<ref name=tws2ZG311/>
====Rolling admissions==== Some colleges offer this type of admission, typically used by schools with large numbers of applicants, which means that colleges are continually receiving applications and making decisions, typically within four to six weeks after application.<ref name=twsL12/> It allows prospective students to apply at any time between the fall and spring and to receive their result a few weeks later. One benefit is that if a student is accepted early in the school year, there is less anxiety about acceptance for the rest of the year.<ref name=twsL12/> Rolling admission schools are also beneficial to students who are rejected from all the schools they applied regularly to, yet still wish to enroll without taking a [[gap year]]. Guidance counselors suggest that rolling admissions should not be used late in [[twelfth grade]] since financial aid money may have already been distributed, and few slots may be left for September.<ref name=twsL12/> One advisor suggests that if a college offers rolling admissions and is on a student's list, then it should be applied to as soon as rolling admissions becomes available for that year.<ref name=twsL12/> Another report suggested that rolling admissions was more characteristic of noncompetitive colleges.<ref name=twsL16/>
===Testing options===
====Test preparation courses==== There are conflicting reports about the usefulness of test preparation courses. Mamlet and VanDeVelde suggest that "most students don't need a coach or a class" and that the single largest factor was "familiarity with the test".<ref name=twsMay2R214/> Another report agreed that SAT/ACT prep courses were a waste of money and that taking a few practice exams, and understanding how each test works, was all that was needed.<ref name=twsMay2R211/> According to ''[[NBC News]]'', the multibillion-dollar private test prep industry, including coaching and tutoring as well as software and clinics, is a source of "inequality and injustice" in higher education since it enables the offspring of well-to-do families to improve their test scores by means of learning "tips and tricks"; there is a report in March 2014 that the ''College Board'' is planning to redesign the SAT to make it less susceptible to gaming.<ref name=NBCNews17>Nona Willis Aronowitz, March 6, 2014, NBC News, [http://www.nbcnews.com/news/education/does-new-sat-spell-doom-test-prep-industry-n45936 Does the New SAT Spell Doom for the Test Prep Industry?], Accessed March 6, 2014</ref> Test prep courses can cost $1,000 per course; tutors can cost $15,000 per year, according to one estimate.<ref name=NBCNews17/>
====Standardized admissions tests==== [[File:SAT Grid-in mathematics question.png|thumb|alt=Picture of a math question in a book.|A sample so-called "grid-in" question from a standardized test.<ref>Note: answer = 14; for further explanation, click on the picture and read the description.</ref>]]
In 2003, according to one estimate, 1.4 million students took the SAT and 1.4 million also took the ACT test,<ref name=twsMay2S213/> paying about $50 per test.<ref name=tws2V2449/> Generally counselors suggest that students should plan on taking the SAT or ACT test twice, so that a low score can possibly be improved.{{sfn|Mamlet|2011|p=98}} One advisor suggested that students with weak [[SAT]] or [[ACT (test)|ACT]] scores could consider applying to colleges where these measures were optional.<ref name=twsL19/> One suggested retaking the tests if there are "subpar test scores" in September and October (if applying early admission) or November and December (if applying regular admission.)<ref name=twsL27/> Generally over half of eleventh graders retaking the SAT or ACT tests during the twelfth grade saw improvements in their scores.<ref name=tws2V2449/> Colleges vary in terms of how much emphasis they place on these scores.<ref name=tws2T21>{{cite news |author1=Hunter, Jeffrey G. |author2=Samter, Wendy |title= A college admission test protocol to mitigate the effects of false negative SAT scores |work= Journal of College Admission via Highbeam Research |quote= According to Gandara and Lopez (1998), SAT scores will be weighted anywhere from "almost not at all" to "heavily" in the admission decision, depending upon the college or university. |date= July 1, 2000 |url= http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P3-56122130.html |accessdate= August 20, 2012 }}</ref>
A consensus view is that most colleges accept either the [[SAT]] or [[ACT (test)|ACT]], and have formulas for converting scores into admissions criteria, and can convert SAT scores into ACT scores and vice versa relatively easily.{{sfn|Hernandez|2009|pp=57}} The ACT is reportedly more popular in the [[Midwestern United States|midwest]] and [[Southern United States|south]] while the SAT is more popular on the [[Eastern United States|east]] and [[Western United States|west]] coasts.<ref name=tws2V211/> Apparently there have been instances of persons taking admissions tests in place of the real student as paid ''SAT test-takers,'' which is illegal, but the existence of such services has been called "an open secret in competitive circles"; for example, in 2011, an [[Emory University]] second-year student was arrested for taking the test for another person on a fee basis.<ref name=twsL35>{{cite news |author= Susan Dominus |title= Studying, Testing or Paying Their Way In |publisher= ''The New York Times Magazine'' |date= December 2, 2011 |url= http://6thfloor.blogs.nytimes.com/2011/12/02/studying-testing-or-paying-their-way-in/?ref=admissions |accessdate= December 12, 2011 }}</ref> One report suggested the [[College Board]] was considering requiring that test-takers submit a photograph of themselves on the test day as a precaution against impersonation. The photos would be stored in a password-protected database, but would not be shared with college admissions departments.<ref name=twsMay2Q959>{{cite news |author= Tanya Caldwell |title= SAT's Student Photo Database Draws Comparisons to Facebook Profiles |newspaper= The New York Times |date= March 28, 2012 |url= http://thechoice.blogs.nytimes.com/2012/03/28/sats-student-photo-database-draws-comparisons-to-facebook-profiles/ |accessdate= May 17, 2012 }}</ref>
Michele Hernandez recommended taking the SAT or ACT test only once or twice otherwise an applicant may appear "score obsessed."{{sfn|Hernandez|2009|pp=56–57}} One report suggested that a benefit of the ACT test was that it allowed the test-taker to have greater freedom to choose which scores to send to which colleges.{{sfn|Hernandez|2009|pp=57}} Counselors suggest that students practice taking the test under actual testing conditions.{{sfn|Mamlet|2011|p=93}} Counselors advise students taking tests should become familiar with directions beforehand so there will be more time to focus on problems during the actual test.{{sfn|Mamlet|2011|p=92}} And the use of tests by colleges has been criticized as being ineffective at predicting ultimate life success; one study suggested that SAT results "don't mean much long term".<ref name=twsMayO412>{{cite news |author= Jay Mathews |authorlink= Jay Mathews |title= Your SAT score has little to do with your life |newspaper= Washington Post |date= July 8, 2010 |url= http://voices.washingtonpost.com/class-struggle/2010/07/your_sat_score_has_little_to_d.html |accessdate= May 15, 2012 }}</ref>
{| style="float:right; width:30em; font-weight:bold; border:solid 1px #999999; font-size:.9em; line-height:1.3em; margin:0 0 1em 1em;" cellpadding="4" cellspacing="0"
|-style="color:#000080; font-size:1.1em;" align="center" valign="top" |ACT test |SAT test
|-style="color:#800000;" valign="top" |Content-based test<ref name=tws2V211/> |Tests reasoning ability<ref name=tws2V211/>
|-style="color:#10365B;" valign="top" |Emphasizes higher math<ref name=twsMay2Pfjk/><ref name=tws2V211/> |Emphasizes vocabulary<ref name=twsMay2Pfjk/><ref name=tws2V211/>
|-style="color:#2A6B35;" valign="top" |Longer questions<ref name=tws2V211/> |Trickier questions<ref name=tws2V211/>
|-style="color:#0581F1;" valign="top" |More popular in south & midwest<ref name=tws2V211/> |More popular in east & west<ref name=tws2V211/>
|-style="color:#266F5E;" valign="top" |Science reasoning section<ref name=tws2V211/> |Vocabulary section<ref name=tws2V211/>
|-style="color:#630C75;" valign="top" |No penalty for wrong answers{{sfn|Mamlet|2011|p=92}} |No penalty for wrong answers<ref name=twsReuters143>Renee Dudley, September 21, 2016, Reuters, [https://www.reuters.com/investigates/special-report/college-sat-redesign/ Despite warnings, College Board redesigned SAT in way that may hurt neediest students], Retrieved October 12, 2016, "...no penalty for guessing wrong, ... encourages students to answer every question ... simply earn points for the questions you answer correctly..."</ref><ref>Note: SAT updated in 2016</ref>
|-style="color:#10365B;" valign="top" |Greater choice in selecting which scores to send to colleges{{sfn|Hernandez|2009|pp=57}} |Fewer options
|-style="color:#0581F1;" valign="top" |Difficult questions randomly interspersed<ref name=tws2V211/> |Difficulty progresses within each section<ref name=tws2V211/> |} Regarding whether to choose the SAT or ACT, the consensus view is that both tests are roughly equivalent and tend to bring similar results, and that each test is equally accepted by colleges. Reporter Jacques Steinberg in ''[[The New York Times]]'' suggested that admissions deans repeatedly inform him that colleges view the ACT and SAT tests equally and do not have a preference.<ref name=twsMayO312>{{cite news |author= Jacques Steinberg |title= Q. & A. College Admissions; ACT vs. SAT: Deciding Which Exam to Take |newspaper= The New York Times |date= September 12, 2010 |url= https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=950DEEDF1339F931A2575AC0A9669D8B63 |accessdate= May 15, 2012 }}</ref> At the same time, small differences between the tests may translate into a slight benefit for the test-taker. One report suggested that the SAT favors "white male students" from upper income backgrounds.<ref name=twsMayO313>{{cite news |author= Sarah Gonzalez |title= SAT Tests Favor White, Male Students, Book Argues |newspaper= NPR Florida |date= November 10, 2011 |url= http://stateimpact.npr.org/florida/2011/11/10/sat-tests-favor-white-male-students-book-argues/ |accessdate= May 15, 2012 }}</ref> Another report suggests that the ACT has more questions geared to higher levels of high school mathematics, suggesting that students who do well in math may perform better, but that the SAT is a better choice for students with an excellent vocabulary.<ref name=twsMay2Pfjk/><ref name=tws2V211/> According to one view, the SAT is more focused on testing reasoning ability while the ACT is more of a content-based test of achievement.<ref name=tws2V211>{{cite web |title= ACT vs SAT: Key differences between the ACT and SAT |work= Studypoint.com |year= 2012 |url= http://www.studypoint.com/ed/act-vs-sat/ |accessdate= June 22, 2012 }}</ref> In addition, according to this view, some SAT questions can be trickier and harder to decipher while some ACT questions may be longer;<ref name=tws2V211/> question difficulty progresses within each SAT section while difficult questions are randomly interspersed in the ACT;<ref name=tws2V211/> the SAT has a separate vocabulary section while the ACT has a separate science reasoning section.<ref name=tws2V211/> In 2016 the SAT was updated to remove the penalty for random guessing; the College Board advises that test-takers will benefit by guessing.<ref name=twsReuters143/>
====SAT subject tests==== Several sources suggested that the [[SAT subject tests]] were becoming more important in evaluating applicants. One described them as "true equalizers" in admissions, suggesting how strong a high school is, and elaborated that some admissions officers considered them to be a better indicator of academic ability than high school grades.{{sfn|Hernandez|2009|pp=59–65}} Another suggested that selective colleges like to get results from [[SAT subject tests]] in addition to other ones, while public universities placed less emphasis on them.{{sfn|Mamlet|2011|p=94}}
====Advanced placement tests==== There was a report that scores on [[Advanced Placement exams]] could be helpful in the evaluations process.{{sfn|Hernandez|2009|pp=97}} One report suggested there was a limit on the number of AP tests that should be taken, such that taking 12 AP tests was not as helpful as taking five and doing well on those five.<ref name=twsMay2R211/>
===Common vs. college's application=== [[File:Sign saying Common Application Membership.jpg|thumb|The [[Common Application]].]] The advantage of the [[Common Application]] is that it is the same for numerous colleges, and can save time and trouble for a student. It is accepted at 488 colleges out of several thousand, but only a third of the 488 use it exclusively, meaning that two-thirds allow an applicant to submit either the ''Common Application'' or the school's specific application form.{{sfn|Hernandez|2009|pp=115–116}}<ref>{{cite web|title=All Members|url=https://www.commonapp.org/CommonApp/Members.aspx|publisher=The Common Application|accessdate=November 1, 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121031075325/https://www.commonapp.org/CommonApp/Members.aspx|archivedate=October 31, 2012|df=mdy-all}}</ref> According to Hernandez, many admissions officers complain that the ''Common Application'' stifles creativity and encourages "dull responses", and she recommends that students use the college's particular application when there is a choice.{{sfn|Hernandez|2009|pp=115–116}}
===Interviews=== {{Main|College interview}} [[File:Videoconferencing via Skype across the Internet between Interview Coach Mark Efinger and a woman being coached.png|thumb|right|300px|Internet videoconferencing using [[Skype]] with face-on-face technology allows a coach to prepare an applicant for a [[college interview]] despite the geographic distance.]] [[File:Lieber College, University of South Carolina.jpg|thumb|Admissions office of the [[University of South Carolina]] in [[Columbia, South Carolina]].]] There are differing recommendations about the importance of interviews, with the consensus view that interviews were overall less important than college admissions essays, but should be done if they were offered.<ref name=twsMay2S213/> One advisor suggested that visits by college admissions personnel to the high schools were a waste of time for colleges, since there was not enough time to get to know specific applicants.{{sfn|Hernandez|2009|pp=107}} In addition, she felt that personal interviews were generally overrated, though she noted that many Ivies have alumni interviews, which can help in borderline situations.{{sfn|Hernandez|2009|pp=153–156}} One counselor suggested that if an interview was offered by a college admissions program, then it was not really optional but it should be seen as a requirement, that is, not going to such an interview could be detrimental to a student's chances for admission.<ref name=twsL24/> Another suggested that a student should try to get an interview, even if it was not required, since it might help "exhibit character strengths" that might not show up via grades on high school transcripts.<ref name=twsL19/> Several reports noted that most [[Ivy League]] schools have abandoned the interview requirement, but that if there is an opportunity for an interview, even with an alumnus of the college, then it is a good idea to do it since not doing it signals a lack of interest in the school.<ref name=twsL24/>{{sfn|Hernandez|2009|pp=153–156}} Knowing a college can be helpful during an interview, so that an applicant can say something specific about the school, or a professor who teaches there, or a subject or internship opportunities, since it shows sincere interest.<ref name=twsL44/>{{sfn|Hernandez|2009|pp=153–156}} Interviews (if offered) may be more of a factor at small liberal arts colleges:
{{Quote|Our advice is that if offered an interview, a student should take it ... And they should dress as if they are going to dinner with their grandparents. The biggest faux pax comes in inappropriate dress for both sexes. Spaghetti straps, buttons that pop open. For boys a rumpled T-shirt ... If you look in the mirror and you think you look good, change your clothes. This is not a date.|Mamlet and VanDeVelde<ref name=twsMay2R214/>}}
One suggested that a goal of interview preparation should be to present oneself as "comfortable with spontaneous conversation" and be able to talk about interests without sounding like the answers were prepared in advance, and suggested it was important to show intellectual passion and a love of learning with a deep excitement, and show "social maturity" with sensitivity, empathy for others unlike oneself, and concern for issues larger than personal career ambitions.{{sfn|Dunbar|2007|pp=29, 36, 38, 83–96}} An applicant should have an attitude that was not be what can the college offer but what can the student offer the college, and he or she should avoid asking questions about facts better answered elsewhere, and show an openness to new ideas, an ability to work cooperatively with others, ambition, and caring about others.{{sfn|Dunbar|2007|p=62, 66, 67}} Interviewees should be ready for sometimes provocative questions to test social sensitivity; if an interviewer asks a "baiting or leading question", an applicant should respond by laughing while politely disagreeing with the perspective, and to keep trying to enjoy the conversation with the interviewer.{{sfn|Dunbar|2007|p=93}} Another advisor suggested that students must be prepared to answer the question ''What is your biggest failure'' in an interview.<ref name=twsBostonGlobe4>Sanjay Solomon, January 30, 2015, The Boston Globe, [http://www.boston.com/jobs/news/2015/01/30/can-failure-resume-help-you-succeed/uTBdq9A7LfXXF7vVOlG9oM/story.html Can a Failure Resume Help You Succeed?], Retrieved January 30, 2016, "... "Asking 'what is your biggest failure?' is an opportunity [for an interviewer] to get a reality check and to put a little pressure on this person"...."</ref> Applicants should avoid sounding snide, annoyed, contemptuous, and avoid describing oneself as humiliated, bored, depressed, angry, shy, inhibited, anxious, frightened, and frustrated,{{sfn|Dunbar|2007|pp=110–122}} and should be upbeat but avoid going for the hard sell.{{sfn|Dunbar|2007|pp=110–122}} Another report suggested that shy or timid applicants were at a disadvantage.<ref name=tws2T28>{{cite news |author= Hanley, Thomas A., Jr. |title= Shyness and the College Admission Process: Who is Being Left Out? |work= Journal of College Admission |quote= ... If two applicants appeared academically equivalent on paper and both were interviewing at a top tier school, the gregarious, self-confident candidate would most likely be perceived more favorably than the timid and self-conscious one ... |date= January 1, 2005 |url= http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P3-809396571.html |accessdate= August 20, 2012 }}</ref> Another advisor suggested that a student try to find a common bond with the interviewer, and send a brief follow-up letter afterwards.{{sfn|Hernandez|2009|pp=157–158}}
===Essays=== There are differing opinions about the importance of the [[admissions essay|college essay]]. The consensus view is that the essay is less important than grades and test scores, but that an essay can make a difference in some instances,<ref name=twsL24/> often at highly selective colleges where they can "make or break your application."<ref name=twsMayO112/> There was one report that essays were becoming more important as a way to judge a student's potential,<ref name=twsMayO112/> and that essays have supplanted personal interviews as a primary way to evaluate a student's character.
The [[Common Application]] requires that personal statements be 250 to 650 words in length.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://admission.stanford.edu/apply/freshman/apply.html|title=How to Apply : Stanford University|last=University|first=Undergraduate Admission at Stanford|website=admission.stanford.edu|language=en|access-date=2018-10-28}}</ref> Although applicants may strive to reach the word limit, college admissions officers emphasize that the most important part is honing and rewriting:
{{Quote|Writing is easy; rewriting is hard. And essays deserve to be rewritten several times. Lots of kids think the objective is to write about something that will ''impress'' the admission office. In part that is true, but what impresses an admission officer is an essay that conveys something positive about the applicant; that allows the committee to get to know the kid just a bit from those few pieces of paper. The essay is an opportunity to provide a different perspective about the applicant, a reason to accept a kid. It is an opportunity not to be wasted.<ref name=twsL24/>}}
Advisors suggest that the essay should be concise, honest (with no embellishments), coherent, not boring,<ref name=tws2ZG315/> accurate, and visually evocative. The essay should reveal a likeable<ref name=tws2ZG315/> and smart individual. It should approach humor and controversial topics with caution and balance.<ref name="twsL26">{{cite news|url=https://www.usnews.com/education/blogs/professors-guide/2010/09/15/10-tips-for-writing-the-college-application-essay|title=10 Tips for Writing the College Application Essay|author1=Jeremy S. Hyman|date=September 15, 2010|accessdate=December 12, 2011|publisher=''US News''|author2=Lynn F. Jacobs|author3=Jonathan Reider}}</ref> Other tips include avoiding [[jargon]] or abbreviations, overly emotional appeals, profanity or texttalk (example: Schools H8 2 C texttalk), or artiness (e.g. poetry in an application)<ref name=tws2ZG315/> or cockiness.<ref name=twsL44/>
Former guidance counselor for students at [[Phillips Academy|Andover]] and college admissions authority Donald Dunbar suggested that essays must emphasize personal character and demonstrate intellectual curiosity, maturity, social conscience, concern for the community, tolerance, and inclusiveness.{{sfn|Dunbar|2007|p=ix}} He advises to not merely "be yourself," but show your "best self."{{sfn|Dunbar|2007|pp=11–21}} Dunbar furthermore claims that demonstrating class participation suggests a "willingness to go beyond selfishness" and shows enthusiasm for learning.{{sfn|Dunbar|2007|p=25}} Alan Gelb suggests that the only "no-no" is "shameless self-promotion".<ref name=twsMayO212>{{cite news |last= Gelb |first= Alan |title= The College Admissions Essay: Finding a Topic |newspaper= The New York Times |quote= For your college admissions essay, you will be asked to write 500 flawless words ... As far as I'm concerned, the only taboo is shameless self-promotion. |date= May 14, 2012 |url= http://thechoice.blogs.nytimes.com/2012/05/14/the-college-admissions-essay-finding-a-topic/ |accessdate= May 15, 2012 }}</ref> Topics to avoid{{according to whom|date=October 2016}} include babysitting experiences, pets, encounters with illegal drugs or alcohol or criminal activity,{{sfn|Mamlet|2011|p=207}} excuses to explain a low grade,{{sfn|Mamlet|2011|p=207}} stories about a former home or big brother or sister,{{sfn|Dunbar|2007|p=34}} a simple listing of achievements,{{sfn|Mamlet|2011|p=207}} expressing thanks for being chosen as a leader, talking about a "wilderness leadership course",{{sfn|Dunbar|2007|pp=67–68}} general complaining or whining,{{sfn|Mamlet|2011|p=207}} [[racism]] or [[sexism]] or disrespect for groups of people,{{sfn|Mamlet|2011|p=207}} bad taste or profanity or vulgarity or bathroom humor,{{sfn|Mamlet|2011|p=207}} early love or sex experiences,{{sfn|Mamlet|2011|p=207}} criticism or disrespect for parents,{{sfn|Mamlet|2011|p=207}} telling only jokes,{{sfn|Mamlet|2011|p=207}} excessive bragging or too many instances of the "I" pronoun,{{sfn|Mamlet|2011|p=207}}<ref>For example: "I did this, I did that, then I did this" and on and on ...</ref> personal health information about yourself or a friend or a family member,{{sfn|Mamlet|2011|p=207}} and copy-and-pasting a term paper in the essay form{{sfn|Mamlet|2011|p=207}} such as about global warming or the European debt crisis. Applicants should refrain from express opinions too strongly as if no counterviews were possible.{{sfn|Mamlet|2011|p=207}} The topic should be something the applicant cares about,{{sfn|Dunbar|2007|p=50}} and should show ''leadership'' in the sense of "asserting yourself to help others have more success." According to Dunbar, leadership is not necessarily about being in charge such as being the team captain or school president.{{sfn|Dunbar|2007|p=54}} Applicants should present a broad perspective and avoid simplistic words such as ''never'', ''always'', ''only'', or ''nobody'', which suggest narrow thinking.{{sfn|Dunbar|2007|p=136+}} Dunbar advised against the standard "tell 'em what you've told 'em" essay formula but doing something different, interesting, and exciting.{{sfn|Dunbar|2007|p=147}}
Former admissions director Michele Hernandez agreed, and suggested that the best essay topics were a slice-of-life story with poignant details, in which the writer ''shows'' and does not ''tell''.{{sfn|Hernandez|2009|pp=130–136}} She suggested that a student show their essay to a literate friend and ask if would they admit this person to the college.{{sfn|Hernandez|2009|pp=130–136}} She recommended that applicants not try to come across as a "preppy well-off kid" but downplay parental status.{{sfn|Hernandez|2009|pp=6–9}} Advisors Mamlet and VanDeVelde suggest that students proactively try to explain an unusual grade, such as a low grade in a core course.{{sfn|Mamlet|2011|p=58}} There are online databases available to help students write cogent essays.<ref name=Anders2014>{{cite news|last1=Anders|first1=George|title=What Essays Thrill Elite Schools? These Teens Will Show You|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/georgeanders/2014/12/01/what-essays-thrill-elite-schools-these-teens-will-show-you/|accessdate=March 17, 2015|work=Forbes|date=December 1, 2014}}</ref>
===Teacher recommendations=== Some colleges ask for teacher recommendation letters, typically from 11th or 12th grade teachers of core courses, and preferably who know the student well. One report suggested that having more than four recommendations was a mistake, and that a "thick file" indicated a "thick student" to admissions personnel.<ref name=tws2ZG315/> One report, however, was that teacher recommendations were becoming less important as a rating measure, according to one report.<ref name=twsMayO112>{{cite news |author= Kim Clark |title= 8 Big Changes to College Admissions in 2010 and 2011 |newspaper= US News |date= November 15, 2010 |url= https://www.usnews.com/education/best-colleges/applying/articles/2010/11/15/8-big-changes-to-college-admissions-in-2010-and-2011 |accessdate= May 15, 2012 }}</ref> There is a report that some colleges are asking for recommendation letters from parents to describe their child:
{{Quote|You might think they do nothing but brag ... But parents really nail their kids. They really get to the essence of what their daughter is about in a way we can't get anywhere else.|Deb Shaver, director of admissions at [[Smith College]]<ref name=twsMay2R213>{{cite news |author= Bonnie Rochman |title= The Latest Trend in College Admissions: Parents Write Letters of Recommendation: Some colleges are starting to ask Mom and Dad to put in a written plug for their progeny in the college admissions process. |newspaper= Time Magazine |date= March 26, 2012 |url= http://healthland.time.com/2012/03/26/the-latest-trend-in-college-admissions-parents-write-letters-of-recommendation/ |accessdate= May 18, 2012 }}</ref>}}
===Other considerations=== [[File:Dickinson College 2.JPG|thumb|alt=Archway outdoors shot says Dickinson College.|[[Dickinson College]] in [[Carlisle, Pennsylvania]].]]
Advisors counsel that applicants should meet deadlines,<ref name=twsL12/>{{sfn|Hernandez|2009|pp=153}}<ref name=twsMay2Pfjk/> spend time researching colleges,<ref name=twsL12/> be open-minded,<ref name=twsL13/> have fun,<ref name=twsL13/> communicate what "resonates" to the applicant about a particular school,<ref name=twsL23/> not fall in love with one or two colleges,<ref name=twsL14/> follow directions precisely<ref name=twsMay2Pfjk/> and make sure to click the "submit" button.<ref name=twsL44/> Rudeness towards staff members, feigning enthusiasm, and being pretentious are other turnoffs reported by admissions officers.<ref name=twsMay2Pfjk/> There is strong consensus among counselors and advisors that starting the college search early is vital. One recommends starting early in the twelfth grade;<ref name=twsL13/> another suggests that even this is too late, and that the process should begin during the eleventh grade and summer before twelfth grade.<ref name=twsL23>{{cite news |author1=Nancy Meislahn |author2=Don Fraser Jr. |author3=Jolyn Brand |author4=George Mills |title= What Are Some Mistakes to Avoid in the College Admissions Process? |publisher= ''US News'' |date= July 20, 2011 |url= https://www.usnews.com/education/blogs/college-admissions-experts/2011/07/20/what-are-some-mistakes-to-avoid-in-the-college-admissions-process |accessdate= December 12, 2011 }}</ref> And sources suggest that students who begin the process earlier tend to earn more acceptance letters.<ref name=twsL12/> Another advantage of beginning early is so that applications can be proofread for mistakes.<ref name=twsL23/> Advisors suggest that emails should be sent to specific persons in the admissions office, not to a generalized inbox.<ref name=twsL44/> Advisors suggest that applicants sending in paper applications should take care that handwriting is legible, particularly email addresses.<ref name=twsL44/> Advisors counsel that mistakes or changes should be explained somewhere in the application; for example, an adviser at [[Grinnell College]] suggested that a record need not be perfect but there must be an "explanation for any significant blip."<ref name=twsL44/><ref name=twsL14/> Advisors suggest that applicants should "own up to any bad behavior" such as suspensions since schools are "dutybound to report them", and suggest that a person should "accept responsibility and show contrition for "lessons learned," according to one view.<ref name=twsL44/>{{sfn|Hernandez|2009|pp=137}} Disciplinary actions are usually reported to the colleges by the high school as a matter of course. Advisors suggest that the application should help a student position themselves to create a unique picture.<ref name=twsL14/> It helps, according to one advisor, if a person knows himself or herself, because that enables an applicant to communicate effectively with a prospective school.<ref name=twsL23/> A report in ''[[The New York Times]]'' in 2016 suggested that some universities were considering changing their admissions guidelines to be more inclusive of less affluent applicants, to put less emphasis on standardized test and AP scores, and to put more emphasis on determining "which students' community-service projects are heartfelt and which are merely window dressing"; the report suggested that college admissions policies were often "cited as a culprit in sleep deprivation, anxiety and depression among students."<ref name=twsNYT7>Frank Bruni, January 19, 2016, The New York Times, [https://www.nytimes.com/2016/01/20/opinion/rethinking-college-admissions.html?_r=0 Rethinking College Admissions], Accessed January 19, 2016</ref><ref name=twsWashPost5>Lisa Heffernan and Jennifer Wallace, January 20, 2016, The Washington Post, [https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/parenting/wp/2016/01/20/to-get-into-college-harvard-report-advocates-for-kindness-instead-of-overachieving/?tid=sm_fb To get into college, Harvard report advocates for kindness instead of overachieving], Retrieved January 20, 2016, "...Parents, educators and college administrators have long wrestled with the unintended negative side effects ... intense focus on personal achievement and the unfair advantages of more affluent students...."</ref>
===International applications=== Foreign (non-US citizen) students applying from another country form a large and growing percentage of applicants (including accepted applicants) to American universities.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.iie.org/Who-We-Are/News-and-Events/Press-Center/Press-Releases/2011/2011-11-14-Open-Doors-International-Students|title=International Student Enrollments Increase in 2010/11|publisher=|accessdate=September 29, 2014}}</ref> According to [[Phillips Academy|Andover]] counseling director Sean Logan, applications to American universities from foreign students have increased dramatically in the past decade.<ref name=tws3afa/> International applications are typically similar to domestic ones but with additional complications. Most international applicants do not receive a GPA score or transcript from their school.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thestudentroom.co.uk/wiki/Applying_to_the_United_States|title=Apply to uni in the USA – The Student Room – The Student Room|work=The Student Room|accessdate=September 29, 2014}}</ref> Most will not normally take SAT or ACT exams, so these must be arranged. Most American universities are happy to accept international and foreign qualifications such as the [[International Baccalaureate]] or ''IB'', or British [[A Levels]],<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/education/universityeducation/8796366/The-American-dream-How-to-apply-to-a-US-university.html | location=London | work=The Daily Telegraph | first1=Andrew | last1=Halls | title=The American dream: How to apply to a US university | date=September 29, 2011}}</ref> although it is often up to the applicant to elaborate on the meaning of these qualifications.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fulbright.org.uk/study-in-the-usa/undergraduate-study/applying/admissions-criteria#academics|title=US Admissions Criteria – Undergraduate Study in the USA – US-UK Fulbright Commission|publisher=|accessdate=September 29, 2014}}</ref> Non-native English speakers may be asked to provide English language qualifications. If a university requires or offers an interview, these can normally be conducted over the phone or with alumni residing in the applicant's country, according to ''[[Uni in the USA]]'',<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.uniintheusa.com/how-why/us-applications/1449/interviews|title=Study Abroad Grants – Study Abroad Funding – University In The USA|publisher=|accessdate=September 29, 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141225040629/http://www.uniintheusa.com/how-why/us-applications/1449/interviews|archivedate=December 25, 2014|df=mdy-all}}</ref> a guide book catering to the growing number of British students seeking to study in the United States.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/education/universityeducation/8810587/Why-study-in-the-US-could-be-a-bright-idea.html | location=London | work=The Daily Telegraph | first=Janette | last=Wallis | title=Why study in the US could be a bright idea | date=October 7, 2011}}</ref> International applicants often must cope with higher tuition fees and less available financial aid, although this varies significantly by college. Further, international applicants also have to apply for a student visa, which can be a complex and time-consuming process.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.intstudy.com/study-in-america/study-advice/apply-to-study-in-america |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2013-01-14 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130124222427/http://www.intstudy.com/study-in-america/study-advice/apply-to-study-in-america |archivedate=January 24, 2013 |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
International students contributed an estimated $35 billion to the United States economy.<ref>{{cite news |last=Hess |first=Abigail |url=https://www.cnbc.com/2017/08/09/why-students-are-choosing-to-go-to-college-in-canada-instead-of-the-us.html |title=Why students are choosing to go to college in Canada instead of the United States |work=[[CNBC]] |date=2017-08-09 |accessdate=2017-08-10 }}</ref>
==How colleges evaluate applicants== {| class="wikitable" style="float:right;" |+Factors having considerable importance |- !'''Factor''' !'''% Agree''' |- |align="left"|Grades in college prep courses |align="right"|83% |- |align="left"|Strength of curriculum |align="right"|66% |- |align="left"|Admission test scores |align="right"|59% |- |align="left"|Grades in all courses |align="right"|46% |- |align="left"|Essay or writing sample |align="right"|27% |- |align="left"|Student's demonstrated interest |align="right"|23% |- |align="left"|Class rank |align="right"|22% |- |align="left"|Counselor recommendation |align="right"|19% |- |align="left"|Teacher recommendation |align="right"|19% |- |align="left"|Subject test scores |align="right"|10% |- |align="left"|Interview |align="right"|9% |- |align="left"|Extracurricular activities |align="right"|7% |- |align="left"|Portfolio |align="right"|6% |- |align="left"|SAT II scores |align="right"|5% |- |align="left"|State graduation exam |align="right"|4% |- |align="left"|<small>Source: 2010 survey by [[National Association for College Admission Counseling|NACAC]]</small><ref name=twsLfjffhg>{{cite news |author= NACAC |title= Survey |work= Summit High School |quote= (from a handout by the SHS guidance department); note: percent is those colleges agreeing that each factor exerted "considerable importance" in their decision to admit students |year= 2010 }}</ref> |align="right"| |- |}
===Overview=== Colleges use a variety of methods to evaluate applicants. One source noted that four of every five colleges accept more than half of all applicants, and three-fourths of students who apply to colleges are accepted by their first choice college.{{sfn|Mamlet|2011|p=3}} Depending on the size and values of the school, admissions criteria can vary from being almost entirely formulaic to involving significant subjective judgment regarding the student's "fit" for the institution.<ref name=twsMay2Q84567/> Criteria vary considerably by school, and one view is that the "great deal of inconsistency across institutions" sometimes gave an incorrect impression that "student selection is arbitrary."<ref name=twsMay2Q84567/> Criteria include standardized test scores (generally [[ACT (test)|ACT]] and/or [[SAT]]), class rank, grades (as shown in the high school [[Transcript (education)|transcript]]), degree of extracurricular involvement, and leadership potential. One report suggested that the most important criteria, in order of importance, were # Grades in college preparatory courses # Strength of curriculum # Grades in all courses # Class rank<ref name=twsMayO112/> Many colleges also rely on personal essay(s) written by the applicant and letters of recommendation written by the applicant's teachers and [[guidance counselor]]. One principal benefit of the essay lies in its ability to further differentiate students who have perfect or near-perfect grades and test scores. Institutions place different weight on these criteria: for example, [[Liberal arts colleges in the United States#SAT optional movement|some schools]] do not require or even accept the [[SAT]]s for admission.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.unigo.com/get-to-college/college-search/test-optional-colleges-10-colleges-that-dont-require-sat-or-act-scores|title=10 colleges that don't require SAT or ACT scores|last=Unigo.com|first=Author:|date=2018-07-13|work=Unigo.com|access-date=2018-10-28}}</ref> It should be noted that some factors are beyond a student's control, such as a college's need in a given year for [[Affirmative action|diversity]], [[Legacy preferences|legacy applicants]], or [[Recruiting (college athletics)|athletic recruiting]].<ref name=twsL14/>
It is a complicated task for admissions staff at selective colleges to analyze and process thousands of applications with a "huge mail deluge" since there are often six pieces of mail for each applicant, including transcripts, letters of recommendation, and the application itself.{{sfn|Hernandez|2009|pp=104}} However, electronic transmission of documents has eased this burden at most colleges. Regardless, high volumes of applications mean that college admissions personnel spend less time on average reading each particular application; in 2009, the average admissions officer was responsible for analyzing 514 applications, and officers have experienced an upward trend in the number of applications they must read over time.<ref name=twsMayO112/> A typical college application receives only about 25 minutes of reading time, including three to five minutes for the personal essay if it is read.{{sfn|Dunbar|2007|p=6}} Advisors suggest that an understanding of the criteria can help an applicant apply to colleges with greater success. Some colleges extract information from the federal [[FAFSA]] financial aid form, including names of other schools the applicant is applying to.<ref name=twsZe25/> Counselors urge students and parents to understand what types of things colleges tend to look for in applications, and plan accordingly. A key attribute admissions evaluators look for, according to Mamlet and Vandevelde, is ''authenticity''—a real person who comes through the application, not a packaged artificial entity{{sfn|Mamlet|2011|p=15}} or distortion crafted to impress an admissions officer.<ref name=twsMay2R214/> An admissions officer at [[Vanderbilt University]] wrote about how their office evaluates applicants: "It's really about, 'What did I take advantage of in the environment I was given.'"<ref name=twsL14/> Several reports suggested that colleges were not looking for the "well-rounded kid"<ref name=twsL42>{{cite news |author= Jenny Anderson |title= For a Standout College Essay, Applicants Fill Their Summers |publisher= ''The New York Times'' |date= August 5, 2011 |url= https://www.nytimes.com/2011/08/06/nyregion/planning-summer-breaks-with-eye-on-college-essays.html?ref=admissions |accessdate= December 12, 2011 }}</ref> but rather a "well-rounded class":{{sfn|Mamlet|2011|p=71}}{{sfn|Dunbar|2007|p=42}}
{{Quote|Colleges are looking for ... the well-rounded class. Colleges put together their entering class as a mosaic: a few great scholars for each academic department; a handful of athletes; some musicians, dancers, and theater stars; a few for racial and economic diversity; some potential club leaders, etc. Colleges want a kid who is devoted to – and excels at – something. The word they most often use is passion.|Steve Cohen in ''The Washington Post'', 2011<ref name=twsL24/>}}
{{Quote|Colleges want students who have demonstrated through their actions an ability to see and connect with a world that is larger than they are.|Robin Mamlet and Christine Vandevelde, 2011{{sfn|Mamlet|2011|p=69}}}}
