Wisc-Mad. |align="left"|WI |align="right"|29008 |align="right"|54% |align="right"|54% |align="right"| |- |align="left"|Vanderbilt |align="left"|TN |align="right"|28335 |align="right"|13% |align="right"|25% |align="right"|12% |- |align="left"|Vassar |align="left"|NY |align="right"|7908 |align="right"|22% |align="right"|43% |align="right"|21% |- |align="left"|Wake Forest |align="left"|NC |align="right"|11366 |align="right"|32% |align="right"|43% |align="right"|31% |- |align="left"|Wash & Lee |align="left"|VA |align="right"|5970 |align="right"|18% |align="right"|40% |align="right"|15% |- |align="left"|Washington U |align="left"|MO |align="right"|28826 |align="right"|15% |align="right"|31% |align="right"|17% |- |align="left"|Wesleyan |align="left"|CT |align="right"|10503 |align="right"|20% |align="right"|45% |align="right"|18% |- |align="left"|William & M. |align="left"|VA |align="right"|13651 |align="right"|31% |align="right"|48% |align="right"|29% |- |align="left"|Williams |align="left"|MA |align="right"|7067 |align="right"|17% |align="right"| |align="right"| |- |align="left"|Yale |align="left"|CT |align="right"|28974 |align="right"|7% |align="right"|16% |align="right"|5% |- |} Results for admissions decisions for selected colleges are posted in the adjacent table.
====Statistical analysis==== There are numerous reports that colleges use proprietary mathematical algorithms as part of their process for evaluating applications. Some colleges hire statistical experts known as "enrollment consultants" to help them predict enrollment by developing [[computer model]]s to select applicants in such a way as to maximize [[Yield (college admissions)|yield]] and acceptance rates.<ref name=twsZe25/> Some of these models take into account factors such as an applicant's "zip code, religion, first-choice major and extracurricular interests, as well as academic performance".<ref name=twsZe25/> Colleges have been reported to have mathematical algorithms that recalculate an applicant's high school [[grade point average]] by weighing different course grades by factors such as perceived course difficulty and strength of high school curriculum. This helps the college come up with a revised GPA number for a student to compare against applicants from other schools. Furthermore, many colleges track how well other students from the same high school have done—that is, applicants from the same high school who attended or are attending the college—by comparing their high school grades against their college grades, and admissions officers use this data to try to estimate the likely college grade performance of a given applicant. Generally admissions departments do not reveal the particulars of such mathematical analyses. According to Michele Hernandez, Ivy League admissions departments compile an ''academic index'' based on three main factors: * Highest SAT Reasoning Math/Critical Reading score * Average of three highest SAT Subject tests * Converted rank score based on grades, class rank, and high school difficulty{{sfn|Hernandez|2009|pp=66–71}} In her view, two-thirds of this evaluation is based on tests, while only one third is based on grades, leading her to conclude at one point that grades were less important overall as a factor than test scores,{{sfn|Hernandez|2009|pp=66–71}} while in a different chapter she also suggested that the high school transcript information described roughly 60% of the college's perception of a student's academic performance.{{sfn|Hernandez|2009|pp=146}} Next, the composite ''academic index'' score was combined with an analysis of personal factors such as extracurricular activity or the essay, such that the academic factor was weighted 70% to 85% while the personal evaluation was weighted only 30% to 15%.{{sfn|Hernandez|2009|pp=66–71}} Generally the particulars of the mathematical formulas are not revealed to the public,{{sfn|Hernandez|2009|pp=66–71}} and different colleges have different formulas. Part of the purpose of algorithms is to expedite the handling of thousands of applications in a short amount of time. For example, at [[Dartmouth College]], data goes into a ''master card'' for each application, which leads to a ''ready sheet'', where readers summarize applications; then, an initial screening is done: top applications go directly to the director of admissions for approval while lackluster ones go to another director.{{sfn|Hernandez|2009|pp=110–111}} Dartmouth uses "A" for accept, "R" for reject, "P" for possible, with "P+" and "P-" being variants.{{sfn|Hernandez|2009|pp=110–111}} A committee might spend a week with the "P" ones, of which they only accept about a sixth, according to Hernandez.{{sfn|Hernandez|2009|pp=110–111}}
====Analysis of grades==== The consensus view is that high school grades are probably the single most important factor in winning admission.<ref name=twsL14/> Maintaining high grades is particularly important for the fall semester of twelfth grade, as well as winter grades if applying by regular admission,<ref name=twsL27/> and there is a report that colleges are paying greater attention to a student's grades throughout twelfth grade.<ref name=twsMayO112/> Particularly important is academic performance in core courses,{{sfn|Mamlet|2011|p=57}} and having a high grade point average based on good grades in AP-level or honors courses.<ref name=twsMay2R211/> Colleges evaluate applicants often by examining how a student has successfully exploited what a high school has had to offer.{{sfn|Mamlet|2011|p=41}}<ref>Note: quoting William Fitzsimmons, Dean of Admissions and Financial Aid at Harvard University.</ref> High school guidance counselor Erin Day of [[Summit High School (New Jersey)|Summit High School]] in [[New Jersey]] suggested that of the top five criteria for getting into college, having good grades were first, second, and third most important overall (test scores were fourth, extracurricular activities and essay were fifth).<ref>Note: from a speech given in October 2011</ref> An ideal academic record is one of increasingly better grades in courses of progressive difficulty.{{sfn|Mamlet|2011|p=53}} Hernandez wrote that colleges looked for patterns with both grades and test scores; high grades with low test scores suggested a hard-working student, but high test scores with low grades suggested a picture of a lazy student.{{sfn|Hernandez|2009|pp=146}} Ninth grade grades generally do not count much,<ref name=twsMay2R211/> but trends are important—an upward trend in grades was a positive factor, a decline a negative one.{{sfn|Hernandez|2009|pp=146}} Public universities are more likely to evaluate applicants based on grades and test scores alone, while private universities tend to be more "holistic" and consider other measures, according to one view.{{sfn|Mamlet|2011|p=13}}
==== ACT and SAT scores ==== The consensus view is that these are important, although Mamlet and VanDeVelde feel the scores "don't count as much as people think they do."<ref name=twsMay2R214/> There are many reports that admissions departments consider only the highest test results in different test subsections, sometimes called ''superscore'' results or ''superscoring'',<ref name=twsOctO2012uiuy>{{cite news |author= Peter Van Buskirk |title= 9 Testing Tips for College Applicants |newspaper= US News |quote= ... Keep the "superscore" in mind: At most colleges, admissions officers look at the best combination of scores. |date= June 9, 2010 |url= https://www.usnews.com/education/blogs/the-college-admissions-insider/2011/08/29/9-testing-tips-for-college-applicants |accessdate= October 15, 2012 }}</ref> so if a student takes a standardized test during multiple sittings, for example, admissions officers consider the highest math and verbal scores, regardless of test date.<ref name=twsOctO2012>{{cite news |author= Devon Keefe |title= Develop a Testing Strategy.(Kaplan)(presenting SAT Reasoning Test scores for college application) |newspaper= Newsweek via Highbeam Research |quote= Even many schools that have "opted out" of Score Choice have suggested that they will continue to "super score" students' test scores (i.e., take the highest sectional score from each test and combine them). |date= August 17, 2009 |url= http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-207214496.html |accessdate= October 15, 2012 }}</ref> Two sources in ''[[The Washington Post]]'' suggested that colleges routinely ''superscore'' the SAT test but rarely the ACT,<ref name=twsOctO2012sks>{{cite news |author= Valerie Strauss |title= Do colleges superscore ACT and SAT equally? |newspaper= The Washington Post |quote= ... most schools superscore both the ACT and the SAT. While many schools do, many more do so for the SAT than the ACT. |date= June 9, 2010 |url= http://voices.washingtonpost.com/answer-sheet/sat-and-act/superscoring-act-vs-sat.html |accessdate= October 15, 2012 }}</ref> possibly because of difficulty processing five separate rounded numbers.<ref name=twsOctO2012fjs>{{cite news |author= Daniel de Vise |title= College, Inc. |newspaper= The Washington Post |quote= Not many superscore the ACT, because they'd have to work with five separate numbers, including a composite that often has been rounded up or rounded down ... |date= February 8, 2012 |url= https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/college-inc/post/guest-post-calculator-shopping-the-night-before-the-sat/2012/02/08/gIQAoVc0yQ_blog.html |accessdate= October 15, 2012 }}</ref>
==== Rigor of high school courses ==== [[File:Analysis of high school applicants.png|thumb|Analysis of high school applicants]]
A consensus view is that taking rigorous high school courses is a plus.<ref name=twsMay2S213/> Guidance counselors report that admissions personnel take a student's course of study into serious consideration when evaluating applications.<ref name=twsL14>{{cite news |author= Carolyn Butler |title= Follow 7 Strategies to Get Into College: To stand out in the admissions game, prepare early and use common sense |publisher= ''US News'' |date= September 13, 2011 |url= https://www.usnews.com/education/best-colleges/articles/2011/09/13/follow-7-strategies-to-get-into-college?PageNr=2 |accessdate= December 12, 2011 }}</ref><ref name=twsL23/> Admissions officers construct a high school profile and take into account such data as curriculum offerings, demographics, and grade distributions at the high school.<ref name=twsL14/> One adviser suggested taking the hardest courses that there were, and that the worst thing, in terms of evaluations, was to drop a hard course.{{sfn|Hernandez|2009|pp=139}}
===Personal evaluation===
====Athletic ability==== [[File:BenhabernHS.jpg|thumb|left|110px|Athletes in popular sports such as [[American football|football]] are recruited by colleges hoping to improve their athletic programs.]]
A survey of admissions officers revealed that 28% agreed that their school had accepted athletes despite having lower grades and test scores than others.<ref name=twsL22/> A survey by the ''[[Atlanta Journal-Constitution]]'' found that schools with strong athletics departments tended to have athletes with lower [[SAT]] scores than non-athletic students.<ref name=twsL25/> Athletes get better treatment even at elite colleges, according to one academic study.<ref name=twsL25/> A report suggested that some applications by athletes go first to a special committee for review by coaches, who may then, in turn, advocate for particular players.<ref name=tws2ZG315/> Recruited athletes who play in-demand or "revenue" sports (i.e. generate ticket sales) such as [[American football|football]]<ref name=tws2T19>{{cite news |agency= Associated Press |title= Athletes get break on college admission standards |work= Charleston Daily Mail |quote= ... A review of admissions data submitted to the NCAA by most of the 120 schools in college footballs top tier shows that athletes enjoy strikingly better odds of having admission requirements bent on their behalf. ... |date= December 31, 2009 |url= http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P2-21070487.html |accessdate= August 20, 2012 }}</ref> or [[basketball]] can have a "significantly greater advantage in admissions" than others.<ref name=twsL37/>{{sfn|Dunbar|2007|p=155}} Some Ivy League coaches, seeking to improve the average academic performance of their teams, would admit mediocre athletes with top academic skills as a means to balance out the stellar athletes with below-average academic ability. To fix this "average score" arrangement in which there had been a temptation to admit an extremely poor student with great athletic ability, many schools went to a ''banding'' arrangement. For example, coaches would consider all wrestling applicants within a specified range or ''band'' of academic performance, and coaches could admit more wrestler-applicants who showed greater scholastic promise.<ref name=twsMay2Chuuy>{{cite news |author1=Steve Cohen |author2=Anne Dwane |author3=Paulo de Oliveira |author4=Michael Muska |title= Getting In! The Zinch Guide to College Admissions |publisher= Wiley Publishing |quote= (see page 197) |year= 2011 |url= https://books.google.com/books?id=MKQOs-pXjA4C&pg=PA197&lpg=PA197&dq=%22banding%22+%22college+admissions%22&source=bl&ots=cvCC9OD8qJ&sig=WmOiJ1Qq3PzxPxjhH9hYKCwneaE&hl=en&sa=X&ei=EfKiT82wNcX06AGOs6ndCA&ved=0CDsQ6AEwAQ#v=onepage&q=%22banding%22%20%22college%20admissions%22&f=false |accessdate= May 3, 2012 }}</ref> Howard and Matthew Greene report that coaches do not make admissions decisions, but they can advocate for a particular applicant.<ref name=twsMay2S213/> And they report that committed athletes should explain in their applications how much time they have used towards perfecting their athletic ability:
{{Quote|We often talk with highly involved athletes who have little time for other activities outside of their sports. In many cases their grades suffer. Most student-athletes are not "recruited" to colleges, but colleges will respect their commitment and drive.|Howard and Matthew Greene, 2003<ref name=twsMay2S213/>}}
====Particular skills==== Some colleges are more likely to admit students with in-demand skills, such as writing, debating, theater management, science competitions, organizational skills, musical skills, and so forth.{{sfn|Dunbar|2007|p=155}}
====Personal initiative==== [[File:David Hogg at the Rally to Support Firearm Safety Legislation in Fort Lauderdale.jpg|thumb|right|Parkland student activist [[David Hogg (activist)|David Hogg]] demonstrated initiative in helping to organize and lead the [[Never Again MSD]] student-led campaign against [[Gun violence in the United States|gun violence]] yet his applications were still rejected by four California schools: [[UCLA]], [[UCSD]], [[UCSB]] and [[University of California, Irvine|UC Irvine]].<ref name=twsMercury444>Mercury News, Pueng Vongs, March 27, 2018, [https://www.mercurynews.com/2018/03/27/uc-schools-reject-march-for-our-lives-leader-david-hogg/ UC schools reject March For Our Lives leader David Hogg], Retrieved March 30, 2018</ref>]]
Admissions personnel look favorably on applications where it is clear that the student, himself or herself, appears to be firmly in control over the whole application process; the appearance of pushy parents or coaching can have a dampening effect. Ideally it is best if the student, himself or herself, is in charge of organizing the college search and decision-making process; the "student must be in the driver's seat".{{sfn|Mamlet|2011|p=9}} One admissions dean explained:{{sfn|Mamlet|2011|p=42}} And admissions officers are turned off by "micromanaging parents".<ref name=twsMay2Pfjk/>
:{{Quote|Students who really manage the show on their own, fill out the application on their own, make their own appointments for interviews, correspond with you on their own email account – these students get extra points because they're managing their lives.|Jennifer Delahunty, Admissions Dean at [[Kenyon College|Kenyon]]{{sfn|Mamlet|2011|p=42}}}}
====Demonstrated interest==== This can be an important factor in some situations, sometimes a "driving factor",<ref name=tws3afa>{{cite news |author = Sally Holm (interviewer) Sean Logan (interviewee) |title = Inside College Counseling with Director Sean Logan |work = Andover Magazine |date = Winter 2013 |url = https://www.andover.edu/About/Newsroom/TheMagazine/Documents/AndoverMagSeanLogan.pdf |accessdate = February 24, 2013 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20150510172036/https://www.andover.edu/About/Newsroom/TheMagazine/Documents/AndoverMagSeanLogan.pdf |archivedate = May 10, 2015 |df = mdy-all }}</ref> since a college may be more likely to say yes to a student likely to matriculate. Accordingly, it has been advised to become knowledgeable about schools being applied to, and "tailor each application accordingly."<ref name=twsL27/> College visits (including overnight ones),{{sfn|Mamlet|2011|p=121}} interviews, attending College Fair days,{{sfn|Mamlet|2011|p=121}} comments in the essay, contacting college faculty members, answering and opening emails,{{sfn|Mamlet|2011|p=121}}<ref>Note: colleges can tell whether emails are opened or not by a prospective student.</ref> place position of the college on the FAFSA form or its [[FAFSA position]],<ref name=Rivard/><ref name=CBSNews1/><ref name=DailyFinance/><ref>Note: admissions officers can see all colleges applied to that are listed on the FAFSA form, and there are reports that some colleges interpret being first or second on the FAFSA list as a sign of demonstrated interest</ref> and other indications of interest can be a factor for many colleges concerned about their [[Yield (college admissions)|yield]]—the percent of students who accept an offer of enrollment.<ref name=tws2ZG315/><ref name=twsZe25/> According to Andover's college counseling director Sean Logan, it is important to have numerous contact points with colleges to show demonstrated interest: visiting, phone contact, emailing, visits to websites (including number of clicks as well as length of time on the website), whether a college visit included a tour and interview, and whether a college-recommended off-campus personal interview was done.<ref name=tws3afa/> Schools such as [[Connecticut College]] and [[Emory University]] have been credited as "popularizing the yield game" by refusing well-qualified students who failed to show much real interest in attending, as a way to boost their yield scores.<ref name=twsZe25/> One top high school student was waitlisted at a "likely" college<ref>Note: "likely" meant there was an estimated 80% chance of acceptance by the college</ref> for showing lack of interest:
{{Quote|We assumed they weren't coming, because we didn't have much contact from them. We know they're probably using us as a back-up and they haven't done much to show any sincere interest, so we decided to waitlist them.|Andover college counseling director Sean Logan, remembering a comment from a college admissions director.<ref name=tws3afa/>}}
====Active participation==== [[File:Students wrestling 05.jpg|thumb|alt=Two wrestlers.|Students with special skills such as [[wrestling]] may be given preferential treatment.]]
One report suggested that colleges seek students who will be actively involved on campus and not spend every day studying alone.{{sfn|Dunbar|2007|p=55}} As a result, they look for high school teacher recommendations that suggest active classroom participation, students who speak up in class, who ask questions.{{sfn|Dunbar|2007|p=56, 57}}
====Weeding out problem people==== Admissions tries to screen out difficult people.{{sfn|Dunbar|2007|pp=69–82}} According to Dunbar, many colleges are "afraid of aggression." He recommends avoiding "harsh humor" or signs of severe emotion, anger, or aggression.{{sfn|Dunbar|2007|pp=69–82}} Admissions evaluators look for signals that might indicate a difficult person, such as nonconstructive or disrespectful criticisms of others, or evidence of [[substance abuse]].{{sfn|Dunbar|2007|pp=69–82}} Colleges try to weed out dependent people who either follow their parents too closely, or do only what the "cool kids" do. Dunbar advised that "parental control of any kind, if detected, can be very damaging," and advised that students should not appear to be controlled by parental whims.{{sfn|Dunbar|2007|pp=97–109}}
====Analysis of essays==== [[File:BakerLibrary.jpg|thumb|alt=Picture of a college building with steeple.|[[Dartmouth College]] admissions, according to Michele Hernandez, spends a week examining the ''possibles'' or Ps, and after much deliberation, accepts perhaps a sixth of them.]]
Michele Hernandez suggested that almost all admissions essays were weak, cliche-ridden, and "not worth reading".{{sfn|Hernandez|2009|pp=130–136}}<ref>An admissions staffer at Gettysburg College (who requested to remain anonymous) agreed most application essays were boring.</ref> The staff gets thousands of essays and have to wade through most of them.{{sfn|Hernandez|2009|pp=130–131}} When she worked as an admissions director at Dartmouth, she noticed that most essays were only read for three minutes.{{sfn|Hernandez|2009|pp=130–136}} Some too-common essay types were the "outward bound" essay about how a person discovered their inner grit while hiking tough mountains, or the "community service" essay about how a student discovered, while working among disadvantaged peoples, that "all persons were the same".{{sfn|Hernandez|2009|pp=130–136}} Admissions officers seek to learn how a person thinks, what kind of person they are, and their level of intellectual promise.{{sfn|Hernandez|2009|pp=130–136}} Essays are generally important only in borderline cases.{{sfn|Hernandez|2009|pp=130–131}}
===Other factors=== One report was that at [[Ivy League]] universities, 40% of students were so-called "special cases" including student-athletes, minorities, low-income, legacies, and development cases, and that admissions standards were typically lowered for these groups.<ref name=tws2ZG315/>
====Ability to pay==== While there is general agreement that chances for admission are higher for students who are prepared to pay the full price, there are indications that this has been even more prevalent in the past few years given economic uncertainty and rising college costs,<ref name=twsL32>{{cite news |author= Kate Zernike |title= Paying in Full as the Ticket Into Colleges |publisher= ''The New York Times'' |date= March 30, 2009 |url= https://www.nytimes.com/2009/03/31/education/31college.html?adxnnl=1&ref=admissions&adxnnlx=1323736058-Eaz0sOFgvQqaLKkSLqo30g |accessdate= December 12, 2011 }}</ref> particularly at schools without large endowments. Half of admissions officers at both public universities and a third of officers at four-year colleges were actively seeking students who could "pay full price" and did not need financial aid, according to one survey of 462 admissions directors and managers in 2011.<ref name=twsL21>{{cite news |author= Tamar Lewin |title= Universities Seeking Out Students of Means |publisher= ''The New York Times'' |date= September 21, 2011 |url= https://www.nytimes.com/2011/09/21/education/21admissions.html |accessdate= December 12, 2011 }}</ref> The report suggested that full-pay students tended to have lower high school grades and test scores than other students, compared to other applicants, on average.<ref name=twsL21/> Two other reports confirmed that public university admissions officers were actively seeking out-of-state and international students since they paid higher rates for tuition.<ref name=twsL22>{{cite news |author= Eyder Peralta |title= Survey: Universities Increasingly Admitting Students Based On Wealth |publisher= ''NPR'' |date= September 21, 2011 |url= https://www.npr.org/blogs/thetwo-way/2011/09/21/140681011/survey-universities-increasingly-admitting-students-based-on-wealth |accessdate= December 12, 2011 }}</ref><ref name=twsL21/> Another report found that one in ten admissions officers had said that their college admitted full-pay students despite their having lower average grades and test scores.<ref name=twsL22/> Reports vary about whether the financial neediness of applicants impacts admissions chances; one suggested that applicants with strong academic credentials or talents are more likely to get financial aid, but that depending on the college, "borderline admits" needing money were most vulnerable;<ref name=twsMay2R115/> a second report was that "colleges like rich students".<ref name=twsMay2R115>{{cite news |author= Stacey Kostell |title= Does Financial Need Impact College Admissions Chances? |newspaper= US News |date= November 23, 2011 |url= https://www.usnews.com/education/blogs/college-admissions-experts/2011/11/23/does-financial-need-impact-college-admissions-chances |accessdate= May 18, 2012 }}</ref> [[George Washington University]], despite claiming to have [[need blind admissions]], was more likely to waitlist financially needy applicants, according to one report.<ref>[[Jeremy Diamond (journalist)|Jeremy Diamond]], Sarah Ferris, October 21, 2013, The GW Hatchet, [http://www.gwhatchet.com/2013/10/21/gw-misrepresented-admissions-and-financial-aid-policy-for-years/ GW misrepresented admissions and financial aid policy for years], Accessed December 13, 2013, "... Administrators now say the admissions process has always factored in financial need. But that contradicts messaging from the admissions and financial aid offices that, as recently as Saturday, have regularly attested that the University remained need-blind ..."</ref> One view was that financial aid depends on how a specific student compares with other students:
{{Quote|What this means is that your financial aid package from a reach college may not be as attractive as the package from one of your target, or well matched, colleges. If you are looking for generous scholarship aid, you need to look at colleges and universities where your academic profile is strong compared to that of the average admitted student.|Hannah Serota, college counselor<ref name=twsMay2R115/>}}
By contrast, other schools practice [[need-blind admission]], such as Ivy League Universities, but there are exceptions. A report in ''[[The New York Times]]'' suggested that [[Donald Trump|Trump]] advisor and son-in-law [[Jared Kushner]] gained admission to [[Harvard University|Harvard]] after his father promised a $2.5 million gift.<ref name=twsNYT484848>The New York Times, November 20, 2016, [https://www.nytimes.com/2016/11/20/us/politics/jared-kushner-donald-trump.html?hp&action=click&pgtype=Homepage&clickSource=story-heading&module=b-lede-package-region&region=top-news&WT.nav=top-news The In-law in the Trump Inner Circle: Jared Kushner's steadying hand], Retrieved November 20, 2016</ref>
====Geographic diversity==== One view was that state schools strive to admit students from "all parts of a state,"<ref name=twsL25/> which suggests that applicants who live farther away from a given school had a better chance of admission. But a contrary view was that geographic location of the applicant matters perhaps only slightly, if at all; Hernandez looked at acceptance ratios to Dartmouth for different geographic locations, and found that geographic distance was not a factor influencing admittances.{{sfn|Hernandez|2009|pp=209–210}}
====Race and ethnicity==== {{POV section|date=July 2018}}
[[File:Kennelly Commons.JPG|thumb|alt=Outdoors with people.|Students at the Commons at [[Green River Community College]] in [[Washington (state)|Washington]].]] {{see also|Grutter v. Bollinger|Fisher v. University of Texas (2013)|Fisher v. University of Texas (2016)}}
A survey of admissions personnel suggested that two-fifths had said ''yes'' to applicants from minorities despite having lower grades and test scores than other applicants, on average.<ref name=twsL22/> At the same time, rulings by the [[Supreme Court of the United States|Supreme Court]] have upheld the use of race as one factor among many in college admissions as long as it is not an overriding factor.<ref name=twsL25/><ref name=twsMay2R111>{{cite news |author= Claudio Sanchez |title= Case Renews Focus On Race In College Admissions |newspaper= NPR |date= March 1, 2012 |url= https://www.npr.org/2012/03/01/147663617/case-renews-focus-on-race-in-college-admissions |accessdate= May 18, 2012 }}</ref><ref name=twsMay2R112>{{cite news |author= Valerie Strauss |title= College admissions: How diversity factors in |newspaper= Washington Post |date= February 22, 2012 |url= https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/answer-sheet/post/college-admissions-how-diversity-factors-in/2012/02/20/gIQAs0BHSR_blog.html |accessdate= May 18, 2012 }}</ref><ref>Pete Williams and Erin McClam, NBC News, June 24, 2013, [http://usnews.nbcnews.com/_news/2013/06/24/19115041-supreme-court-raises-bar-for-affirmative-action-in-college-admissions?lite Supreme Court raises bar for affirmative action in college admissions], Accessed December 31, 2013, "... it amounts to a warning to colleges nationwide that the courts will treat race-conscious admissions policies with a high degree of skepticism ..."</ref> A report suggested minority students have a better chance overall at selective colleges.<ref name=tws2ZG315/> In the case of multiracial students, they have a choice of which box to check since it may be perceived either as "gamesmanship" or reflecting one's racial makeup.<ref name=twsL43>{{cite news |author1=Susan Saulny |author2=Jacques Steinberg |title= Mixed-Race Students Wonder How Many Boxes to Check |publisher= ''The New York Times'' |date= June 13, 2011 |url= https://www.nytimes.com/2011/06/14/us/14students.html?ref=admissions |accessdate= December 12, 2011 }}</ref> Some Asian-Americans have felt loathe to describe themselves as ''Asian'', or to reveal information about their ethnic background, on the supposition that college admissions departments [[Discrimination|discriminate]] against them because of their ethnicity and consider them incorrectly to be "boring academic robots", according to several reports.<ref name=tws2ZG315>{{cite news |author= Kathleen Kingsbury |title= Dirty Secrets of College Admissions |work= The Daily Beast |date= January 9, 2009 |url= http://www.thedailybeast.com/articles/2009/01/09/dirty-secrets-of-college-admissions.html |accessdate= July 7, 2012 }}</ref><ref name=twsL11>{{cite news |agency= Associated Press |title= Some Asians' college strategy: Don't check 'Asian' |publisher= ''USA Today'' |date= December 4, 2011 |url= https://www.usatoday.com/news/education/story/2011-12-03/asian-students-college-applications/51620236/1 |accessdate= December 12, 2011 }}</ref> Typically, Asian applicants require a SAT score 140 points above that of a comparable white student, and considerably higher than that of a non-Asian minority, to have a similar chance of admission.<ref name=twsMayO215/><ref>{{cite news |title= Do colleges redline Asian-Americans? |author= Kara Miller |publisher= ''Boston Globe'' |date= February 8, 2010 |url= http://www.boston.com/bostonglobe/editorial_opinion/oped/articles/2010/02/08/do_colleges_redline_asian_americans/ |accessdate= January 2, 2011}}</ref><ref name=twsNYT8997>Andrew Lam, January 30, 2017, The New York Times, [https://www.nytimes.com/2017/01/30/opinion/white-students-unfair-advantage-in-admissions.html?em_pos=small&emc=edit_ty_20170130&nl=opinion-today&nl_art=13&nlid=76434108&ref=headline&te=1&_r=0 White Students' Unfair Advantage in Admissions], Retrieved January 31, 2017, "...There's ample evidence that Asian-Americans are at a disadvantage in college admissions..."</ref> Asians get a "raw deal" in Ivy admissions, according to Hernandez, and have to be much better students than the typical white applicant to be admitted.{{sfn|Hernandez|2009|pp=201}} She wrote that it benefits an applicant to be [[African American]], [[Latino (demonym)|Latino]], or [[Native Americans in the United States|Native American]], since colleges can advertise their diversity as a result.{{sfn|Hernandez|2009|pp=118}} The admissions practices of [[Harvard University|Harvard]] and [[Princeton University|Princeton]] were investigated for possible discrimination against Asian-American applicants by the Department of Education's [[Office for Civil Rights]].<ref name=twsMayO215>{{cite news |author= Daniel E. Slotnik |title= Do Asian-Americans Face Bias in Admissions at Elite Colleges? |newspaper= The New York Times |date= February 8, 2012 |url= http://thechoice.blogs.nytimes.com/2012/02/08/do-asian-americans-face-bias-in-admissions-at-elite-colleges/ |accessdate= May 15, 2012 }}</ref>
On July 3, 2018, the Education and Justice Departments under US President Donald Trump rescinded affirmative action policies which encouraged college and university diversity by evaluating the race factor during the admission process.<ref>https://abcnews.go.com/Politics/trump-administration-dials-back-obama-era-affirmative-action/story?id=56347886</ref><ref>https://www.nytimes.com/2018/07/03/us/politics/trump-affirmative-action-race-schools.html</ref><ref>http://www.chicagotribune.com/news/nationworld/politics/ct-trump-college-admissions-race-20180703-story.html</ref> The two policies rescinded were written in 2011 and 2016 and were enforced by both Departments.<ref>https://slate.com/news-and-politics/2018/07/affirmative-action-trump-rolling-back-obama-guidelines-race-college-admissions-process.html</ref>
====Legacy applicants==== {{main|Legacy preferences}} There are differing views about how important it is to have a family member or relative who also attended a college. It is clear that it is a factor; one report suggested that having a family member who is an alumnus gives "a leg up" for applicants.<ref name=twsL25/>{{sfn|Hernandez|2009|pp=121–122}} One report suggested that siblings do not count as legacies.{{sfn|Hernandez|2009|pp=121–122}} In some cases, a parent's attendance at a related graduate school counts as a legacy, but most colleges do not count this.{{sfn|Hernandez|2009|pp=121–122}} Many selective private colleges have a higher admit rate for alumni children as a way to "keep the larger set of alumni happy and giving", and being a legacy applicant can mean as much as "100 or 200 points on the SAT".<ref name=tws2T25>{{cite news |author= Neal Conan |title= Analysis: College admissions and legacies |work= NPR Talk of the Nation (via Highbeam Research) |quote= ... it can mean as much as 100 or 200 points on the SATs, ... |date= January 15, 2004 |url= http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P1-89438132.html |accessdate= August 20, 2012 }}</ref>
Legacy admissions have had a history of controversy; [[economist]] Peter Sacks criticized the practice of legacy admissions as a "social reproduction process" in which "elite institutions have an implicit bargain with their alumni ... 'You give us money, and we will move your kid to the front of the line.'"<ref name=twsL37>{{cite news |author= Rebecca R. Ruiz |title= Debating Legacy Preferences in Admissions |publisher= ''The New York Times'' |date= November 15, 2011 |url= http://thechoice.blogs.nytimes.com/2011/11/15/legacy-admissions/?ref=admissions |accessdate= December 12, 2011 }}</ref> Another agreed that legacies perpetuated a "hereditary aristocracy".<ref name=tws2T25/> But an opposing view is that all colleges, to varying extents, make choices as part of the admissions process, including state schools that charge in-state residents (with taxpaying parents) a lower rate than out-of-state residents, and it was argued that there was not really much difference between taxpaying parents contributing to a state school as well as generous alumni contributing to a private school—both with the possibility that it will help their offspring get into college.<ref name=twsL37/> Consultant Donald Dunbar suggested that admitting legacies encourages future donations, and in turn these incoming money flows help the school subsidize the education of more minority students;{{sfn|Dunbar|2007|p=166}} another source suggested that alumni gifts was important in helping a college pay for need-blind programs.<ref name=tws2T25/> Legacy admissions was criticized by Daniel Golden in his book ''The Price of Admission'' in which elite schools gave "heavy preferences to the wealthy", according to essayist Neal Gabler in the ''[[Boston Globe]]''.<ref name=twsMay2R113/>
====Family wealth==== {{main|Development case}} In certain cases, family wealth of applicants is considered, based on potential to make a substantial donation<ref name=tws2ZG315/> to the school (above and beyond paying tuition, and separate from considerations such as ability or fame). Such candidates are known as [[development case]]s, and are intended to bolster the finances of the university, especially to its further mission. The practice is not widely discussed by universities that use it, but is reported to be used by a number of top-ranked schools, Ivy League and otherwise, and has been associated with [[Duke University]] (which acknowledges its use) and [[Brown University]] (which does not comment), especially since the 1980s.<ref name="golden">{{Cite news | issn = 0099-9660 | last = Golden | first = Daniel | authorlink = Daniel Golden | title = How Lowering the Bar Helps Colleges Prosper | work = Wall Street Journal | accessdate = June 10, 2012 | date = September 9, 2006 | url = https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB115774251817757837 }}</ref>
====Personal connections==== Counselors and admissions directors tend to agree that in a few selected cases, connections were important. A report based on a survey of admissions directors suggested that "whom you know does matter", since higher-level administrators and prominent alumni and trustees can exert pressure on the admissions departments to admit certain applicants.<ref name=twsL21/>
===Other considerations=== There was a report that more colleges are resorting to computerized fact-checking software, as well as anti-plagiarism tools such as [[Turnitin]], which checks documents for unoriginal content on the web,<ref name=twsMayO112/> possibly as a response to well-publicized scandals in which a student won admission to Harvard University by fraudulent means.<ref name=twsMayO113>{{cite news |author1=Jacques Steinberg |author2=Katie Zezima |title= Campuses Ensnared by 'Life of Deception' |newspaper= The New York Times |date= May 18, 2010 |url= https://www.nytimes.com/2010/05/19/education/19harvard.html?pagewanted=all |accessdate= May 15, 2012 }}</ref> Supplementary materials generally carry "no weight" in college admissions, according to one view.<ref name=twsMay2Q848/> A report in ''[[Time Magazine]]'' suggested that many elite colleges used a vaguer measure of ''institutional fit'' to decide who is admitted, which is based on nonacademic qualities and may favor "underrepresented minorities and students who demonstrate exceptional talent."<ref name=twsMay2Q84567>{{cite news |author= Kayla Webley |title= How Colleges Really Make Admissions Decisions |newspaper= Time Magazine |date= April 12, 2012 |url= http://newsfeed.time.com/2012/04/12/how-colleges-really-make-admissions-decisions/ |accessdate= May 17, 2012 }}</ref> Students who take a "gap year" between high school and college can benefit if the year was enriching and developing and helped the student mature.<ref name=twsMay2S213/>
==Acceptances and rejections== [[File:Lafayette College admissions department waitlist letter.jpg|thumb|Colleges use waitlists to hedge their bets, uncertain about how many accepted students will say yes, and to draw applicants from the waitlist when vacancies open. In addition, waitlists allow colleges to target acceptance letters to students likely to attend to maintain the college's selectivity ranking and [[Yield (college admissions)|yield]].]]
===Notifications=== Students are usually notified of a college's decision in April, sometimes in the last two weeks of March, unless they had applied using an early approach, and are usually notified by email,{{sfn|Mamlet|2011|p=9}} although some colleges still send "fat" envelopes (usually an acceptance) or "thin" envelopes (usually a rejection). A trend appears to be declining percentages of acceptances to leading schools.<ref name=twsMayO114>{{cite news |author= Blake Ellis |title= Harvard, Princeton post record low acceptance rates |newspaper= CNN Money |date= March 30, 2012 |url= http://money.cnn.com/2012/03/30/pf/college/acceptance_rates_ivy_league/index.htm |accessdate= May 15, 2012 }}</ref> There are indications that the percentage of students who say "yes" to an offer of admission (the [[Yield (college admissions)|yield]]) has been declining, from 49 percent in 2001 to 43 percent in 2009.<ref name=tws2P315/> Admitted students may also be awarded financial aid. There are two kinds of financial aid: need-based aid, awarded entirely on the financial specifics of the student's family, and merit-based aid, given to students judged to show exceptional academic promise. Several reports confirm that accepted students who are dissatisfied with an aid offer should contact the college to see if the offer can be improved.<ref name=twsMay2Q848/><ref name=tws3L111/> International students who have been accepted should complete an [[I-20 (form)|I-20]] form.<ref name=twsMayO214>{{cite news |author= Tanya Caldwell |title= For International Students, a College Admissions Checklist for April |newspaper= The New York Times |date= April 6, 2012 |url= http://thechoice.blogs.nytimes.com/2012/04/06/for-international-students-a-college-admissions-checklist-for-april/ |accessdate= May 15, 2012 }}</ref> A disappointing aid package may be appealed with a polite call to the school's financial aid office, while being thankful for any funds that have already been offered.<ref name=tws3L111/> In some cases, it is possible to bargain with a school for a more generous aid package, particularly if there is a more generous offer from a second school that the first school sees as a competitor. One report suggested that even by May 2012, 375 colleges still had space for first-year or transfer applicants for the fall of 2012.<ref name=twsMay2Q944>{{cite news |author= Tanya Caldwell |title= Many Colleges Are Still Taking Applications for the Fall |newspaper= The New York Times |date= May 3, 2012 |url= http://thechoice.blogs.nytimes.com/2012/05/03/nacac-space-availability-survey/ |accessdate= May 17, 2012 }}</ref> Twelfth graders accepted to college are expected to maintain good grades during the spring; for example, one hundred high school applicants accepted to [[Texas Christian University]], whose grades plummeted in the spring of their twelfth grade as a symptom of [[senioritis]], received so-called "fear of God" letters from an admissions dean asking them to explain themselves, and threatening to rescind offers of admission.<ref name=tws2V115>{{cite news |author= Tanya Caldwell |title= University Sends 'Fear of God' Letter to Students With Senioritis |work= The New York Times |quote= College-bound seniors beware: ... failing grades ... your university may soon threaten to rescind your admission ... |date= June 18, 2012 |url= http://thechoice.blogs.nytimes.com/2012/06/18/university-sends-fear-of-god-letter-to-students-with-senioritis/ |accessdate= June 22, 2012 }}</ref>
===Wait list considerations=== About half of colleges use a wait list, particularly those that accept fewer than half of all applications.<ref name=twsMayO211/><ref name=tws3JanN113/><ref>Note: figure for Fall 2010 admission cycle was 48% of colleges using wait lists.</ref> Since students on average tend to be sending out more applications, colleges have been having a tougher time knowing for certain whether the students to whom they have offered admission will, in fact, attend in the fall. Some of the uncertainty is related to the phenomenon of students applying to more and more schools, sometimes 15 or more, to increase their chances in a statistical sense, but this adds a new layer of guesswork for colleges trying to predict how many accepted students will say yes,<ref name=twsL31/> and puts waitlisted students in "limbo"<ref name=twsZe21>{{cite news |author= Lynn O'Shaughnessy |title= Getting Off a College Wait List: 5 Things to Do Now |publisher= ''CBS News'' |date= April 9, 2010 |url= http://www.cbsnews.com/8301-505145_162-37241846/getting-off-a-college-wait-list-5-things-to-do-now/ |accessdate= December 31, 2011 }}</ref> or the "basic equivalent of purgatory," according to ''[[US News]]''.<ref name=twsZe19>{{cite news |author= Zach Miners |title= You've Been Put on the Wait List for College. Now What? |publisher= ''US News'' |date= April 9, 2010 |url= https://www.usnews.com/education/best-colleges/right-school/timeline/articles/2010/04/09/youve-been-put-on-the-wait-list-for-college-now-what |accessdate= December 31, 2011 }}</ref> In addition, many colleges lose some students due to a phenomenon sometimes called ''[[summer melt]]'',<ref name=twsL17>{{cite news |author= Scott Jaschik |title= The Other 'Summer Melt' in Admissions |publisher= ''Inside Higher Ed'' |date= April 4, 2011 |url= http://www.insidehighered.com/news/2011/04/04/new_research_points_to_a_summer_melt_issue_for_low_income_students |accessdate= December 12, 2011 }}</ref> meaning that some students, even ones who have sent in a deposit, will not show up in the fall, and melt away, and this "melt percentage" can be as high as 5% to 10% of persons who have paid a deposit.
{{Quote|The admission process is a complicated dance of supply and demand for colleges. And this spring, many institutions have accepted fewer applicants, and placed more on waiting lists, until it becomes clear over the next few weeks how many spots remain.|Jacques Steinberg in ''The New York Times'', April 2010<ref name=twsL31/>}}
As a result, colleges use wait lists as a hedge to make sure they have enough students in the fall. Some schools "under-invite" applicants in the regular admissions season to appear highly selective and then about-face and accept them from their wait lists later.<ref name=twsMayO111/> One report is that [[Vanderbilt University|Vanderbilt]] gets a tenth of their first-year class from the wait list.<ref name=twsMayO111/> But it varies from college to college and from year to year. For example, in 2010 [[Stanford University|Stanford]] and [[Yale University|Yale]] wait-listed 1,000 students while [[Duke University|Duke]] wait-listed 3,000 students.<ref name=twsZe21/> Overall, one survey suggested that 30% of wait-listed students are eventually accepted,<ref name=twsZe21/> but this is an average figure for all wait-listed students, and the percentage is dramatically lower at elite or prestigious schools. There is a report suggesting that in recent years, the lists are more fluid than in previous years, in the sense that there is more wait list activity—which have become more of a safety net for colleges rather than students.<ref name=twsL25/> Estimates vary about how many college applicants find themselves on a wait list; one report was that 10% of applicants were wait-listed.<ref name="twsZe19"/>
{| class="wikitable sortable" style="float:right;" |- |+Average yields and wait list acceptances<br>for selected schools 2009–2010<br>Sources and notes:<ref name=twsZe23>{{cite news |author= Jacques Steinberg |title= The Early Line on Admission Yields (and Wait-List Offers) |publisher= ''The New York Times'' |date= May 12, 2010 |url= http://thechoice.blogs.nytimes.com/2010/05/12/yield-3/ |accessdate= December 31, 2011 }}</ref><ref name=twsZe24>{{cite news |author= The Daily News Staff |title= Stanford yield rate may be highest ever |publisher= ''The Stanford Daily'' |date= May 7, 2010 |url= http://www.stanforddaily.com/2010/05/07/stanford-yield-rate-may-be-highest-ever/ |accessdate= December 31, 2011 }}</ref><ref name=twsZe22>{{cite news |author= Tracy Jan |title= Students hope to beat college waiting list |publisher= ''The Boston Globe'' |date= April 18, 2009 |url= http://www.boston.com/news/local/massachusetts/articles/2009/04/18/students_hope_to_beat_college_waiting_list/ |accessdate= December 31, 2011 }}</ref><ref>Note: the ''yield'' is the percent of students offered admission by April who commit to enroll by May; ''wait list acceptances'' are the number of students initially put on the wait list, who were eventually offered admission and who accepted this offer.</ref> |- !College !Yield !Wait list<br>acceptances |- |align="left"|Harvard |align="right"|75% |align="right"|70 |- |align="left"|Princeton |align="right"|69% |align="right"| |- |align="left"|Stanford |align="right"|71% |align="right"|76 |- |align="left"|U. Pennsylvania |align="right"|63% |align="right"| |- |align="left"|SUNY New Paltz |align="right"|21% |align="right"| |- |align="left"|Cornell |align="right"|49% |align="right"| |- |align="left"|Amherst |align="right"| |align="right"|35 |- |align="left"|Lafayette |align="right"|26% |align="right"| |- |align="left"|U. North Carolina |align="right"|54% |align="right"| |- |align="left"|U. Iowa |align="right"|33% |align="right"| |- |align="left"|Connecticut College |align="right"|30% |align="right"|44 |- |align="left"|Colorado College |align="right"|35% |align="right"| |- |}
One adviser suggested that students who are wait-listed "work the wait list" by staying in touch with the admissions office to make sure they know the student will attend if accepted,<ref name=twsL25/> and possibly take steps such as forwarding new grades and making a subsequent college visit,<ref name=twsL14/> or send a one-page letter or 60-second video describing a strong desire to attend and the reasons.<ref name=twsL31/><ref name="twsZe22"/> A former dean of admissions at [[Franklin and Marshall College]] suggests that students not view the wait list letter as a "polite denial" but rather as a possible opportunity.<ref name=twsL14/> A second report in 2011 confirmed this, and it suggested that private colleges without "billion-dollar endowments or 40,000 applicants" were finding that the period from May to the start of classes in fall was a time of uncertainty, with many institutions seeking new applicants, and unsure how many of the applicants that had promised to attend would, in fact, show up in the fall.<ref name=twsL15>{{cite news |author1=Scott Jaschik |author2=Kevin Kiley |title= Private colleges try to round out fall's enrollment into summer |publisher= ''USA Today'' |date= May 5, 2011 |url= https://www.usatoday.com/news/education/2011-05-05-college-admissions-summer_n.htm |accessdate= December 12, 2011 }}</ref> What can happen is that institutions at the top of the "food chain" accept students from their wait lists, and these students in turn sacrifice their deposit to schools lower down the chain, generating vacancies and uncertainty.<ref name=twsL15/> A downside to wait lists is that by the time a student is accepted, there may be much less money available for scholarships or grants.<ref name=twsL25/> There was a report in ''[[The Wall Street Journal]]'' of a few colleges, such as [[Franklin & Marshall]], that deliberately [[wait list|waitlisted]] overqualified students on the assumption that, even if accepted, they would almost certainly not enroll.<ref name=twsZe25/> The alleged purpose was to boost the ''admissions yield rate''––the percentage of students who accept a college's admissions offer––as a means to improve the college's overall performance on the influential [[College rankings#U.S. News & World Report College and University rankings|US News]] college rankings.<ref name=twsZe25>{{cite news |author= Daniel Golden |title= Glass Floor: Colleges Reject Top Applicants, Accepting Only the Students Likely to Enroll |publisher= ''The Wall Street Journal'' |date= May 29, 2001 |url= http://www.tdy-perdiem.com/club1/college12.htm |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20120426082540/http://www.tdy-perdiem.com/club1/college12.htm |archive-date= April 26, 2012 |accessdate= December 31, 2011 |deadurl= yes |df= mdy-all }}</ref>
[[Duke University]] in 2010 had 27,000 first-year applicants, accepted 4,000 and placed 856 on its waiting list in April, since it was uncertain how many of those accepted would choose to attend; in this sense, the wait list is a form of hedge for the university to guard against uncertainty.<ref name=twsL31>{{cite news |author= Jacques Steinberg |title= For Students, a Waiting List Is Scant Hope |publisher= ''The New York Times'' |date= April 13, 2010 |url= https://www.nytimes.com/2010/04/14/education/14waitlist.html?ref=admissions |accessdate= December 12, 2011 }}</ref> Duke does not rank students on the wait list, but chooses based on other characteristics.<ref name=twsL31/>
==Transfer admissions== {{Main|Transfer admissions in the United States}} While most college admissions involves high school students applying to colleges, [[Transfer admissions in the United States|transfer admissions]] are important as well. Estimates of the percentage of college students who transfer vary from 20%<ref name=twsMay2S113>{{cite news |author= David Moltz |title= More private colleges court community college transfers |newspaper= USA Today |date= February 18, 2010 |url= https://www.usatoday.com/news/education/2010-02-18-IHE-transfer-students-18_ST_N.htm |accessdate= May 19, 2012 }}</ref> to 33%<ref name=twsMay2R311a>{{cite news |author= Lynn O'Shaughnessy |title= Transfer Students: 8 Things You Need to Know |newspaper= US News |date= November 16, 2010 |url= https://www.usnews.com/education/blogs/the-college-solution/2010/11/16/transfer-students-8-things-you-need-to-know |accessdate= May 18, 2012 }}</ref> to 60%,<ref name=twsMay2R311c>{{cite news |author= Bill Schackner |title= Transfers a hot commodity for colleges |newspaper= Pittsburgh Post-Gazette |date= March 28, 2012 |url= http://www.post-gazette.com/stories/news/education/transfers-a-hot-commodity-for-colleges-240047/ |accessdate= May 18, 2012 }}</ref> with the consensus position being around a third of college students transfer, and there are many indications that transfer activity is increasing.<ref name=twsMay2R311c/> One report suggested that nearly half of all undergraduates in the nation were attending community colleges.<ref name=tws2T26>{{cite news |author= Roman, Marcia A. |title= Community College Admission and Student Retention |work= Journal of College Admission (via Highbeam Research) |quote= Community colleges enroll nearly half the undergraduates in the U.S. |date= January 1, 2007 |url= http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P3-1209566581.html |accessdate= August 20, 2012 }}</ref> Media coverage of student transfers is generally less than coverage of the high school to college transition. A common transfer path is students moving from two-year community colleges to four-year institutions, although there is considerable movement between four-year institutions.<ref name=twsMay2R311d>{{cite news |author= Kim Clark |title= Obama's Lessons for Transfer Students: His former roommate talks about what he and Obama learned about switching between colleges |newspaper= US News |date= January 16, 2009 |url= https://www.usnews.com/education/articles/2009/01/16/obamas-lessons-for-transfer-students |accessdate= May 18, 2012 }}</ref> Reasons for transferring include unhappiness with campus life, cost, and course and degree selection.<ref name=twsMay2R311d/> There are no consistent national rules for transfers, and requirements vary by college.<ref name="twsMay2S312"/> Many community colleges have [[Articulation (education)|articulation agreements]] with four-year schools, particularly [[Flagship university#Education|flagship]] state universities, so that matters such as the transfers of credits are handled appropriately. There are indications that many private colleges are more actively seeking transfer applicants.<ref name=twsMay2R311c/> Still, transferring can be difficult; transfer students have been described in the past as "academic nomads".<ref name=twsMay2S411>{{cite news |author= Tim Barker |title= Meet the transfers – they are academic nomads: Schools, government seek to streamline system to help more students make switch to four-year colleges, keep credit hours they have earned. |newspaper= St. Louis Today |date= February 5, 2012 |url= http://www.stltoday.com/news/local/education/meet-the-transfers---they-are-academic-nomads/article_075d610e-dc58-5686-abfe-61c803e18594.html |accessdate= May 19, 2012 }}</ref>
==See also== {{col-begin}} {{Col-3}} * [[Admissions essay]] * [[American Association of Collegiate Registrars and Admissions Officers]] * [[College application]] * [[College Entrance Exam Advisors and Educators]] * [[College tour]] * [[Common Application]] * [[Cooling Out]] {{Col-3}} * [[Early action]] * [[Early decision]] * [[FAFSA]] * [[FAFSA position]] * [[Hidden Ivies]] * [[National Association for College Admission Counseling| NACAC]] * [[Need-blind admission]] {{Col-3}} * [[Open-door academic policy]] * [[Rolling admission]] * [[Senioritis]] * [[Student financial aid in the United States]] * [[The Early Admissions Game: Joining the Elite|The Early Admissions Game]] * [[Transfer admissions in the United States]] * [[University and college admissions]] *[[First-generation college students in the United States]]{{Col-end}}
==Notes== {{Reflist|2}}
==References== * {{Cite book | last =Coates| first =Ken| last2 =Morrison| first2 =Bill| title =What to Consider If You're Considering College: New Rules for Education and Employment| publisher =Dundurn| year =2015| isbn =978-1459723726}} * {{cite book |last=Dunbar |first=Donald |title=What You Don't Know Can Keep You Out of College |url= |accessdate= |year=2007 |publisher=Gotham Books |location= |isbn=978-1-59240-302-8 |page= |ref=harv }} * {{cite book |last=Hernandez |first=Michele A. |title=A is for Admission: The Insider's Guide to Getting into the Ivy League and Other Top Colleges |url= |accessdate= |year=2009 |publisher=Grand Central Publishing |location= |isbn=978-0-446-54067-4 |page= |ref=harv }} * {{cite book |last1=Mamlet |first1=Robin |last2=Vandevelde |first2=Christine |authorlink= |title=College Admission: From Application to Acceptance, Step by Step |url= |accessdate= |year=2011 |publisher=Three Rivers Press |location=New York |isbn=978-0-307-59032-9 |page= |ref={{harvid|Mamlet|2011}} }}

revision.text:
{{infobox record label | name = Contrakultura | image = | image_bg = | parent = Iruña Films, SA | founded = 2002 | founder = [[Eduardo Montes-Bradley]] | distributor = [[Heritage Film Project]],[[Alexander Street Press]] | genre = [[Documentary Films]] | country = [[Argentina]] | location = [[San Telmo, Buenos Aires|San Telmo]] | url = }}
'''Contrakultura Films''' was an imprint of Iruña Films, SA a [[Buenos Aires, Argentina|Buenos Aires]] film production studio dedicated to produce biographical documentaries on Latin American writers<ref>Perez, Erwin. "Documentales de escritores Argentinos" El Nuevo Herald. Miami, April 3, 2202. Section C., page 2</ref>. The initiative eventually expanded to include [[visual artists]] such as [[:es:Andrés Waissman|Andrés Waissman]] and [[:es:Humberto Calzada|Humberto Calzada]], and [social scientists] like [[:es:León Rozitchner|León Rozitchner]], Ismael Viñas, [[Juan José Sebreli|Juan Jose Sebreli]] and Jorge Lovisolo.
Between 2002 and 2006'''Contrakultura''' produced approximately twenty-five documentaries. Most of these films are currently owned by [Heritage Film Project]<ref>Instituto Nacional de Cine y Artes Audiovisuales. Biblioteca.</ref>, and distributed by [[Alexander Street Press]].
The initial "contrakultural series" was known as “Perfiles”,<ref>La Nacion, "Trece documentales por jóvenes directoras" Buenos Aires, June 1, 2003.</ref> and was made of thirteen biographical documentaries. The series was presented at the Biennial Northeast Regional Meeting "Luso-Hispanic Presence in the Changing Cultural Landscape of America", organized by the [[American Association of Teachers of Spanish and Portuguese]] at [[Yale University]].<ref>American Association of Teachers of Spanish and Portuguese at Yale University. Biennial Northeast Regional Meeting. Hosted by Fernando Rosenberg. Yale University [[William L. Harkness]] Hall, [[New Haven, Connecticut|New Haven]]. September 10, 2004.</ref>
Several of the documentaries on the series Perfiles where directed by [[Eduardo Montes-Bradley]]. Somthe e of original titles are listed under a pseudonym inspired in legendary actresses of the silent era of Mexican Cinema such as Cándida Beltrán, Mimi Derba, Ana Lobos, Emma Padilla, Lupe Velez, Maria Laura del Rio, Ma. Laura Del Rio.<ref>Montes-Bradley, Eduardo. International Movie Data Base. Alternate Names.</ref> The series was initially publicized as directed by thirteen woman-directors by Eduardo Montes-Bradley.<ref>Ranzani, Oscar, "Literatura y cine" Pagina/12, Buenos Aire, May 21, 2003</ref>
Contrakultura also produced the series known as the NOA Trilogy, films produced by Contrakultura and directed by Norbert “Negro” Ramírez in the Jujuy and Salta provinces, on the Northwestern region of Argentina.
==Perfiles== [[File:OsvaldoBayerGermany.jpg|thumb|left|220px|upright|Bayer with [[Bolex|16mm Bolex]] during the filming of ''Los cuentos del Timonel''.]] [[File:Soriano Documentary segment.webm|thumb|left|220px|Excerpt from "Soriano"]] Perfiles was a series of thirteen documentaries by Eduardo Montes-Bradley which had already produced biographical documentaries on [[Jorge Luis Borges]], [[Julio Cortázar]], [[Osvaldo Soriano]] and [[Osvaldo Bayer]].
The average budget for a documentary on Perfiles was $40,000 of which 25% came as advance distribution fees advance from Patagonia Film Group, LLC, and 75% was subsidized by the Ministry of Culture of Argentina through [[National Institute of Cinema and Audiovisual Arts]].
* '''''Una cierta mirada'''''. Conversations with [[:es:Juan José Sebreli|Juan José Sebreli]]. Sebreli recalls his entire life in front of camera taking the audience for a ride through timeless Buenos Aires. Sebreli's extraordinary perception of the surroundings, the arts, the architecture and the music of the city he was born in and he loves is a constant throughout the entire film. In a way, this doc can be watch as a 20th-century Tour Guide of Buenos Aires, a sketch on Peronism and yet, more.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Roca|first1=Pilar|title=Las vidas paralelas de Montes-Bradley. Ensayo Crítico|date=2010|publisher=Grupo Archivo de Comunicación|location=Charleston, SC|isbn=1452857725|page=57|edition=First}}</ref><ref>{{cite video|people=Montes-Bradley,Eduardo (Director)|year=2005|title= Una cierta mirada|trans-title=A Certain Regard|medium= Motion Picture |language=Spanish | location=US | publisher=Heritage Film Project}}</ref> * '''''Le mot Juste'''''. The documentary tracks [[Héctor Tizón]] to his hometown of Yala in [[Jujuy|Jujuy, Argentina]]. In a series of interviews with Montes-Bradley, Tizón evokes his childhood, and the experience of living on the edge between two extremely different cultures: the [[Quechua people|Quechua]] universe of his native homeland, and the Spanish of the [[conquistadores]].<ref>Roca, Pilar "Las vidas paralelas de Montes-Bradley". Universidade Federal de Paraíba. Brazil.</ref> In the film Tizón explores the idea of exile in different directions with particular emphasis to the exile of the native inhabitants of the [[Puna de Atacama|Puna]] in a territory dominated by the Spanish Culture and Catholic traditions. Tizón also talks in this film about his personal experience in exile during the dictatorship of [[Jorge Rafael Videla]].<ref>Roca, Pilar. "Las vidas paralelas de Montes-Bradley" [[Universidade Federal da Paraiba|UFPA]]</ref> * '''''La otra orilla'''''. Biographical sketch on [[psychotherapist]] [[:es:Luis Gusmán|Luis Gusmán]], member of Revista Sitio and writer-member of the generation of [[Osvaldo Lamborghini]] and [[:es:Germán García|Germán García]]. Gusmán is a [[Konex Award]] recipient. ''La otra orilla'' follows Gusmán from his native [[Avellaneda]], in the peripheral and less privilege southern suburbs of Buenos Aires, to the middle class-hipster [[Palermo, Buenos Aires|Palermo]] in the capital city. The film includes previously unknown tango recordings of Luis Gusmán´s father.<ref>[https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0426157/combined IMDB]</ref> The actual interviews with Gusmám were conducted behind the camera by film student Yael Szmulewicz under the supervision of Montes-Bradley, camera by Alejandro Ortiz, Sound by Horacio Almada. DV | 70 min. and 70 min. version.<ref>{{Vimeo|id= 149610947 |title=La Otra Orilla - Luis Gusmán}}</ref> * '''''Planeta Bizzio''''', Documentary on the life and works of Sergio Bizzio, off beat-poet, playwright and novelist. Interview conducted by Nadina Fushimi. * '''''Deliciosas perversiones polimorfas'''''. An intimate portrait of [[Alberto Laiseca]]. Laiseca is a cult literary figure of Buenos Aires better known for his fictional metaphysics. The documentary explores the relationship between Laiseca and his father, a rural family doctor living in [[Córdoba (Argentina)|Córdoba]]. References to [[Edgar A. Poe]], [[William Shakespeare]] and the imminent arrival of the [[Antichrist]] are constant leitmotivs in the film.<ref>{{Vimeo|id= 150449246 |title=Deliciosas perversiones polimorfas - Alberto Laiseca}}</ref><ref>La Nacion: "Murió el escritor Alberto Laiseca" December 22, 2016.</ref> * '''''Si yo fuera Realmente Libre'''''. Biographical essay on the life and works of [[Alan Pauls]]. Interview conducted by Daniel Guebel.<ref>{{Vimeo|id= 99396320 |title=Si yo fuera Realmente Libre - Alan Pauls}}</ref> * '''''Ecce Homo'''''. Biographical essay on the writer, and cultural icon [[Juan Filloy]]. The film is based on an interview with Ana da Costa shortly before his death at 106 in the year 2000. Montes-Bradley's film reconstructs the life of Filloy.<ref>[http://fcaw.library.umass.edu/F/AVH883KGH32HDSBFHC8Q7KVH9M47CC32UXITRQTNJSNE1Q7N4N-00647?func=direct&doc_number=004969731&doc_library=FCL01&pds_handle=GUEST William Allan Neilson Library Smith Colleges Libraries]</ref> Contrakultura, 2004. 52 min.<ref>[http://bibliotech.memphis.edu:2082/search~S16?/aCost%2C+Noel+D./acost+noel+d/-3%2C-1%2C0%2CB/frameset&FF=acosta+ana+da+1969&1%2C1%2C The University of Memphis. University Library]</ref><ref>{{Vimeo|id=150032522=Vimeo Screening}}</ref> *'''''Las memorias del señor Alzheimer'''''. The protagonist of this film is Jorge "Dipi" Di Paola, a [[dadaist]]-[[Eccentricity (behavior)|eccentric]], writer-poet, an unconventional character of the Buenos Aires underground during the 1970s. The film was shot in 2007, shortly before Di Paola's death in [[Tandil]], some 450 kilometers from the capital of Argentina. In the film, Di Paola, recalls the times in which he and his mentor [[Witold Gombrowicz]] shared an apartment in Buenos Aires first, and later in Di Paola's home-town of [[Tandil]]. Produced by Montes-Bradley, directed by Sergio Belloti.<ref>[https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0491052/combined International Movie Data Base]</ref> [[File:Andres Rivera 02.jpg|thumb|300px|Andres Rivera and crew on the set of "Marcos Ribak aka Andrés Rivera".]]
*'''''Marcos Ribak aka Andrés Rivera'''''. Biographical portrait of [[Andrés Rivera]] author of "[[La revolución es un sueño eterno]]". The film was primarily shot in [[Córdoba, Argentina|Córdoba]] where the author lived with his second wife Susana Fiorito. The film contributes to shed light on Polish Jewelry immigration to Argentina, and in the political life of young members of the Communist Party in Buenos Aires during the Peronist regime (1945-1955).<ref>[https://vimeo.com/149934440=Vimeo Screening]</ref> Many of the scenes of this film where shot at the legendary [[Eden Hotel]], know to have served as a retreat to the former nazi officer after the war. *'''''No matarás'''''. Documentary on [[Marcelo Birmajer]], an irreverent Jewish-Argentine writer, who´s political views, largely at odds with the overwhelming "progressive"-minded cultural milieu in Buenos Aires are largely responsible for his continue political isolation. In the film, Birmajer presents himself to the audience as a lost soul somewhere between Buenos Aires and a not so distant [[Middle East]]; holding a tight grip on the umbilical cord that his Jewish-mother preserves intact for generations to-come. The film was produced shortly after the terrorist attack to [[Asociación Mutual Israelita Argentina|AMIA]] and the Israel Embassy in Buenos Aires which recently gained renewed attention in the media after the presumed murder of [[Alberto Nisman]]. In the film, Birmajer accuses Iran as the primary instigator of the terrorist attacks in Buenos Aires.<ref>[https://vimeo.com/149725054=Vimeo Screening]</ref> * '''''El país de no me acuerdo''''' (Neverland). A biographical sketch on [[:es:Iván Grondona|Ivan Grondona]]. Produced with the support of [[National Institute of Cinema and Audiovisual Arts|INCAA]], Ministerio de Cultura, [[Fondo Nacional de las Artes|National Endowment for the Arts]], City of Buenos Aires, Sociedad Argentina de Escritores, and [[National Library of the Argentine Republic|Biblioteca Nacional]] Filmed scarcely two years before Grondona's passing in Buenos Aires in 2006, the film explores the political life in Argentina through the eyes of this iconic and revered actor-director who first appearance in the screen [[Immigrants (1948 film)|Immigrants]] came under the direction of [[Aldo Fabrizi]]. The film comes to a severe critique to [[Peronism]], and what Grondona refers to in the film as "moral decay" and the "decomposition of the social fabric in Argentina". Produced by Contrakultura, 2004. Cinematography Alejandro Ortiz, Sound Horacio Almada. Directed by Eduardo Montes-Bradley as Cándida Beltrán. DV | 79 min.<ref>Paraná Cendrós, Daniel. Museo del Cine Pablo Ducrós Hicken. Buenos Aires, Argentina.</ref> * '''''Saludablemente en pelotas'''''. Biographical sketch on [[:es:Juan Sasturain|Juan Sasturain]], journalist ([[Pagina/12]]), and fiction writer better known for his collaboration with [[comics]] artist. * '''''La célula fugitiva'''''. Biographical sketch on journalist and script writer [[José Pablo Feinmann]]. The title translates as "The fugitive cell" and alludes to the protagonist survival to a cancer diagnosis during the government of [[Isabel Perón]] and the [[Argentine Anticommunist Alliance|Triple A]]. * '''''Desandando el tiempo'''''. Biographical sketch of the poet [[:es:Juan-Jacobo Bajarlía|Juan-Jacobo Bajarlía]] (1914-2005). Produced by Eduardo Montes-Bradley and Directed by Rodolfo Durán as "Valentina Carrasco". * '''''En el nombre del padre'''''. Biographical sketch on [[Ana María Shua]]. * '''''Espléndida decadencia'''''. Biographical sketch on [[:es:Daniel Guebel|Daniel Guebel]].
===NOA Trilogy===
Series of three documentary films produced by Montes-Bradley with the support of the Ministry of Culture of [[Salta, Argentina|Salta]], and a grant from the [[National Institute of Cinema and Audiovisual Arts]]. The trilogy was directed by Norberto "Negro" Ramírez, a filmmaker born in [[Catamarca Province]], and raised in Buenos Aires. During the [[Jorge Rafael Videla|dictatorship 1976-1983]] Ramirez found refuge in the internal exile in the northwestern provinces of Argentina, a region known as NOA (Noroeste Argentino), also known as [[Altiplano|Puna]], which mainly includes [[Jujuy Province|Jujuy]] and [[Salta Province|Salta]] provinces.
* '''''From Frankfurt to [[Humahuaca]]'''''. Biographical-essay on Jorge Lovisolo, a philosopher entrenched in the northwestern province of Salta; a disciple of [[The Frankfurt School]], and author of numerous essays. The film deals with Lovisolo's obsessions in a sort of self-imposed exile in [[Salta]]; his perspectives on religion and local communities, the thoughts of [[Walter Benjamin]], [[Herbert Marcuse]], [[Theodore Adorno]] and others.<ref>"Africans and their Descendants in Latin America" Professor Tamara J. Walker. University of Pennsylvania</ref> NOA Productions, 2005. *'''''Kopla Vera'''''. Biographical-essay on Jesús Ramón Vera, author of numerous verses inspired in the liturgical [[carnival]] of [[Jujuy]]. NOA Productions, c. 2006. * ''Yo y el tiempo''. Biographical-essay on poet-composer Juan José Botelli, a native and cultural icon in [[Salta, Argentina|Salta]]. "Yo y el tiempo" is the third and last documentary in the NOA trilogy produced by Montes-Bradley, and directed by Norberto "Negro" Ramírez. NOA Productions, c.2006
== Notes == {{reflist|30em}}
[[Category:Film production companies of Argentina]] [[Category:Documentary film production companies]] [[Category:Documentary film series]] [[Category:Educational films]] [[Category:Entertainment companies established in 2002]] [[Category:2002 establishments in Argentina]]

{{refimprove|date=November 2016}} The '''Council of British International Schools''' (COBIS) serves British International Schools around the globe, representing over 281 Member Schools in 79 countries and over 209 Supporting Member organisations.
COBIS exists to serve, support and represent its member schools – their leaders, governors, staff and students by: * Representing member schools with the [[British Government]], educational bodies, and the corporate sector * Providing effective [[professional development]] for senior leaders, [[governors]], [[teachers]] and support staff * Facilitating, coordinating and supporting professional networking opportunities for British International schools * Processing [[Disclosure Barring Service]] checks to promote child protection and safer recruitment and employment practices * Providing access to information about trends and developments in [[UK education]] * Facilitating mentoring and support programmes for Heads and school leaders * Promoting career opportunities within the global COBIS network * Brokering a cost-effective consultancy service between schools and approved educational support service providers
COBIS hosts a range of conferences and professional development events for teachers, middle leaders, support staff throughout the year, plus an annual conference in [[London]] in May for school leaders and Governors. In addition to accessing high quality training COBIS events provide excellent opportunities for colleagues to develop professional networks and contacts. COBIS represents its members with the British Government, educational bodies, the corporate sector and Ministries of Education worldwide and is committed to advancing the interests of British schools and British education overseas. From 2015, COBIS expanded its range of services to include a COBIS Diploma for [[Teaching Assistants]] (DITA) and DITA for [[Early Years Foundation Stage|Early Years]], both run in association with the TA College, as well as a COBIS Summer School based at [[Cambridge University]].
Founded over 30 years ago, COBIS is governed by an elected [[Executive (government)|Executive Committee]] consisting of Headteachers and Governors from member schools worldwide. The association is a constituent member of the [[Independent Schools Council]] and operates on a [[not-for-profit]] basis to reflect being a UK registered company 'Limited by Guarantee'.
The [[Patron]] of COBIS is [[HRH The Duke of York KG]], the [[Honorary President]] is [[Roger Fry (educationist)|Sir Roger Fry CBE]] and the [[Chairman]] is Mr Trevor Rowell.
COBIS is led by [[CEO]] Colin Bell and supported by the COBIS team based in London. In August 2015, COBIS [[Head Office]] moved from [[Twickenham]] to [[Russell Square]] in London's [[Bloomsbury]] area.
==The Patron's Accreditation and Compliance==
In October 2016, COBIS announced a new external validation scheme for British schools overseas to be known as The Patron's Accreditation and Compliance.<ref name="ReferenceA">https://www.cobis.org.uk/accreditation</ref> The new scheme will officially be available to schools from April 2017 and will be offered as an alternative to inspections carried out by the [[Department for Education]] for British Schools Overseas.
==References== <references />
==External links== *[http://www.cobis.org.uk Official COBIS Website]
[[Category:Educational organisations based in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:International school associations]] [[Category:Private and independent school organizations]]
