revision.text:
{{Orphan|date=January 2017}} {{Infobox person |name =Patricia Ocampo |birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1979|12|26}} |birth_place = {{nowrap|[[Oberá]], [[Misiones Province]]}} |death_date = |death_place = |image = Pato3.jpg |signature = |parents = Juan Mauricio Ocampo
Zusana Da Cruz |spouse = |children = |nationality = Argentine |movement = [[Peace movement]] |organization = Un sueño para Misiones |monuments = |alma_mater = |awards = |religion = }} '''Patricia Ocampo''' (born 1979) is an Argentine activist involved in community development and creation of libraries in [[Misiones Province]]. By 2014, she had worked with community organizers and celebrities to found 20 libraries. The organization she co-founded provides basic assistance to those in poverty and with disabilities and attempts to empower people through education and access to books and libraries. She is also involved in trying to stop child labor in Argentina, specifically in the [[yerba mate]] regions. ==Biography== Patricia Liliana Ocampo was born 26 December 1979 in [[Oberá]], [[Misiones Province]], Argentina. She grew up in a family that could not afford books and realized when she was in school the power books have to expand ideas.{{cite news|last1=Bachiller|first1=Mariano D.|title=Entrevista de El Territorio a Patricia Ocampo, fundadora de Un Sueño para Misiones|url=http://gruposolidario.org/novedades/entrevista-de-el-territorio-a-patricia-ocampo-fundadora-de-un-sueno-para-misiones-874/|accessdate=17 April 2015|publisher=Grupo Solidario|date=1 April 2013|location=Posadas, Misiones, Argentina|language=Spanish}} She serves as the regional head of the [[Federal Authority for Audiovisual Communication Services]] (AFSCA), Argentina's broadcast media regulator.{{cite news|title=AFSCA Misiones: comunicadores buscan apropiarse de herramientas que ofrece la ley|url=http://www.diario33.com/23798-afsca-misiones-comunicadores-buscan-apropiarse-de-herramientas-que-ofrece-la-ley.html|accessdate=17 April 2015|publisher=Diario 33|date=30 November 2014|location=Argentina|language=Spanish}} In 2011, she helped found the movement ''"Un sueño para Misiones"'' (A dream for Misiones Province), an organization that attempts to bridge the gap between government services and citizens needs. Primarily known for building libraries the group addresses a wide range of issues in Misiones Province, from illiteracy to providing clothing and basic needs for citizens living in poverty, to creation of community gardens{{cite news|title=Eldorado: Trabajan por "Un sueño para Misiones"|url=http://misionesonline.net/2013/10/12/eldorado-trabajan-por-un-sue-o-para-misiones/|accessdate=17 April 2015|publisher=Misiones Online|date=12 October 2013|location=Posadas, Misiones, Argentina|language=Spanish}} to assistance to those with disability,{{cite news|title="Un sueño para Misiones" comenzó campaña para donar elementos ortopédicos a los que necesitan y no pueden comprarlos|url=http://misionesonline.net/2012/07/28/un-sueno-para-misiones-comenzo-campana-para-donar-elementos-ortopedicos-a-los-que-necesitan-y-no-pueden-comprarlos/|accessdate=17 April 2015|publisher=Misiones Online|date=28 July 2012|location=Posadas, Misiones, Argentina|language=Spanish}} to addressing [[child labor]].{{cite news|title=Trabajo Infantil: "el oscuro y multimillonario negocio de la Yerba Mate"|url=http://www.saladeprensa.net/inf/trabajo-infantil-el-oscuro-y-multimillonario-negocio-de-la-yerba-mate/|accessdate=17 April 2015|publisher=SaladePrensa|date=19 November 2013|location=Buenos Aires, Argentina|language=Spanish}} Ocampo has been successful in building support for expanding and creating new libraries by both community involvement and asking celebrities and writers to donate books or help raise funds.{{cite news|last1=Abad|first1=Esteban|title=Tobuna recibió a Marcelo Moreyra con muchos libros para la biblioteca|url=http://www.primeraedicionweb.com.ar/nota/suplemento/12569/tobuna-recibio-a-marcelo-moreyra-con-muchos-libros-para-la-biblioteca-.html|accessdate=17 April 2015|publisher=Primera Edicion|date=2012|location=Posadas, Misiones, Argentina|language=Spanish|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150418030754/http://www.primeraedicionweb.com.ar/nota/suplemento/12569/tobuna-recibio-a-marcelo-moreyra-con-muchos-libros-para-la-biblioteca-.html|archivedate=18 April 2015|df=}}{{cite news|title="Un Sueño para Misiones" en el Top Race en Oberá|url=http://www.lacapitalmdp.com/noticias/Deportes/2012/05/05/216830.htm|accessdate=17 April 2015|publisher=La Capital MDP|date=5 May 2012|location=Mar del Plata, Argentina|language=Spanish}}{{cite news|title=Famosos cumplieron el sueño de la biblioteca|url=http://www.territoriodigital.com/nota3.aspx?c=7649294309807506|accessdate=17 April 2015|publisher=TerritorioDigital|date=September 12, 2011|location=Posadas, Misiones, Argentina|language=Spanish}} In 2014, the 20th library was built.{{cite news|title=Se inauguró la biblioteca "Andrés Guacurarí" en Eldorado|url=http://misionesonline.net/2014/12/21/se-inauguro-la-biblioteca-andres-guacurari-en-eldorado/|accessdate=17 April 2015|publisher=Misiones Online|date=21 December 2014|location=Posadas, Misiones, Argentina|language=Spanish}} ===Libraries=== In 2010, Patricia Ocampo, Jorge Kordi and Daniela Paola Friedl began a project to build libraries throughout the Misiones Province.{{cite web|last1=Tessieri|first1=Enrique|title=Eino Parkkulainen’s home in Argentina becomes a community library|url=http://www.migranttales.net/eino-parkkulainens-home-in-argentina-becomes-a-community-library/|website=Migrant Tales|publisher=Migrant Tales|accessdate=17 April 2015|location=Finland|date=June 7, 2012}} The goal was to build ten libraries the first year in villages with populations between 2500 and 5000 people,{{cite news|title="Un sueño para Misiones" inaugurará la biblioteca número ocho y llevará el nombre de Guido Fallaci|url=http://misionesonline.net/2012/08/23/un-sueno-para-misiones-inaugurara-la-biblioteca-numero-ocho-y-llevara-el-nombre-de-guido-fallaci/|accessdate=17 April 2015|publisher=Misiones Online|date=23 August 2012|location=Posadas, Misiones, Argentina|language=Spanish}} seeding each library with 1,000 initial books.{{cite news|title="Un sueño para Misiones" inauguró la biblioteca N° 17 en Tobuna|url=http://misionesonline.net/2013/11/29/un-sue-o-para-misiones-inaugur-la-biblioteca-n-17-en-tobuna/|accessdate=17 April 2015|publisher=Misiones Online|date=29 November 2013|location=Posadas, Misiones, Argentina|language=Spanish}} The first library they completed was in the village of [[San Martín, Misiones|San Martín]] in the former home of Eino Parkkulainen, who created the Finnish-Spanish dictionary. The second library was founded in [[Puerto Leoni]]. Libraries three, in the barrio 180 Viviendas de [[Oberá]]; four, in [[Guaraní, Misiones|Guaraní]];{{cite news|title=Hoy se inaugura la primera biblioteca pública|url=http://www.territoriodigital.com/notaimpresa.aspx?c=6725588969982263|accessdate=17 April 2015|publisher=TerritorioDigital|date=27 April 2012|location=Posadas, Argentina|language=Spanish}} and five, in [[Colonia Victoria]] were all founded by the organization's first anniversary.{{cite news|title="Un Sueño para Misiones" inaugurará la quinta biblioteca popular y será en colonia Victoria|url=http://misionesonline.net/2012/07/02/un-sueno-para-misiones-inaugurara-la-quinta-biblioteca-popular-y-sera-en-colonia-victoria/|accessdate=17 April 2015|publisher=Misiones Online|date=2 July 2012|location=Posadas, Misiones, Argentina|language=Spanish}} The sixth library opened by the group was in [[Loreto, Misiones|Loreto]] and the seventh was in [[Panambí]].{{cite news|title="Un sueño para Misiones" inaugura en Loreto su sexta biblioteca|url=http://misionesonline.net/2012/08/08/un-sueno-para-misiones-inaugura-en-loreto-su-sexta-biblioteca/|accessdate=17 April 2015|publisher=Misiones OnLine|date=8 August 2012|location=Posadas, Misiones, Argentina|language=Spanish}} The eighth library was built in the village of [[Colonia Delicia]] and named after [[Guido Falaschi]], whose racing circuit has supported ''Un sueño para Misiones''.{{cite news|title=Guido Falaschi tiene su biblioteca|url=http://www.territoriodigital.com/notaimpresa.aspx?c=1236899836247997|accessdate=17 April 2015|publisher=TerritorioDigital|date=1 September 2012|location=Posadas, Argentina|language=Spanish}} The 9th library opened in [[Wanda, Argentina|Wanda]]{{cite news|title=Inauguraron la sede de la biblioteca Alma Guaraní|url=http://www.territoriodigital.com/notaimpresa.aspx?c=3083901195984102|accessdate=17 April 2015|publisher=TerritorioDigital|date=25 September 2012|location=Posadas, Argentina|language=Spanish}} and the 10th library opened in [[Caraguatay (Argentina)|Caraguatay]] in November, 2012.{{cite news|title=Se ubica en la zona rural, a 5 kilómetros del casco urbano Caraguatay incorporó una biblioteca popular barrial|url=http://www.territoriodigital.com/nota3.aspx?c=8092837576358981|accessdate=17 April 2015|publisher=TerritorioDigital|date=3 November 2012|location=Posadas, Argentina|language=Spanish}} The 11th library was built in Puerto Libertad,{{cite news|title=Inauguran nueva biblioteca popular en Puerto Libertad|url=http://www.territoriodigital.com/notaimpresa.aspx?c=0490343703756606|accessdate=17 April 2015|publisher=TerritorioDigital|date=20 June 2014|location=Posadas, Argentina|language=Spanish}} the 12th in [[Santo Pipó]],{{cite news|title=Un Sueño para Misiones inauguró doce bibliotecas en el 2012|url=http://misionesonline.net/2012/12/28/un-sue-o-para-misiones-inaugur-doce-bibliotecas-en-el-2012/|accessdate=17 April 2015|publisher=Misiones OnLine|date=28 December 2012|location=Posadas, Misiones, Argentina|language=Spanish}} and in March 2013 the 13th library was opened by the group in [[El Alcázar (Misiones)|El Alcázar]].{{cite web|title=El Alcázar ya tiene biblioteca !!! Marilú Leverberg participó de la inauguración|url=http://www.udpmonline.com/2013/03/17/el-alcazar-ya-tiene-biblioteca-maril%C3%BA-leverberg-particip%C3%B3-de-la-inauguraci%C3%B3n/|website=UDPM Online|publisher=Unión Docentes de la Provincia de Misiones|accessdate=17 April 2015|location=Posadas, Misiones, Argentina|language=Spanish|date=17 March 2013}} The 14th library was built in Paraje Parejha,{{cite web|title=Paraje Parejha tiene su primer biblioteca Popular "Un sueño para MIsiones"|url=http://paramisiones.blogspot.com.ar/2013/04/paraje-parejha-tiene-su-primer.html|website=Para Misiones|publisher=Un sueño" para Misiones|accessdate=17 April 2015|location=Argentina|language=Spanish|date=17 April 2013}} the 15th in [[Puerto Iguazú]],{{cite news|title="Un sueño para Misiones" inaugurará la biblioteca popular número 15 en Iguazú|url=http://misionesonline.net/2013/07/03/un-sue-o-para-misiones-inaugurar-la-biblioteca-popular-n-mero-15-en-iguaz/|accessdate=17 April 2015|publisher=Misiones OnLine|location=Posadas, Misiones, Argentina|date=3 July 2013|language=Spanish}} and the 16th library was founded in El Saltito.{{cite news|title=Una biblioteca más se suma a Misiones, esta vez en paraje El Saltito|url=http://misionesonline.net/2013/11/12/una-biblioteca-m-s-se-suma-a-misiones-esta-vez-en-paraje-el-saltito/|accessdate=17 April 2015|publisher=Misiones OnLine|date=12 November 2013|location=Posadas, Misiones, Argentina|language=Spanish}} The 17th library was built in Tobuna, and the 18th library was established in [[San Pedro de Jujuy]].{{cite web|title=Jujuy, Biblioteca y Cumpliendo promesas|url=http://paramisiones.blogspot.mx/2014/02/jujuy-biblioteca-y-cumpliendo-promesas.html|website=Para Misiones|publisher=Un sueño" para Misiones|accessdate=17 April 2015|location=Argentina|language=Spanish|date=5 February 2014}} The 20th library opened in 2014 in the barrio Sarmiento of the town of [[Eldorado, Misiones|Eldorado]].{{cite news|title=Inauguraron una Biblioteca en barrio Sarmiento|url=http://www.nortemisionero.com.ar/?modulo=noticia&id=23204|accessdate=17 April 2015|publisher=Norte Misionero|date=21 December 2014|location=Eldorado, Misiones, Argentina|language=Spanish}} ===Child labor=== She has met with the National Commission for the Eradication of Child Labour (CONAETI) to discuss working conditions of child laborers.{{cite news|title="Un Sueño para Misiones" se suma al COPRAETI|url=http://mundogremial.com/analisis-y-opinion/un-sueno-para-misiones-se-suma-al-copraeti-4738|accessdate=17 April 2015|publisher=Mundo Gremial|date=23 March 2014|location=Argentina|language=Spanish}} On 4 April 2014, a draft resolution was adopted by the [[Argentine Chamber of Deputies]] acknowledging Ocampo's work in the Misiones province since 2010 and declaring their intent to eradicate exploitation of child laborers in the Yerba Mate industry.{{cite web|title=H.Cámara de Diputados de la Nación PROYECTO DE RESOLUCIÓN|url=http://www1.hcdn.gov.ar/proyxml/expediente.asp?fundamentos=si&numexp=2023-D-2014|website=Honorable Cámara de Diputados|publisher=Government of Argentina|accessdate=17 April 2015|location=Buenos Aires, Argentina|language=Spanish|date=4 April 2014}} In October, 2014, Ocampo attended a public audience with [[Pope Francis]] in the [[Vatican City]] to discuss child labor.{{cite news|title=La ONG Un sueño para Misiones tuvo una audiencia con el Papa|url=http://infodia.com.ar/la-ong-un-sueno-para-misiones-tuvo-una-audiencia-con-el-papa/|accessdate=17 April 2015|publisher=Infodía|date=27 October 2014|location=Posadas, Misiones, Argentina|language=Spanish}} In March, 2015, she took the campaign against child labor to the legislature hoping to gain support for a national bill banning the practice in Argentina.{{cite news|last1=Luis|title="Un sueño para Misiones" relanza la campaña "Me Gusta el Mate sin trabajo infantil"|url=http://misionesopina.com.ar/un-sueno-para-misiones-relanza-la-campana-me-gusta-el-mate-sin-trabajo-infantil-esta-vez-bajo-el-lema-los-argentinos-elegimos-productos-sin-trabajo-infantil/|accessdate=17 April 2015|publisher=MisionesOpina|date=30 March 2015|location=Posadas, Argentina|language=Spanish}} ==References== {{reflist|30em}} == External links == {{Portal|Argentina}} * [http://www.vinculonatural.blogspot.com/ Personal site] {{es}} * [http://www.paramisiones.blogspot.com/ Un sueño" para Misiones" (A dream for Misiones Province) channel] {{es}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Ocampo, Patricia}} [[Category:1979 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:People from Oberá]] [[Category:Open content activists]] [[Category:Health activists]] [[Category:Argentine activists]] [[Category:Education activists]] [[Category:Argentine women]]

page.title: Presidential Award for Excellence in Science, Mathematics, and Engineering Mentoring

revision.text:
The '''Presidential Award for Excellence in Science, Mathematics and Engineering Mentoring (PAESMEM)''' is a Presidential award established by the United States White House in 1995. The program is administered by the [[National Science Foundation]] (NSF) on behalf of the White House [[Office of Science and Technology Policy]] (OSTP) to reward outstanding mentoring by individuals and organizations.<ref>[https://www.nsf.gov/funding/pgm_summ.jsp?pims_id=5473 National Science Foundation Program page]</ref> PAESMEM is the highest national mentoring award bestowed by the White House. <ref>[http://paesmem.net Presidential Awards for Excellence in Science, Mathematics and Engineering Mentoring Official site]</ref>
==Recipients== *1996 [[Richard A. Tapia]] *1997 [[Geraldine L. Richmond]] *1998 [[Nina Roscher]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.nsf.gov/news/news_summ.jsp?cntn_id=102914|title=Presidential Awards Honor Science, Mathematics and Engineering Mentoring {{!}} NSF - National Science Foundation|website=www.nsf.gov|language=en|access-date=2018-09-08}}</ref> *2003 [[Linda B. Hayden]], [[Margaret Werner-Washburne]]<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://paesmem.net/awards|title=Awards {{!}} paesmem|website=paesmem.net|language=en|access-date=2018-10-14}}</ref> *2005 [[Rosemary Gillespie (biologist)|Rosemary Gillespie]]<ref name=":0" /> *2008 [[Richard Zare]]<ref name=":0" /> *2011 [[Jo Handelsman]]<ref name=":0" />
== STEM Mentoring== [[Mentoring]] in the [[STEM fields]] has been shown to assist with student retention, a significant problem in the [[STEM pipeline]]. <ref>{{Citation | first = Zakiya | last = Wilson | title = Hierarchical Mentoring: A Transformative Strategy for Improving Diversity and Retention in Undergraduate STEM Disciplines | place = | publisher = Springer Science+Business Media, LLC | series = Journal of Science Education and Technology | volume = | edition = | year = 2012 | page = | doi = 10.1007/s10956-011-9292-5 | isbn = | mr = | zbl = }}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
==See also== * [[Awards and decorations of the United States government]] * [[Computer science]] * [[Computing]] * [[Engineering]] * [[Math]] * [[Science]] * [[STEM fields]] * [[Technology]]
==External links== *[http://paesmem.net/ Official site] *[https://www.nsf.gov/funding/pgm_summ.jsp?pims_id=5473 National Science Foundation Program page]
[[Category:National Science Foundation]] [[Category:Mentorships]] [[Category:American science and technology awards]]

revision.text:
:''Not to be confused with [[Public Knowledge]], a non-profit in Washington D.C. {{Infobox non-profit | name =Public Knowledge Project | image =PublicKnowledgeProjectLogo.jpg | image_size =150px | caption = | map = | map_size = <!-- map size, optional, default 250px --> | map_alt = <!-- map alt text --> | map_caption = | map2 = | type = | tax_id = <!-- or | vat_id = --> | registration_id = | founded_date = 1998<!-- {{Start date|YYYY|MM|DD}} --> | founder =[[John Willinsky]] | predecessor = | dissolved = <!-- {{End date|YYYY|MM|DD}} --> | merged = | successor = | location = | addnl_location = | coordinates = <!-- {{Coord|LAT|LON|display=inline,title}} --> | origins = | key_people = | area_served = | products = | services = | focus = | mission = | method = | revenue = | disbursed = | expenses = | endowment = | num_volunteers = | num_employees = | num_members = | affiliations = | subsid = | owner = | motto = | formerly = | website = {{URL|pkp.sfu.ca}} | footnotes = }}
The '''Public Knowledge Project''' is a non-profit research initiative that is focused on the importance of making the results of publicly funded research freely available through [[open access]] policies, and on developing strategies for making this possible including software solutions. It is a partnership between the Faculty of Education at the [[University of British Columbia]], the Canadian Centre for Studies in Publishing at [[Simon Fraser University]], the [[University of Pittsburgh]], [[Ontario Council of University Libraries]], the [[California Digital Library]] and the School of Education at [[Stanford University]].<ref name="PKP">{{cite web|title=About|url=http://pkp.sfu.ca/about|work=Public Knowledge Project|accessdate=21 August 2013}}</ref> It seeks to improve the scholarly and public quality of academic research through the development of innovative online environments.
==History== The PKP was founded in 1998 by [[John Willinsky]] in the Department of Language and Literacy Education at the Faculty of Education at the University of British Columbia, in [[Vancouver]], [[British Columbia]], [[Canada]], based on his research in education and publishing.<ref name="PKP" /> Willinsky is a leading advocate of [[open access]] publishing, and has written extensively on the value of public research.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://pkp.sfu.ca/biblio |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2006-11-21 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061208193100/http://pkp.sfu.ca/biblio |archivedate=2006-12-08 |df= }} PKP Bibliography</ref>
The PKP’s initial focus was on increasing access to scholarly research and output beyond the traditional academic environments. This soon led to a related interest in scholarly communication and publishing, and especially on ways to make it more cost effective and less reliant on commercial enterprises and their generally restricted access models. PKP has developed free, open source software for the management, publishing, and indexing of journals, conferences, and monographs.
The PKP has collaborated with a wide range of partners interested in making research publicly available, including the [[Scholarly Publishing and Academic Resources Coalition]] (SPARC), the [[Brazilian Institute for Information Science and Technology]] (IBICT), and the [[International Network for the Availability of Scientific Publications]] (INASP).
Together with INASP, the PKP is working with publishers, librarians, and academics in the development of [[:Category:Academic journal online publishing platforms|scholarly research portals]] in the developing world, including [[African Journals OnLine]] (AJOL) and Asia Journals Online.<ref>{{cite web|title=About|url=http://asiajol.info/index.php/about|work=Asia Journals Online|accessdate=21 August 2013}}</ref>
As of 2008, the PKP has joined the [[Synergies Canada]] initiative, contributing their technical expertise to integrating work being done within a five-party consortium to create a decentralized national platform for social sciences and humanities research communication in Canada.
==Growth 2005 to 2009== The Public Knowledge Project grew between 2005 and 2009. In 2006, there were approximately 400 journals using Open Journal Systems (OJS), 50 conferences using Open Conference Systems (OCS), 4 organizations using the Harvester, and 350 members registered on the online support forum. In 2009, over 5000 journals were using OJS, more than 500 conferences were using OCS, at least 10 organizations are using the Harvester, and there were over 2400 members on the support forum.
Since 2005, there were major releases (version 2) of three software modules (OJS, OCS, Harvester), as well as the addition of [[Lemon8-XML]], with a growing number of downloads being recorded every month for all of the software. From June 12, 2009 to December 21, 2009, there were 28451 downloads of OJS, 6329 of OCS, 1255 of the Harvester, and 1096 of Lemon8-XML. A new module, Open Monograph Press (a publication management system for monographs) has also been released.
The PKP also witnessed increased community programming contributions, including new plugins and features, such as the subscription module, allowing OJS to support full open access, delayed open access, or full subscription-only access. A growing number of translations have been contributed by community members, with Croatian, English, French, German, Italian, Japanese, Portuguese, Russian, Spanish, Turkish, and Vietnamese versions of OJS completed, and several others in production.
==Growth from 2010==
A German platform, based on OJS, is being developed by the Center for Digital Systems (CeDiS), [[Free University of Berlin]] and two other institutions.<ref name="ojs-de"> {{cite web | title = OJS-de.net | url = http://www.ojs-de.net | access-date = 2016-09-15 }} </ref> Funding by the [[Deutsche Forschungsgemeinschaft|German Research Foundation]] (DFG) initially runs from 2014 to 2016.
==PKP conferences== The PKP holds a biannual conference. The First PKP Scholarly Publishing Conference was held in [[Vancouver]], [[British Columbia]], Canada on July 11–13, 2007<ref>{{cite web|title=PKP Scholarly Publishing Conference 2007|url=http://pkp.sfu.ca/ocs/pkp/index.php/pkp2007/pkp2007|work=Public Knowledge Project|accessdate=21 August 2013}}</ref> and the Second PKP Scholarly Publishing Conference was also held in Vancouver on July 8–10, 2009.<ref>{{cite web|title=International PKP Scholarly Publishing Conference 2009|url=http://pkp.sfu.ca/ocs/pkp/index.php/pkp2009/pkp2009|work=Public Knowledge Project|accessdate=21 August 2013}}</ref> The Third PKP Scholarly Publishing Conference was held in [[Berlin]], Germany between 26–28 September 2011.<ref>{{cite web|title=PKP Scholarly Publishing Conference 2011|url=http://pkp.sfu.ca/ocs/pkp/index.php/pkp2011/pkp2011|work=Public Knowledge Project|accessdate=21 August 2013}}</ref> The fourth PKP Scholarly Publishing Conference was held in [[Mexico City]], [[Mexico]] in August 19–21, 2013.<ref>{{cite web|title=PKP Scholarly Publishing Conference 2013|url=http://pkp.sfu.ca/pkp2013|work=Public Knowledge Project|accessdate=21 August 2013}}</ref>
Notes on the presentations were recorded on a scholarly publishing blog for both the 2007 <ref>[http://scholarlypublishing.blogspot.com/] PKP 2007 Conference Blog</ref> and 2009 <ref>[http://blogs.ubc.ca/pkp2009/] PKP 2009 Conference Blog</ref> conferences, and selected papers from the 2007 conference were published in a special issue of the online journal ''[[First Monday]]''.<ref>{{cite journal|title=Public Knowledge Project: Selected papers from the Scholarly Publishing Conference, 11-13 July 2007|journal=First Monday|date=October 2007|volume=12|issue=10|url=http://journals.uic.edu/ojs/index.php/fm/issue/view/250|accessdate=21 August 2013}}</ref> Papers from the 2009 conference are available in the inaugural issue of the journal ''Scholarly and Research Communication''.<ref>{{cite web|title=Volume 4, Issue 1|url=http://src-online.ca/index.php/src/announcement/view/27|work=Scholarly and Research Communication|accessdate=21 August 2013}}</ref>
==Software== {{cat see also|Abstract management software|Publication management software}} The PKP's suite of software includes four separate, but inter-related applications to demonstrate the feasibility of open access: the [[Open Journal Systems]], the [[Open Conference Systems]], the [[PKP Open Archives Harvester]], and Open Monograph Press. PKP briefly experimented with a fifth application, Lemon8-XML, but has since opted to incorporate the XML functionality into the existing applications. All of the products are [[open source]] and freely available to anyone interested in using them. They share similar technical requirements (PHP, MySQL, Apache or Microsoft IIS 6, and a Linux, BSD, Solaris, Mac OS X, or Windows operating system) and need only a minimal level of technical expertise to get up and running. In addition, the software is well supported with a free, online support forum and a growing body of publications and documentation is available on the project web site.
Increasingly, institutions are combining the PKP software, using OJS to publish their research results, OCS to organize their conferences and publish the proceedings, and the OAI Harvester to organize and make the metadata from these publications searchable. Together with other open source software applications such as [[DSpace]] (for creating institutional research repositories), institutions are creating their own infrastructure for sharing their research output.
==Involved parties== It is a partnership among the following entities: * [[Simon Fraser University]] Library * The [[University of British Columbia]] Library * Canadian Centre for Studies in Publishing at [[Simon Fraser University]] * [[University of Pittsburgh]] * Ontario Council of University Libraries * Graduate School of Education at [[Stanford University]]<ref name="PKP"/>
==See also==
* [[List of open access journals]] * [[List of open-access projects]] * [[Open access]]
== References == {{reflist|30em}}
==External links== * [http://pkp.sfu.ca Public Knowledge Project official site] * [http://pkp.sfu.ca/ojs Open Journal Systems] * [http://pkp.sfu.ca/ocs Open Conference Systems] * [http://pkp.sfu.ca/harvester PKP Open Archive Harvester] * [http://pkp.sfu.ca/omp PKP Open Monograph Press] * [https://www.scribd.com/doc/155083952/Open-monograph-press-Installation-to-functioning Installation manual]
{{open access navbox}}
[[Category:Academic journal online publishing platforms]] [[Category:Academic publishing]] [[Category:Open access projects]] [[Category:Publication management software]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=November 2017}} {{Use British English|date=November 2017}} '''Qualified Weapons Instructor''' (QWI) (''queue-why'') is a qualification given to graduates of the [[Royal Air Force]] or [[Royal Navy]] Qualified Weapons Instructor courses. It is the equivalent to the [[United States Air Force Weapons School]] Course or [[US Navy]]'s [[Naval Strike and Air Warfare Center]] warfare schools (including [[TOPGUN]]). Graduates of a QWI course are entitled to wear a QWI 'patch' on their flying suit or combat uniform, which denotes their status as an expert practitioner in their warfare specialty or platform. While QWI, [[TOPGUN]] and the [[United States Air Force Weapons School]] were traditionally associated with the employment of kinetic weapons and with historical origins in the combat aircraft community, modern warfare experts recognize that kinetic and non-kinetic weapons systems are critical in current and future combat engagements. This is reflected in the expansion of the respective warfare schools over the past two decades<ref name="af.mil">{{cite web|url=http://www.nellis.af.mil/About/FactSheets/Display/tabid/6485/Article/284156/united-states-air-force-weapons-school.aspx |title=United States Air Force Weapons School > Nellis Air Force Base > Display |website=Nellis.af.mil |date=2016-05-10 |accessdate=2017-02-23}}</ref><ref name="navy.mil">{{cite web|url=http://www.public.navy.mil/AIRFOR/nawdc/Pages/About.aspx |title=Commander, Naval Air Forces > NAWDC > About |website=Public.navy.mil |date=1996-07-11 |accessdate=2017-02-23}}</ref> Recognizing this, the RAF has recently expanded the QWI qualification to included several non-kinetic fields and now strives to achieve Full Spectrum Warfare through effects based warfare.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.raf.mod.uk/role/airpoweruncertainworld.cfm |title=Air Power in an Uncertain World |publisher=RAF |date= |accessdate=2017-02-23}}</ref> QWI is not to be confused with QFI [[Qualified Flying Instructor]] which is a non-tactical qualification.
==Overview== Recognizing that modern warfare requires [[Effects-based operations]] and [[Full-spectrum dominance]], the RAF has expanded its QWI programme beyond pure weapons kinetic effects and fighter aircraft tactics. Much like the equivalent weapons and warfare schools in the US, the RAF now qualifies expert level instructors in many fields.
As of January 2017 the RAF delivers the following courses. * QWI - Typhoon/Reaper weapons system tactics and employment * QWI (ISR) - non-kinetic and [[Intelligence, surveillance, target acquisition, and reconnaissance]] employment and delivery of full spectrum warfare.
As requirements continue to evolve for the RAF, future courses may be created as requirements dictate.
Applicants to the QWI program are usually at the end of the first or second tour of duty and have operationally demonstrated above average qualities and capabilities in their field and are usually the top performing aircrew or operators in their squadron.
The course lasts between 7 and 9 months. Selected applicants start their course of study with a Combined Ground School where Student Instructors receive awareness level capabilities briefs on pan-defence subjects, such as platform capabilities and limitations, UK MoD programmes and initiatives, and basic Combined Air Operations (COMAO) tactics. This is followed by 6–8 months of training back at their respective squadrons in the use of the weapons systems specific to their trade. The course culminates in the operational phase, Exercise COBRA WARRIOR (Formerly known as the Combined QWI (CQWI)), where all that they learnt is put into practice and student instructors from each branch must integrate and deliver full spectrum capabilities. Exercise COBRA WARRIOR is the practical application of the Find, Fix, Track, Target, Engage, Assess (F2T2EA)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.airforcemag.com/MagazineArchive/pages/2000/july%202000/0700find.aspx |title=Air Force Magazine |website=Airforcemag.com |date= |accessdate=2017-02-23}}</ref> or Find, Fix, Finish, Exploit, Analyze, Disseminate (F3EAD)<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.dtic.mil/dtic/tr/fulltext/u2/a547092.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2017-01-25 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170202024913/http://www.dtic.mil/dtic/tr/fulltext/u2/a547092.pdf |archivedate=2017-02-02 |df= }} </ref> killchains requires coordinated efforts among all participants to successfully achieve the commander's objectives. Fast jet QWI plan for kinetic weapons effects (both air-air and air-ground) and once handed a target complete Target, Engage and Assess. QWI (ISR) provides the Find, Fix, Track and Assess portion of the kill chain. Each morning the QWI students are given an [[Air Tasking Order]] (ATO). They then need to plan the appropriate missions required to fulfil the commander's objectives laid out by the ATO and promulgated in higher level tasking documentation.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.theinsightonline.co.uk/features/54r-sqn-qwi-isr-course-3/ |title=54(R) Sqn QWI ISR Course 3 |publisher=The Insight Online |date=2013-04-18 |accessdate=2017-02-23}}</ref> With different types of aircraft and effects and a robust simulated adversary, planning is complex and typically requires an entire day to plan while mission execute only takes 1–2 hours.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.raf.mod.uk/news/archive/cqwi-exercise-23072013 |title=CQWI Exercise |website=Raf.mod.uk |date= |accessdate=2017-02-23}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.globalaviationresource.com/reports/2009/cqwi2009.php |title=CQWI Course 2009 |publisher=Global Aviation Resource |date= |accessdate=2017-02-23}}</ref>
All graduates are awarded 'QWI' annotation in the <nowiki>[[Air Force List]]</nowiki> and are recognized as experts for their respective platforms and fields through continued merit, professionalism and achievement. At international training events, such as Operation RED FLAG, QWIs are held in the same regard and to the same standard as USAF and USN patch wearers and are often employed in the tactical mentor role both in exercises and in real world operations.
Recognizing a lack of experts in employing ISR weapons systems, in Feb 2010 the RAF introduced an additional QWI course for aircrew of Intelligence Surveillance and Reconnaissance platforms (such as Reaper, Rivet Joint, E-3 Sentry and Sentinel) and Intelligence Officers. This course is equivalent to the Maritime ISR Weapons and Tactics Instructor run through the [[Naval Strike and Air Warfare Center]] [[US Navy]]<ref name="navy.mil" /> and represents a blend of the Command and Control Operations course (8th Weapons Squadron) and Intelligence Sensor Weapons Instructor Course (19th Weapons Squadron) run by the USAF Weapons School.<ref name="af.mil" /> While traditional QWI focuses on becoming a platform expert and advanced kinetic weapons effects, the QWI (ISR) provides experts in pan-defence non-kinetic and ISR weapons systems.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.raf.mod.uk/rafwaddington/aboutus/54rsquadron.cfm |title=RAF Waddington - 54 (R) Sqn |website=Raf.mod.uk |date= |accessdate=2017-02-23}}</ref>
Pilots of other air forces can attend the school through the [[Ministry of Defence (United Kingdom)|Ministry of Defence]]'s International Defence Training Programme.<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20071018051055/http://idtraf.mod.uk/325_807.html RAF MOD]</ref>
==See also== *[[United States Air Force Weapons School]] *[[TOPGUN]] *[[Naval Strike and Air Warfare Center]] *[[No. 54 Squadron RAF]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [https://www.raf.mod.uk/idtraf/courses/807.cfm RAF About the Course] * [http://www.globalaviationresource.com/reports/2009/cqwi2009.php UK CQWI] * [http://www.raf.mod.uk/rafwaddington/aboutus/54rsquadron.cfm 54(R) Sqn] * [http://www.public.navy.mil/AIRFOR/nawdc/Pages/About.aspx Naval Aviation Warfighting Development Center] * [http://www.nellis.af.mil/About/FactSheets/Display/tabid/6485/Article/284156/united-states-air-force-weapons-school.aspx USAF Weapons School]
[[Category:Military education and training in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Ministry of Defence (United Kingdom)]] [[Category:Royal Navy]] [[Category:Royal Air Force]]

{{Infobox book | name = On the Right to Philosophy | title_orig = Du droit à la philosophie | translator = | image = File:The Right to Philosophy, French edition.jpg | caption = Cover of the first edition | author = [[Jacques Derrida]] | illustrator = | cover_artist = | country = France | language = French | series = | subject = [[Philosophy]] | publisher = | release_date = 1990 | english_release_date = 2002 (volume one)
2004 (volume two) | media_type = Print | pages = | isbn = | dewey= | congress= | oclc= | preceded_by = | followed_by = }} '''''On the Right to Philosophy''''' ({{lang-fr|Du droit à la philosophie}}) is a 1990 book by French philosopher [[Jacques Derrida]]. It collects all of Derrida's writings, from 1975 till 1990, on the issue of the teaching of philosophy, the academic institution and the politics of philosophy in school and in the university. It has been translated in English in two volumes: '''''Who's Afraid of Philosophy?: Right to Philosophy 1''''' (2002), and '''''Eyes of the University: Right to Philosophy 2''''' (2004). ==Contents== Volume 1 contains the essay ''Where a Teaching Body Begins and How It Ends'', (pp. 67–91) first published separately in 1976 in France;[http://www.culturemachine.net/index.php/cm/article/view/183/164][https://web.archive.org/web/20080504145724/http://sun3.lib.uci.edu/~scctr/Wellek/jacques.html] and the 1977 essay ''The Age of Hegel'' (pp. 117–157). ==Notes and references== {{Reflist}} ==Further reading== *Derrida's ''[[The Right to Philosophy from the Cosmopolitical Point of View]]'' (1997) *Derrida's interview with Robert Maggiori, ''Once Again from the Top: Of the Right to Philosophy,'' in ''[[Libération]]'', November 15, 1990, republished in ''[[Points...: Interviews, 1974-1994]]'' (1995). ==External links== *[https://books.google.com/books?id=103Koc9coZQC ''Who's afraid of philosophy?: Right to philosophy 1''] *[https://books.google.com/books?id=p7wog2So0h4C ''Eyes of the university: Right to philosophy 2''] * Peter Trifonas [http://www.ffst.hr/ENCYCLOPAEDIA/doku.php?id=derrida_and_the_philosophy_of_education ''Jacques Derrida as a Philosopher of Education''], Encyclopaedia of Philosophy of Education {{Jacques Derrida}} [[Category:1990 books]] [[Category:2002 books]] [[Category:2004 books]] [[Category:Education books]] [[Category:Education reform]] [[Category:Philosophy books]] [[Category:Works by Jacques Derrida]]

:{{Other people|Robert Ross}} '''Robert S. Ross''' (born April 9, 1954) is a professor of political science at [[Boston College]], associate of the [[Fairbank Center for Chinese Studies]] at [[Harvard University]], senior advisor of the security studies program at the [[Massachusetts Institute of Technology]], and a member of the [[Council on Foreign Relations]]. He is one of the foremost American specialists on Chinese foreign and defense policy and [[U.S.-China relations]].
==Bibliography==
*''Negotiating Cooperation: The United States and China, 1969-1989''; 1995 *''Great Wall and Empty Fortress: China's Search for Security'' (with [[Andrew J. Nathan]]); 1998 *''Chinese Security Policy: Structure, Power, and Politics'': 2009
As editor:
*''China, the United States, and the Soviet Union: Tripolarity and Policy Making in the Cold War''; 1993 *''East Asia in Transition: Toward a New Regional Order''; 1997 *''After the Cold War: Domestic Factors and U.S.-China Relations''; 1998 *''Engaging China: The Management of an Emerging Power'' (with Alastair Iain Johnston); 1999 *''Re-examining the Cold War: U.S.-China Diplomacy, 1954-1973'' (with Changbin Jiang); 2001 *''New Directions in the Study of China's Foreign Policy'' (with Alastair Iain Johnston); 2006
*''China in the Era of Xi Jinping: Domestic and Foreign Policy Challenges'' (with Jo Inge Bekkevold):2016.
==External links== *[http://www.bc.edu/schools/cas/polisci/facstaff/ross.html Boston College bio] *[http://web.mit.edu/ssp/people/ross/fellow_ross.html M.I.T. bio]
{{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Ross, Robert S.}} [[Category:Boston College faculty]] [[Category:Harvard University people]] [[Category:Massachusetts Institute of Technology faculty]] [[Category:American political scientists]] [[Category:Political science educators]] [[Category:Political science writers]] [[Category:International relations scholars]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:1954 births]]
{{US-polisci-bio-stub}}

revision.comment: Removed erroneous inclusion in category "Prima ballerinas"
revision.text:
{{refimprove|date= June 2014}}
'''Roma Pryma-Bohachevsky''' ({{lang-uk|Рома Прийма-Богачевська}}, [[Romanization of Ukrainian|translit.]] ''Roma Pryima-Bohachevs'ka'') (1927 – May 23, 2004) was a [[dance]]r and [[choreographer]], who instructed thousands of students in the art of [[ballet]] and [[Ukrainian dance]].
==Education== Roma Pryma was born into a musical family in [[Przemyśl]], a city in present-day [[Poland]], but spent her formative years in [[Lviv]], a city in present-day western [[Ukraine]] (at the time, part of a newly established [[Ukrainian SSR|Soviet republic]]). At the age of 5, her mother, Ivanna Pryma, sensing her daughter's talent for movement, enrolled her in [[eurhythmics]] classes, as well as in the study of [[modern dance]], under M. Bronevska, a disciple of [[Mary Wigman]]. Between the years 1939–44, Roma began performing at the [[Lviv Opera and Ballet Theater]], and after a year and a half, she moved up from serving in the [[corps de ballet]], to small [[solo (dance)|solo]] roles of a [[character dance|character]] nature. Leaving her homeland after [[World War II]], Roma and her mother resettled in Austria in 1944, where after 3 years she graduated with honors from the [[University of Music and Performing Arts, Vienna|Academy of Music and Dramatic Arts]] in [[Vienna]] and later became a soloist in the ballet group of the National Theater in [[Innsbruck]].
At this point, Roma turned away from pursuing a career dedicated to classical ballet and followed her roots in alternative expression. After a meeting with [[Harald Kreutzberg]] at his villa in the [[Alps]], she began to focus on creating [[Expressionist dance|expressionistic choreographies]].
==Career== Ms. Bohachevsky's stage appearances included solo performances and concert tours of Europe, North America and Central America. Eventually, she turned to teaching and choreography, influenced by the methods of Agrippina Vaganova and Martha Graham, with whom she studied.
Among Mrs. Bohachevsky's many choreographic creations are "Peer Gynt," "Kvit Paporoti" (Blossoming Fern), and "Cinderella," which have been danced over the years by hundreds of her students. At each summer camp, Mrs. Bohachevsky brought to life a Fairy Tale, weaving traditional and classical themes with imaginative staging, choreography, and costumes. The summer camps continue as of June, July, and August 2014 under her namesake at [[Soyuzivka]] Ukrainian Heritage Center in the [[Shawangunk Mountains]] of Kerhonkson, New York.<ref>http://soyuzivka.com/camps.html</ref>
More impressive choreographies are the ones she created specifically for the Syzokryli Ukrainian Dance Ensemble, composed of her most talented students. Each choreography brings out the beauty of the Ukrainian theme developed in the dance, interwoven with elements of ballet, modern and stylized folk dance. Among her creations are "Battle for Freedom," a dramatic ballet commemorating the tragedy of Chernobyl, and "Icona," a historical recreation celebrating the millennium of Christianity in Ukraine. Shortly, after her death, a concert performed in Lincoln Center showcased much of the work she had taught her students.
==References== {{reflist}}
==Bibliography== *Pasternakova, Maria (1964). ''Ukrainian Woman in Choreography'', Ukrainian Women's Association of Canada & Natalia Kobrynska Foundation.
==External links== *[http://www.syzokryli.com/rpbudf_main.htm Roma Pryma Bohachevsky Ukrainian Dance Foundation] at [http://www.syzokryli.com www.syzokryli.com] *[http://www.brama.com/syzokryli/ukr.html Biography] at [http://www.brama.com www.brama.com]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Pryma-Bohachevsky, Roma}} [[Category:1927 births]] [[Category:2004 deaths]] [[Category:Ballet teachers]] [[Category:Ukrainian ballerinas]] [[Category:Ukrainian choreographers]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=April 2017}} {{Use British English|date=April 2017}} {{refimprove|date=January 2014}} {{Infobox architect | name = Ron Herron | image = | image_size = <!-- if image is smaller than 250px --> | caption = | birth_date = {{Birth date|df=yes|1930|08|12}} | birth_place = London, UK | death_date = {{Death date and age|df=yes|1994|10|01|1930|08|12}} | nationality = | alma_mater = [[University of Westminster|Regent Street Polytechnic]], London | influences = | influenced = | practice = Herron Associates | significant_buildings = | significant_projects = | significant_design = [[Walking City|The Walking City]] (1965) | awards = }} '''Ronald James "Ron" Herron''' (1930 in [[London]], [[England]] – 1994) was a notable English [[architect]] and teacher. He was perhaps best known for his work with the seminal English experimental architecture collective [[Archigram]], which was formed in London in the early 1960s. Herron is the creator of one of the group's best known and celebrated projects, the [[walking city]].
==Early life and education== Ron Herron was born in London on 12 August 1930, to a leather-working family. He studied draughtsmanship at the Brixton School of Building<ref name="Indy obit">{{cite news|author=Sutherland Lyall |title=Obituary: Professor Ron Herron |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/people/obituary-professor-ron-herron-1440981.html |date=5 October 1994 |work=[[The Independent]] |accessdate=26 January 2014 }}</ref> and architecture at the [[University of Westminster|Regent Street Polytechnic]] in [[London]].
==Academic career== Taught at the Architectural Association in London from 1965 until 1993, when he was appointed as professor and Head of the School of Architecture at the University of East London.
==Professional career== In 1981 he formed Herron Associates, along with his sons Andrew and Simon. The firm built the acclaimed Imagination Headquarters in London and were involved in the design for Canada Water station.
==Archigram== Shortly after finishing his architectural studies, Herron went to work for the [[London County Council]], alongside fellow future Archigram members Warren Chalk and Dennis Crompton. They were joined by Peter Cook, [[Michael Webb (architect)|Mike Webb]], and David Greene, who had been meeting regularly as a group at a cafe called Swiss Cottage, and had already published a homemade pamphlet under the moniker "Archigram" (ARCHitecture + teleGRAM). After the publication of the second issue, Cook, Webb and Greene sought out Herron, Chalk and Crompton, whom they knew by reputation. Those six formed the core of Archigram. In 1963 the group was invited by [[Theo Crosby]] to do an exhibition on "The Living City" at the Institute of Contemporary Arts, which became a manifesto of sorts.
==The Walking City== Herron is remembered for his "Walking City", later described as "the international icon of radical architecture of the Sixties".<ref name="Indy obit" /> Between 1964 and 1966, the concepts for the Walking City were published in Archigram.<ref name=":0">{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/1008911381|title=Phantom Architecture|last=Wilkinson|first=Philip|publisher=|year=2017|isbn=1471166422|location=New York|pages=|chapter=Walking City|oclc=1008911381}}</ref> They consist of multi-story buildings mounted on giant, telescopic steel legs, with an ovoid and insect-like form, and while highly detailed, show little about how the ideas are meant to work in practice.<ref name=":0" /> Resembling the [[Maunsell Forts]], they appeared warlike to some, leading Herron to be heckled at a conference in [[Folkestone]] in 1966 when he spoke about the Walking City.<ref name=":0" /> However, they were intended to be more like "survival pods" than weapons.<ref name=":0" />
==Personal life== Herron married Pat Ginn in 1954 and they remained together until his death. They had two sons.<ref name="Indy obit" />
Herron died at [[Woodford Green]], Essex on 1 October 1994.<ref name="Indy obit" />
==References== {{reflist}}
{{Authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Herron, Ron}} [[Category:1930 births]] [[Category:1994 deaths]] [[Category:20th-century English architects]] [[Category:Artists from London]] [[Category:English teachers]]

{{Other uses}} {{pp-semi|small=yes}} {{pp-move-indef}} {{Infobox person | name = Rosa Parks | image = Rosaparks.jpg | caption = Rosa Parks in 1955, with [[Martin Luther King Jr.]] in the background | birth_name = Rosa Louise McCauley | birth_date = {{birth date|1913|2|4}} | birth_place = [[Tuskegee, Alabama|Tuskegee]], [[Alabama]], U.S. | death_date = {{death date and age|2005|10|24|1913|2|4}} | death_place = [[Detroit]], [[Michigan]], U.S. | resting_place = [[Woodlawn Cemetery (Detroit, Michigan)|Woodlawn Cemetery]], Detroit, Michigan, U.S. | occupation = Civil rights activist | known_for = [[Montgomery bus boycott]] | movement = [[Civil rights movement]] | spouse = {{marriage|Raymond Parks|1932|19 August 1977|reason=died}} | signature = Rosa Parks Signature.svg }} '''Rosa Louise McCauley Parks''' (February 4, 1913 – October 24, 2005) was an [[activism|activist]] in the [[civil rights movement]] best known for her pivotal role in the [[Montgomery Bus Boycott]]. The [[United States Congress]] has called her "the first lady of civil rights" and "the mother of the freedom movement".{{USPL|106|26}}. Retrieved November 13, 2011. The quoted passages can be seen by clicking through to the text or PDF. On December 1, 1955, in [[Montgomery, Alabama|Montgomery]], [[Alabama]], Parks rejected bus driver [[James F. Blake]]'s order to relinquish her seat in the "colored section" to a white passenger, after the whites-only section was filled. Parks was not the first person to resist bus segregation, but the [[National Association for the Advancement of Colored People|National Association for the Advancement of Colored People (NAACP)]] believed that she was the best candidate for seeing through a court challenge after her arrest for [[civil disobedience]] in violating Alabama segregation laws. Parks' prominence in the community and her willingness to become a controversial figure inspired the black community to boycott the Montgomery buses for over a year, the first major direct action campaign of the post-war civil rights movement. Her case became bogged down in the state courts, but the federal Montgomery bus lawsuit ''[[Browder v. Gayle]]'' succeeded in November 1956.{{Cite episode | title = The Other Rosa Parks: Now 73, Claudette Colvin Was First to Refuse Giving Up Seat on Montgomery Bus | series = [[Democracy Now!]] | url=http://www.democracynow.org/2013/3/29/the_other_rosa_parks_now_73 | accessdate = April 18, 2013 | publisher = [[Pacifica Radio]] | network = NPR | last1 = González | first1 = Juan | last2 = Goodman | first2 = Amy | date = March 29, 2013 | minutes = 25 }}{{cite web| title= PARTING THE WATERS: America in the King Years| publisher= Simon & Schuster| year= 1988| first= Taylor| last= Branch| url= http://www.colorado.edu/conflict/branch4.htm| accessdate= February 5, 2013| archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20130523192706/http://www.colorado.edu/conflict/branch4.htm| archive-date= 2013-05-23| dead-url= yes| df= }} Parks' act of defiance and the [[Montgomery bus boycott]] became important symbols of the movement. She became an international icon of resistance to [[Racial segregation in the United States|racial segregation]]. She organized and collaborated with civil rights leaders, including [[Edgar Nixon]], president of the local chapter of the NAACP; and [[Martin Luther King, Jr.]], a new minister in Montgomery who gained national prominence in the civil rights movement and went on to win a [[Nobel Peace Prize]]. At the time, Parks was secretary of the Montgomery chapter of the NAACP. She had recently attended the [[Highlander Research and Education Center|Highlander Folk School]], a [[Tennessee]] center for training activists for workers' rights and racial equality. She acted as a private citizen "tired of giving in". Although widely honored in later years, she also suffered for her act; she was fired from her job as a seamstress in a local department store, and received death threats for years afterwards. Shortly after the boycott, she moved to [[Detroit]], where she briefly found similar work. From 1965 to 1988 she served as secretary and receptionist to [[John Conyers]], an African-American [[United States House of Representatives|US Representative]]. She was also active in the [[Black Power]] movement and the support of [[political prisoners]] in the US. After retirement, Parks wrote her autobiography and continued to insist that the struggle for justice was not over and there was more work to be done.{{Cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/posteverything/wp/2015/12/01/how-history-got-the-rosa-parks-story-wrong/|title=How History Got Rosa Parks Wrong|last=Theoharis|first=Jeanne|date=December 1, 2015|work=|access-date=|via=Washington Post}} In her final years, she suffered from [[dementia]]. Parks received national recognition, including the NAACP's 1979 [[Spingarn Medal]], the [[Presidential Medal of Freedom]], the [[Congressional Gold Medal]], and a posthumous statue in the United States Capitol's [[National Statuary Hall]]. Upon her death in 2005, she was the first woman and third non-US government official to [[State funerals in the United States#List of lying in state and honor recipients|lie in honor]] in the [[Capitol Rotunda]]. [[California]] and [[Missouri]] commemorate [[Rosa Parks Day]] on her birthday February 4, while [[Ohio]] and [[Oregon]] commemorate the occasion on the anniversary of the day she was arrested, December 1. ==Early years== Rosa Parks was born '''Rosa Louise McCauley''' in [[Tuskegee, Alabama]], on February 4, 1913, to Leona (née Edwards), a teacher, and James McCauley, a [[carpenter]]. She was of [[Cherokee]]-[[Muscogee|Creek]] descent Douglas Brinkley, ''Rosa Parks'', Chapter 1, excerpted from the book published by Lipper/Viking (2000), {{ISBN|0-670-89160-6}}. [http://partners.nytimes.com/books/first/b/brinkley-parks.html Chapter excerpted] on the site of the ''New York Times''. Retrieved July 1, 2008 with one of her great-grandmothers having been a documented [[Slavery among Native Americans in the United States|Native American slave]]. Additionally, she had a [[Scotch-Irish Americans|Scots-Irish]] great-grandfather. {{cite news| first= Douglas |last= Brinkley| work=Rosa Parks| title= Chapter 1 (excerpt): 'Up From Pine Level'| publisher= Lipper/Viking; excerpt published in ''The New York Times'' |year= 2000| isbn= 0-670-89160-6| url= http://partners.nytimes.com/books/first/b/brinkley-parks.html | access-date= July 1, 2008}}Webb, James. {{cite web|url=http://www.parade.com/articles/editions/2004/edition_10-03-2004/featured_0 |title="Why You Need to Know the Scots-Irish" |accessdate=September 2, 2006 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090704152512/http://www.parade.com/articles/editions/2004/edition_10-03-2004/featured_0 |archivedate=July 4, 2009 |df= }}, ''[[Parade (magazine)|Parade]]'', October 3, 2004. Retrieved July 1, 2008. She was small as a child and suffered poor health with chronic [[tonsillitis]]. When her parents separated, she moved with her mother to [[Pine Level, Montgomery County, Alabama|Pine Level]], just outside the state capital, [[Montgomery, Alabama|Montgomery]]. She grew up on a farm with her maternal grandparents, mother, and younger brother Sylvester. They all were members of the [[African Methodist Episcopal Church]] (AME), a century-old independent [[Black church|black denomination]] founded by free blacks in [[Philadelphia]], [[Pennsylvania]], in the early nineteenth century. McCauley attended rural schools until the age of eleven. As a student at the [[Industrial School for Girls]] in Montgomery, she took academic and vocational courses. Parks went on to a laboratory school set up by the [[Alabama State University|Alabama State Teachers College for Negroes]] for secondary education, but dropped out in order to care for her grandmother and later her mother, after they became ill.{{cite book | title=Rosa Parks: Tired of Giving In | publisher=Enslow | last= Shraff| first= Anne | year=2005 | pages=23–27 | isbn=978-0-7660-2463-2 |url=https://books.google.com/?id=J37vgZvCI78C&pg=PA23&dq=Industrial+School+for+Girls+in+Montgomery+Rosa+Parks#v=onepage&q=Industrial%20School%20for%20Girls%20in%20Montgomery%20Rosa%20Parks&f=false}} Around the turn of the 20th century, the former Confederate states had adopted new constitutions and electoral laws that effectively [[Disenfranchisement after the Reconstruction Era|disenfranchised]] black voters and, in Alabama, many poor white voters as well. Under the white-established [[Jim Crow laws]], passed after Democrats regained control of southern legislatures, racial segregation was imposed in public facilities and retail stores in the [[Southern United States|South]], including public transportation. Bus and train companies enforced seating policies with separate sections for blacks and whites. School bus transportation was unavailable in any form for black schoolchildren in the South, and black education was always underfunded. Parks recalled going to elementary school in Pine Level, where school buses took white students to their new school and black students had to walk to theirs:
I'd see the bus pass every day... But to me, that was a way of life; we had no choice but to accept what was the custom. The bus was among the first ways I realized there was a black world and a white world. {{cite web|url=http://www.thehenryford.org/exhibits/rosaparks/story.asp|accessdate=July 1, 2008|title=The Story Behind the Bus|work=Rosa Parks Bus|publisher=[[The Henry Ford]]}}
Although Parks' autobiography recounts early memories of the kindness of white strangers, she could not ignore the [[Racism in the United States|racism]] of her society. When the [[Ku Klux Klan]] marched down the street in front of their house, Parks recalls her grandfather guarding the front door with a shotgun.{{cite news| url= http://www.gpo.gov/fdsys/pkg/CREC-1995-11-08/html/CREC-1995-11-08-pt1-PgE2135-2.htm |publisher= republished in Congressional Record Volume 141, Number 176; November 8, 1995| first= Walt |last= Harrington| title= A Person Who Wanted To Be Free| work=[[The Washington Post Magazine]] |date= 8 October 1995| accessdate= July 19, 2016}} The [[Montgomery Industrial School]], founded and staffed by white northerners for black children, was burned twice by arsonists. Its faculty was ostracized by the white community. Repeatedly bullied by white children in her neighborhood, Parks often fought back physically. She later said: "As far back as I remember, I could never think in terms of accepting physical abuse without some form of retaliation if possible."{{cite book| title= The Rebellious Life of Mrs. Rosa Parks| first= Jeanne |last= Theoharis| publisher= Beacon Press| year= 2013 | isbn= 9780807076927| url= https://books.google.com/?id=O9_YCwAAQBAJ&pg=PA208&lpg=PA208&dq=remember+rosa+parks+%22never+think+in+terms%22#v=onepage&q=remember%20rosa%20parks%20%22never%20think%20in%20terms%22&f=false| access-date= July 19, 2016}}{{rp|208}} === Early activism === In 1932, Rosa married Raymond Parks, a barber from Montgomery.{{rp|13, 15}}{{cite book| title= The Montgomery Bus Boycott| first1= Sabrina |last1= Crewe| first2= Frank |last2= Walsh | year= 2002| publisher= Gareth Stevens| chapter= Chapter 3: The Boycott| url= https://books.google.com/?id=YHwiynhKj9UC&pg=PA15&dq=%22raymond+parks%22+montgomery#v=onepage&q=%22raymond%20parks%22%20montgomery&f=false| page=15| access-date= July 19, 2016| isbn= 9780836833942 }} He was a member of the [[NAACP]], which at the time was collecting money to support the defense of the [[Scottsboro Boys]], a group of black men falsely accused of raping two white women.{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/?id=RSGhEUq5bp0C&lpg=PA690&dq=raymond%20parks%20%22scottsboro%20boys%22&pg=PA690#v=onepage&q=raymond%20parks%20%22scottsboro%20boys%22&f=false|title=Icons of Black America: Breaking Barriers and Crossing Boundaries|last=Whitaker|first=Matthew|date=March 9, 2011|publisher=ABC-CLIO|year=|isbn=9780313376436|location=|pages=|language=en}}{{Rp|690}} Rosa took numerous jobs, ranging from domestic worker to hospital aide. At her husband's urging, she finished her high school studies in 1933, at a time when less than 7% of African Americans had a high-school diploma. In December 1943, Parks became active in the [[civil rights movement]], joined the Montgomery chapter of the NAACP, and was elected secretary at a time when this was considered a woman's job. She later said, "I was the only woman there, and they needed a secretary, and I was too timid to say no."{{cite news |title=Rosa Parks, civil rights icon, dead at 92 |work=Boston Globe |date= October 25, 2005 |url=http://www.boston.com/news/globe/obituaries/articles/2005/10/25/rosa_parks_civil_rights_icon_whose_single_act_sparked_a_movement_at_92/|accessdate=July 31, 2009 |first=Mark |last=Feeney}} She continued as secretary until 1957. She worked for the local NAACP leader [[Edgar Nixon]], even though he maintained that "Women don't need to be nowhere but in the kitchen."{{cite book|title=Freedom's Daughters: The Unsung Heroines of the Civil Rights Movement from 1830 to 1970|last= Olson| first= L.| date= 2001| publisher= Scribner| isbn= 9780684850122|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=lddD_IFIJisC&pg=PA97|page=97|accessdate=August 1, 2015}} When Parks asked, "Well, what about me?", he replied: "I need a secretary and you are a good one." In 1944, in her capacity as secretary, she investigated the gang-rape of [[Recy Taylor]], a black woman from [[Abbeville, Alabama]]. Parks and other civil rights activists organized "[[The Committee for Equal Justice]] for Mrs. Recy Taylor", launching what the ''[[Chicago Defender]]'' called "the strongest campaign for equal justice to be seen in a decade."{{Cite news |url=http://inamerica.blogs.cnn.com/2012/12/01/opinion-its-time-to-free-rosa-parks-from-the-bus/ |title=Opinion: It's time to free Rosa Parks from the bus |accessdate=December 22, 2012 |first= Danielle |last=McGuire |work=CNN |date=December 1, 2012}} Although never a member of the [[Communist Party USA|Communist Party]], she attended meetings with her husband. The notorious [[Scottsboro Boys|Scottsboro case]] had been brought to prominence by the Communist Party.{{Cite news | title= How 'Communism' Brought Racial Equality To The South| publisher= National Public Radio| date= February 16, 2010| work= Tell Me More|url=https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=123771194 |accessdate= July 19, 2016}} In the 1940s, Parks and her husband were members of the [[Voters' League]]. Sometime soon after 1944, she held a brief job at [[Maxwell Air Force Base]], which, despite its location in [[Montgomery, Alabama]], did not permit racial segregation because it was [[federal government of the United States|federal]] property. She rode on its integrated trolley. Speaking to her biographer, Parks noted, "You might just say Maxwell opened my eyes up." Parks worked as a housekeeper and seamstress for [[Clifford Durr|Clifford]] and [[Virginia Foster Durr|Virginia Durr]], a white couple. Politically [[American liberalism|liberal]], the Durrs became her friends. They encouraged—and eventually helped sponsor—Parks in the summer of 1955 to attend the [[Highlander Research and Education Center|Highlander Folk School]], an education center for activism in workers' rights and racial equality in [[Monteagle, Tennessee]]. There Parks was mentored by the veteran organizer [[Septima Clark]]. In 1945, despite the Jim Crow laws and discrimination by registrars, she succeeded in registering to vote on her third try.{{Rp|690}} In August 1955, black teenager [[Emmett Till]] was brutally murdered after reportedly flirting with a young white woman while visiting relatives in [[Mississippi]].[http://www.usdoj.gov/opa/pr/2004/May/04_crt_311.htm "Justice Department to Investigate 1955 Emmett Till Murder"], [[United States Department of Justice]], May 2004. Retrieved May 27, 2007. R. Alexander Acosta, Assistant Attorney General for the Civil Rights Division, states, "This brutal murder and grotesque miscarriage of justice outraged a nation and helped galvanize support for the modern American civil rights movement." On November 27, 1955, four days before she would make her stand on the bus, Rosa Parks attended a mass meeting at Dexter Avenue Baptist Church in Montgomery that addressed this case as well as the recent murders of the activists [[George W. Lee]] and [[Lamar Smith (activist)|Lamar Smith]]. The featured speaker was [[T. R. M. Howard]], a black civil rights leader from Mississippi who headed the [[Regional Council of Negro Leadership]].{{cite book| first1=David T. |last1= Beito | first2= Linda |last2= Royster Beito| title= Black Maverick: T. R. M. Howard's Fight for Civil Rights and Economic Power| location= Urbana| publisher= University of Illinois Press| year=2009| pages= 138–39}} Howard brought news of the recent acquittal of the two men who had murdered Till. Parks was deeply saddened and angry at the news, particularly because Till's case had garnered much more attention than any of the cases she and the Montgomery NAACP had worked on—and yet, the two men still walked free.{{Cite web|url=http://rosaparksbiography.org/bio/emmett-till/|title=Emmett Till {{!}} The Rebellious Life of Mrs. Rosa Parks|website=rosaparksbiography.org|access-date=September 11, 2016}} ==Parks and the Montgomery bus boycott== {{Main|Montgomery bus boycott}} [[File:Rosaparks busdiagram.jpg|thumb|Seat layout on the bus where Parks sat, December 1, 1955]] ===Montgomery buses: law and prevailing customs=== In 1900, Montgomery had passed a city ordinance to segregate bus passengers by race. Conductors were empowered to assign seats to achieve that goal. According to the law, no passenger would be required to move or give up their seat and stand if the bus was crowded and no other seats were available. Over time and by custom, however, Montgomery bus drivers adopted the practice of requiring black riders to move when there were no white-only seats left.''[[Browder v. Gayle]]'', 142 F. Supp. 707 (1956) The first four rows of seats on each Montgomery bus were reserved for whites. Buses had "colored" sections for black people generally in the rear of the bus, although blacks composed more than 75% of the ridership. The sections were not fixed but were determined by placement of a movable sign. Black people could sit in the middle rows until the white section filled; if more whites needed seats, blacks were to move to seats in the rear, stand, or, if there was no room, leave the bus. Black people could not sit across the aisle in the same row as white people. The driver could move the "colored" section sign, or remove it altogether. If white people were already sitting in the front, black people had to board at the front to pay the fare, then disembark and reenter through the rear door.Garrow, David J. ''Bearing the Cross: Martin Luther King Jr. and the Southern Christian Leadership Conference.'' (1986) {{ISBN|0-394-75623-1}}, p. 13. For years, the black community had complained that the situation was unfair. Parks said, "My resisting being mistreated on the bus did not begin with that particular arrest. I did a lot of walking in Montgomery." One day in 1943, Parks boarded a bus and paid the fare. She then moved to her seat but driver [[James F. Blake]] told her to follow city rules and enter the bus again from the back door. When Parks exited the vehicle, Blake drove off without her. [https://www.theguardian.com/news/2002/mar/27/guardianobituaries "James F. Blake"], ''The Guardian'' obituaries, March 26, 2002. Retrieved December 27, 2016. Parks waited for the next bus, determined never to ride with Blake again.{{cite news|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2005/oct/25/nation/na-parks25 | title = She Set Wheels of Justice in Motion | work=[[Los Angeles Times]] |first=Elaine|last= Woo|date=October 25, 2005| accessdate=July 22, 2011}} ===Her refusal to move=== {{multiple image|width=250|direction=vertical |header=Rosa Parks' arrest|header_align=center |image1=Rosa Parks Booking.jpg|caption1=Booking photo of Parks |image2=Rosaparks policereport.jpg|caption2=Police report on Parks, December 1, 1955, page 1 |image3=Rosaparks policereport2.jpg|caption3=Police report on Parks, December 1, 1955, page 2 |image4=Rosa Parks being fingerprinted by Deputy Sheriff D.H. Lackey after being arrested for boycotting public transportation - Original.jpg|caption4=Rosa Parks being fingerprinted by Deputy Sheriff D.H. Lackey |image5=Rosaparks fingerprints.jpg|caption5=[[Fingerprint]] card of Parks }} After working all day, Parks boarded the Cleveland Avenue bus, a [[General Motors]] [[GM "old-look" transit bus|Old Look bus]] belonging to the [[National City Lines|Montgomery City Lines]],{{cite web |url=http://www.busmag.com/pdfs/2002-09_RPBus.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=March 14, 2016 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150906131826/http://www.busmag.com/pdfs/2002-09_RPBus.pdf |archivedate=September 6, 2015 |df= }} around 6 p.m., Thursday, December 1, 1955, in downtown Montgomery. She paid her fare and sat in an empty seat in the first row of back seats reserved for blacks in the "colored" section. Near the middle of the bus, her row was directly behind the ten seats reserved for white passengers. Initially, she did not notice that the bus driver was the same man, James F. Blake, who had left her in the rain in 1943. As the bus traveled along its regular route, all of the white-only seats in the bus filled up. The bus reached the third stop in front of the Empire Theater, and several white passengers boarded. Blake noted that two or three white passengers were standing, as the front of the bus had filled to capacity. He moved the "colored" section sign behind Parks and demanded that four black people give up their seats in the middle section so that the white passengers could sit. Years later, in recalling the events of the day, Parks said, "When that white driver stepped back toward us, when he waved his hand and ordered us up and out of our seats, I felt a determination cover my body like a quilt on a winter night."{{Cite book|page=48|last1=Williams|first1=Donnie|first2= Wayne |last2= Greenhaw |publisher=Chicago Review Press| year= 2005| isbn=1-55652-590-7|title=The Thunder of Angels: The Montgomery Bus Boycott and the People who Broke the Back of Jim Crow}} By Parks' account, Blake said, "Y'all better make it light on yourselves and let me have those seats."{{cite interview |last=Parks |first=Rosa |interviewer=Lynn Neary |title=Parks Recalls Bus Boycott, Excerpts from an interview with Lynn Neary |chapter=Main Reason For Keeping Her Seat |type=radio interview |url=https://www.npr.org/player/v2/mediaPlayer.html?action=1&t=1&islist=false&id=4973548&m=4973703 |format=adobe flash |publisher=[[National Public Radio]] |year=1992 |accessdate=December 1, 2014 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141201233016/http://www.npr.org/player/v2/mediaPlayer.html?action=1&t=1&islist=false&id=4973548&m=4973703 |archivedate=2014-12-01 |deadurl=yes |quote= |df= }} linked at {{cite web |url=https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=4973548 |title=Civil Rights Icon Rosa Parks Dies |last= |date=October 25, 2005 |website= |publisher=NPR |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20051102021843/http://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=4973548 |archivedate=November 2, 2005 |accessdate=July 4, 2008 }} Three of them complied. Parks said, "The driver wanted us to stand up, the four of us. We didn't move at the beginning, but he says, 'Let me have these seats.' And the other three people moved, but I didn't."[http://www.cnn.com/2005/US/10/24/parks.obit/ "Civil rights icon Rosa Parks dies at 92"], CNN, October 25, 2005. Retrieved July 4, 2008. The black man sitting next to her gave up his seat. Parks moved, but toward the window seat; she did not get up to move to the redesignated colored section.Audio interview of Parks linked from [https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=4973548&sourceCode=gaw "Civil Rights Icon Rosa Parks Dies"], [[National Public Radio]], October 25, 2005. Retrieved July 4, 2008. Parks later said about being asked to move to the rear of the bus, "I thought of [[Emmett Till]] and I just couldn't go back."{{cite book|last1=Houck|first1=Davis|last2=Grindy|first2=Matthew|title=Emmett Till and the Mississippi Press|location=Jackson, Miss.|publisher=University Press of Mississippi|date=2008|isbn=9781604733044|page=x}} Blake said, "Why don't you stand up?" Parks responded, "I don't think I should have to stand up." Blake called the police to arrest Parks. When recalling the incident for ''[[Eyes on the Prize]]'', a 1987 public television series on the Civil Rights Movement, Parks said, "When he saw me still sitting, he asked if I was going to stand up, and I said, 'No, I'm not.' And he said, 'Well, if you don't stand up, I'm going to have to call the police and have you arrested.' I said, 'You may do that.'"{{Cite book|title=Eyes on the Prize: America's Civil Rights Years, 1954-1965|page=66|last=Williams|first=Juan|authorlink=Juan Williams| year= 2002| publisher= Penguin Books|isbn=0-14-009653-1}} During a 1956 radio interview with [[Sydney Rogers]] in [[West Oakland]] several months after her arrest, Parks said she had decided, "I would have to know for once and for all what rights I had as a human being and a citizen."{{Cite book|title=The Beloved Community: How Faith Shapes Social Justice from the Civil Rights to Today|page=21|last=Marsh|first=Charles|publisher=Basic Books|year=2006|isbn=0-465-04416-6}} In her autobiography, ''My Story'', she said: {{quote|People always say that I didn't give up my seat because I was tired, but that isn't true. I was not tired physically, or no more tired than I usually was at the end of a working day. I was not old, although some people have an image of me as being old then. I was forty-two. No, the only tired I was, was tired of giving in.{{Cite book|last=Parks|first=Rosa|author2=James Haskins |title=Rosa Parks: My Story |page=116|publisher=Dial Books |isbn=0-8037-0673-1 |year=1992}}}} When Parks refused to give up her seat, a police officer arrested her. As the officer took her away, she recalled that she asked, "Why do you push us around?" She remembered him saying, "I don't know, but the law's the law, and you're under arrest."[http://achievement.org/autodoc/page/par0int-1 Rosa Parks Interview] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111004015059/http://achievement.org/autodoc/page/par0int-1 |date=October 4, 2011 }} (video and text of interview), [[Academy of Achievement]], June 2, 1995. Retrieved November 13, 2011. She later said, "I only knew that, as I was being arrested, that it was the very last time that I would ever ride in humiliation of this kind...." Parks was charged with a violation of Chapter 6, Section 11 segregation law of the Montgomery City code,{{Cite book|title=The Birth of the Montgomery Bus Boycott|page=27|last=Wright|first=Roberta Hughes|year=1991|publisher=Charro Press|isbn=0-9629468-0-X}} although technically she had not taken a white-only seat; she had been in a colored section.{{Cite book|title=Blessed Unrest: How the Largest Movement in the World Came Into Being, and Why No One Saw it Coming|page=79|last=Hawken|first=Paul|publisher=Viking|year=2007|isbn=0-670-03852-0}} [[Edgar Nixon]], president of the Montgomery chapter of the NAACP and leader of the [[Pullman Union|Pullman Porters Union]], and her friend [[Clifford Durr]] bailed Parks out of jail that evening.{{Cite book|last1=Phibbs|first1=Cheryl|title=The Montgomery Bus Boycott: A History and Reference Guide|page=15|publisher=Greenwood|year=2009|isbn=978-0313358876|url= https://books.google.com/books?id=HKPtlNXNILsC&pg=PA15&dq=booked,+fingerprinted,+imprisoned+clifford+fred+Gray+danger+white+activist+lawyer+volunteered+make+bail+parks+took+home+e.d.+nixon+Later+evening+station&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwj7-pjt05XRAhUDtpQKHZEMBZYQ6AEIGzAA#v=onepage&q=booked%2C%20fingerprinted%2C%20imprisoned%20clifford%20fred%20Gray%20danger%20white%20activist%20lawyer%20volunteered%20make%20bail%20parks%20took%20home%20e.d.%20nixon%20Later%20evening%20station&f=false }}{{Cite book| page= 9| last=Burns|first=Stewart|title=Daybreak of Freedom: The Montgomery Bus Boycott|publisher=UNC Press| year= 1997| isbn=0-8078-4661-9}} Parks did not originate the idea of protesting segregation with a bus [[sit-in]]. Those preceding her included [[Bayard Rustin]] in 1942,{{cite journal | journal = Fellowship | last = Rustin | first = Bayard | date = July 1942 | title = Non-Violence vs. [[Jim Crow]]}} reprinted in {{cite book| last1= Carson| first1= Clayborne| authorlink1= Clayborne Carson|last2=Garrow|first2=David J.|authorlink2=David J. Garrow| last3= Kovach| first3= Bill| authorlink3= Bill Kovach|title=Reporting Civil Rights: American journalism, 1941–1963| url= https://books.google.com/books?id=9j8OAQAAMAAJ|accessdate=September 13, 2011|year=2003|publisher=Library of America| pages= 15–18}} [[Irene Morgan]] in 1946, [[Lillie Mae Bradford]] in 1951,{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2006/apr/04/usa.julianborger|title=Civil rights heroes may get pardons|first=Julian|last=Borger|date=3 April 2006|accessdate=23 March 2017|newspaper=[[The Guardian]]}} [[Sarah Keys v. Carolina Coach Company|Sarah Louise Keys]] in 1952, and the members of the ultimately successful ''[[Browder v. Gayle]]'' 1956 lawsuit ([[Claudette Colvin]], [[Aurelia Browder]], [[Susie McDonald]], and [[Mary Louise Smith (civil rights activist)|Mary Louise Smith]]) who were arrested in Montgomery for not giving up their bus seats months before Parks. ===The boycott=== Nixon conferred with [[Jo Ann Robinson]], an [[Alabama State College]] professor and member of the [[Women's Political Council]] (WPC), about the Parks case. Robinson believed it important to seize the opportunity and stayed up all night [[mimeograph machine|mimeographing]] over 35,000 handbills announcing a bus boycott. The Women's Political Council was the first group to officially endorse the boycott. On Sunday, December 4, 1955, plans for the Montgomery Bus Boycott were announced at black churches in the area, and a front-page article in the ''[[Montgomery Advertiser]]'' helped spread the word. At a church rally that night, those attending agreed unanimously to continue the boycott until they were treated with the level of courtesy they expected, until black drivers were hired, and until seating in the middle of the bus was handled on a first-come basis. The next day, Parks was tried on charges of [[disorderly conduct]] and violating a local ordinance. The trial lasted 30 minutes. After being found guilty and fined $10, plus $4 in court costs, Parks appealed her conviction and formally challenged the legality of racial segregation. In a 1992 interview with [[National Public Radio]]'s Lynn Neary, Parks recalled: {{quote|I did not want to be mistreated, I did not want to be deprived of a seat that I had paid for.
